narrative: On 3/6/2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha met with applicant Kacey Mobley Andrews via tele-inspection. LPA met with applicant via tele-inspection based on unavailable space during time of office refresh at the Monterey Park Children’s Residential office. The purpose of tele inspection is to discuss next phase of applicants review for licensure and component 2 requirements. LPA and applicant discussed the following: · Fingerprinting and associating individuals to facility. · Financial information and supportive documentation ( Surety Bond). · Personnel report · Program Statement/ Plan of operation · Component 3 orientation Applicant will update program statement, update financial report, personnel report, emergency disaster plan, and provide updates to LPA by April 4, 2025. Exit interview completed, no deficiencies cited, and a copy of this report was given to applicant.

On 5/21/2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an announced visit to the K and K Small Family Home for the purpose of a Pre-licensing inspection. LPA met with applicant and together did a walk thru of facility. LPA observed the following: This is a single story single family home located in a residential area. This home is a three (3) bedrooms, two (2) bathroom home with two (2) living spaces, kitchen, and attached garage. Home has backyard and cameras located on exterior of home. Cameras do have sound capabilities and are monitored by applicant. No cameras are located in private restricted areas of home. LPA observed the following: Kitchen- Had required perishable and non- perishable food, pantry and locked cabinets for cleaning supplies and knives located in closet adjacent to bedroom #1. Outside of kitchen area was a fully charged fire extinguisher and first aid kit. Dining room table had required amount of seating for capacity of 3 children. Living space occupied by one (1) sectional, TV mounted on wall. Storage closet adjacent to bedroom #1 occupied by filing cabinet for client files, knives, cleaning solutions and medications. Bedroom 1: Vacant, occupied with one (1) queen size bed, closet and dresser drawers available Bedroom 2: Vacant/ occupied with one (1) toddler twin bed, and one (1) crib, dresser drawers available. Bedroom had no closet present at time of inspection. Bathroom #1: located adjacent to master bedroom- Occupied by one (1) jet tub and shower. Door lock is latch lock from inside of door. Bedroom 3 Master bedroom: Occupied by applicant, closet, door to bedroom able to be locked on inside. Applicant to change locking mechanism on door to make room inaccessible to children in care.

Bathroom #2: Located off of storage/ laundry area. Lock has a dead bolt on inside of bathroom leading into storage area. Applicant to change lock mechanisms to make storage/ laundry area inaccessible to children in care. Backyard: Consisted of full barbecue grill, shed and bar area with various areas of seating. Locking mechanisms were available to make areas inaccessible to children. Garage: Occupied by various items of storage. Laundry/ Storage area occupied by one washer/ dryer and various items including decorations and utensils. Area is accessible off of second bathroom and garage. At the time of this inspection all carbon monoxide and smoke detectors tested audible. LPA observed a full first aid kit with all the required first aid kits. LPA told applicant to post LIC610C, activity log, menu, LIC500, facility sketch, license (once obtained) and to update emergency disaster book with client roster and LIC610C. Additionally, LPA told applicant to remove all alcoholic beverages and potentially hazardous items in bathroom #1 to area inaccessible to children. Applicant to obtain closet for bedroom #2. Water temperature measured at 147 degrees Fahrenheit. LPA told applicant to adjust water temperature to meet regulation of a temperature between 105 and 120. At the time of this inspection home was clean and free of all obstructions. Applicant to send LPA pictures of items discussed and corrections made. Exit interview completed, no deficiencies cited and a copy of this report was provided to applicant.

On 4/15/2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha met with applicant Kacey Mobley via virtual teams meeting for the purpose of a Case- management- other inspection. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct the component 3 section of the application process. LPA played the component 3 pre recorded video and provided guidance to applicant on where to obtain outstanding documents and scheduled pre licensing visit. Exit interview was completed and no deficiencies were cited.

On 02/15/2024 at 10:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Pamela Silva conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection at the above address. LPA met with Kellee Gray, applicant. A physical plant inspection was conducted. The following were observed at the time of inspection: This facility is a two- story home located in a residential neighborhood. The facility consists of 5 bedrooms, 2 and a half (2.5) bathrooms, a game room, a living and family room, kitchen, dining room,3-car garage, a laundry room, and a backyard. Overall, the facility is clean, sanitary and in good condition. The facility has no bodies of water. The facility has a centralized heat and air-conditioning unit. Temperatures in all rooms are maintained at 68 degrees (F). The hot water temperature was measured at 106 degrees (F). Carbon monoxide and smoke alarms were tested and observed to be operational. There are two (2) fire extinguishers, one in the family room and one in the hallway on the second floor. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions, knives and sharps are kept in a locked closet in the hallway. The facility has a working telephone. The applicant reports no firearms on the premises. The grounds are free from obstructions and hazards. Clients will be utilizing bedrooms #2, #3, #4 and #5. During inspection, LPA observed that each bedroom has one (1) bed and has adequate closet and drawer space to accommodate client's clothing and personal belongings. Bedroom #1 will be occupied by the applicant. Each bed has clean pillows, pillowcases, bed sheets and blankets. LPA also observed extra linens stored in the hallway closet in the second floor. Client records and staff records will be stored and locked in the hallway closet in the living room. Medications will be centrally stored in the hallway closet in the second floor. A complete first aid kit is readily available in a central location in the facility. Applicant reports that License, Emergency Plan (LIC 601) and facility sketch will be posted at the facility. The fire clearance inspection has been completed.

LPA also conducted Component III - Category Specific Orientation with the applicant. The following items were discussed and provided to the applicant: -Title 22 regulations on Small Family Homes - Continuing Requirements (General Licensing Requirements) - Personnel Records (forms) - Client Records (forms) -Reporting Requirements - Other administrative forms Applicant submitted the final Program Statement/Plan of Operation to LPA. Applicant also submitted the revised LIC200. An exit interview was conducted a signed copy of this report was provided to the applicant.

On June 6, 2024 at 3:30 P.M., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Demetris Teal conducted an unannounced case management inspection. Purpose of the inspection was to pick up late filed incident reports and TB test for Mr. Alberto Jimenez. Reports and TB test were received. LPA interviewed S1 (see confidential 811 dated June 6, 2024) regarding late filing incident reports. LPA discussed the procedures to send in the reports and the email address to send them to. LIC 624 discussed. LPA discussed SFH regulations. LPA will send email of Care Tool so the Administrator can review. Technical Advisory was discussed with Administrator. Exit interview conducted. Signed copy of the 809, confidential names list and appeal rights were left with Administrator.

On March 18, 2025 at 5:10 P.M. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Demetris Teal conducted an unannounced case management discussion at K3 care services. LPA met with Kellee Gray- Licensee/Administrator. Purpose of the visit was to discuss incident reports received by CCL. LPA discussed five (5) incident reports received on January 14, 2025. Two (2) were dated January 5, 2025 and two (2) were dated January 6, 2025. These reports were received late. Citation will be issued for late reporting. On January 14, 2025, CCL received an incident report informing the department that K3 Care Services staff went to the facility mail box and retrieved a package addressed to a K3 Care Services client. K3 Care Services staff opened mail belonging to a client. Based on discussions with the Licensee/Administrator, she were not aware of any court order disallowing the opening of clients mail. Licensee/Administrator will check to see if there was a court order. Citation will be issued. Facility cited for violations of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6 Section 80061 (b)(1)(E) Reporting Requirements, 83072 (d) (9) Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted. A signed copy of this report along with 811 (Confidential Name List), and appeal rights were left with Licensee/Administrator.

deficiencies.description:
80061(b)(1)(E) Reporting Requirements:
Upon the occurrence,...a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day...(1).Events reported shall include the following:..(E) Any unusual incident......
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, it was determined that the facility failed to report multiple incidents that occurred on 01/05/25 and 01/06/25, within the agency's next working day, as required. which poses a potential  health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee/Administrator will conduct retraining with SFH staff regarding the regulation and email proof to LPA.

deficiencies.description:
83072(d)(9) Personal Rights:
(d) The licensee shall ensure that each child...is accorded the personal rights....as applicable: (9)To have access to...receive unopened mail unless prohibited by court order.
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, and staff interview it was determined that the facility viiolated clients right to receive unopened mail. There was no court order in place as required. which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee/Administrator will conduct retraining with SFH staff regarding the regulation and email proof to LPA.

narrative: The Following Allegation was reported: 1. The staff hit a minor in care. The Licensee (S1) refuted the claims, asserting that they do not condone physical or verbal abuse as a disciplinary method. Instead, S1 prefers to incentivize positive behavior through rewards or by revoking privileges such as access to electronic devices. S1 further elaborated on their active participation in their children's daily lives, ensuring that they provide all necessary support for the children's success. S1 mentioned having a discussion with FC1 about the discrepancies in FC1's academic performance and emphasized the significance of honesty regarding their after-school activities for safety reasons. A statement from FC1 confirmed that they felt secure and enjoyed living in the SFH with S1. However, when questioned about the alleged incident, FC1 claimed that S1 had punched them in the stomach and kicked them in the leg after FC1 admitted to struggling with their grades. FC1 could not provide additional details about the incident and stated that no one else was present at that time. FC2 also denied the allegations, stating that they had never witnessed or heard S1 engage in any form of physical or verbal abuse within the home. FC2 further clarified that while they were in their room, they overheard a conversation between S1 and FC1 regarding academic issues, as their rooms were adjacent, but they denied witnessing any physical altercation. Information gathered from S2 and S3 indicated that S1 is highly engaged with the children, frequently taking them on trips and assisting FC1 and FC2 with their homework as needed. Additionally, the findings from the Bakersfield Police report # GO# 2024-215730 indicated that the discrepancies in the accounts provided by both FC1 and FC2, coupled with the injuries not corresponding to a fist impact to the abdomen, led to the conclusion that there was insufficient probable cause to arrest S1 for child endangerment under PC 273a. Furthermore, FC1 has not expressed any issues regarding residing in the SFH residence and has shown a willingness to return to the home. Therefore, based on the information received, the above allegation is determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation(s) occurred, therefore the allegation is found to be unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the Licensee. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report along with the (LIC 811) was left with the Licensee.

narrative:
On February 18, 2025 at 12:50 P,M., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Demetris Teal conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection at the above named facility. LPA met with Licensee, Kellee Gray. The facility currently has a Small Family Home (SFH) license. The SFH is licensed to serve up to six (6) clients ages 3 to 17. The facility can serve ambulatory developmentally disabled clients, Regional Center clients, County placed clients and provide one on one care. There is currently one (1) client in placement. The LPA requested the following: Personnel Report LIC500, Client Roster, Clients and Staff Files. The facility is a two-story home with 6 bedrooms, living room, kitchen, backyard and two (2) full bathroom with one (1) toilet in each and one half bathroom. There are no firearms or ammunition in the facility. There are no bodies of water in the facility premises. At 1:30 P.M., LPA conducted a walk-through of the entire facility. Physical Plant The license, facility sketch, personal rights, emergency disaster form, complaints poster, emergency phone numbers and food menu are posted in a prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept inaccessible and locked in a storage area. Sharps/knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked storage area. Facility has non-perishable food for at least one week and perishable food for at least two days. Medications are centrally stored in a locked room in the hallway. Smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and in proper working order. Fire extinguisher was fully charged. First Aid Kits were checked and found to be complete. Room temperatures are maintained at 76 degrees F. The hot water temperature was tested and measured at 120 degrees F. All sinks, showers and toilets are in working order. No more than 2 children share a bedroom. All beds are in good repair; equipped with good springs, clean mattresses and pillows. Overall, facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Continued....

.......continued Operations Facility maintains a register of clients and the register is available upon request. The facility administrator/licensee and capable staff are responsible for communicating with emergency personnel in the facility. Client Records LPA reviewed one (1) client record. Client record was available to the licensing agency to inspect, audit and copy upon demand. Client record contained required information including, but not limited to, consent forms, individual treatment plans, medical assessment, safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables; personal rights forms; and medication administration records. Updated JV220 was not observed Staff Records LPA reviewed five (5) staff records. All staff have been subjected to criminal records review and have been fingerprinted and cleared with DOJ, FBI and CACI. The administrator/licensee meets the required qualifications and/or experience. Documentation of the required education and experience requirements are maintained in the personnel file. LPA verified direct care staff training's. There was one citation and two (2) technical advisories assessed during this inspection. Exit interview conducted.

On January 27, 2023 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes began a pre-licensing inspection for Kalns Small Family Home license. LPA met with applicant Kameron Taylor who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Currently there are no clients placed in the home. The applicant is applying to serve three clients ages 0 to 17. The home is a one story building with four bedrooms and two bathrooms which are set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 (Master) has one bed, will sleep the licensee, and has a master bathroom. · Bedroom #2 (Client) was vacant, had one twin; and will sleep one client. · Bedroom #3 (Client) was vacant, had two twin-sized beds. It will sleep two clients. · Bedroom #4 (children’s) has two twin size beds, and will sleep applicants daughters.. · A great room/living room, kitchen, dining area, two bathrooms, an attached two car garage, a laundry room, storage closet, and the backyard. The Client’s bedroom was arranged so that no more than two clients will share the room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the client’s belongings. There was a smoke detector in every bedroom and a carbon monoxide detector located in the hallway. The four smoke detectors and the carbon monoxide detector were checked, and they were working properly. The home’s central air conditioning module was in the back yard. The home’s water heater was located in a hot water closet that can be accessed from the side yard. The Fireplace had glass doors and a gate. The appliances were in working order. CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE:

The client’s files will be locked inside a locked cabinet in the applicant’s room. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable foods. A proper storage of all food was discussed. A trash can for storage of solid waste with a tight-fitting lid and was located next to the refrigerator. The hot water in the Master Bathroom measured to be 117.3 degrees Fahrenheit. The client bathroom also had a trash can with a working lid. The water temperature of the client bathroom was observed to be 121.3 degrees Fahrenheit. The home’s First Aid kit was accessible the first aid kit was missing the first aid manual, Band aids, tweezers, scissors, and adhesive tape and located in the cabinet next to the refrigerator. A fire extinguisher was present in the home and located under the kitchen sink. It was observed to be properly charged but needs to be inspected by the fire department. Applicant stated there were no weapons/firearms in the home. LPA observed there was no swimming pool. The backyard where clients will have access to play was completely fenced. The following deficiencies were observed: The required forms needed prior to operation, were not posted at the time of this inspection. The First Aid Kit was missing the first aid manual, Band aids, tweezers, scissors, and adhesive tape. The fire extinguisher needs to be checked by the fire department. The water temperature in Bathroom 2 measured to be 121.3 degrees. The request for a license will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval once the Plan of Corrections are cleared. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to Kameron Taylor.

met_with: Administrator and Alta Regional Service Coordinator
narrative: On 12/15/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Rivera and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez had a virtually meeting with Administrator (AD) and Alta Regional Service Coordinator (ASC) to discuss placement of two Non-Minor Dependents (NMDs) that reside in the facility. The department informed AD that their facility is only licensed for youth 0-17 years old and will need to transition the NMDs into an adult facility. A waiver was previously granted for 1 NMD due to the COVID-19 pandemic and "shelter-in-place" order, however, the waiver expired on 7/30/2021. AD asked for an additional waiver for both NMDs,due to being medically fragile and the COVID-19 pandemic. NMD 1- 22 years old on 11/22/21, placed at 19 months old Completes school 12/2021 Ventilated 12 hours at night, on oxygen 24/7 No family contact Non-ambulatory, crawls around the facility and only uses wheelchair for outside transports Has Chronic Lung Failure, everyone in facility is vaccinated and social distancing due to Pandemic NMD 2- 23 years old on 7/2021, placed at 22 months old Has G-Tube and low dose of chemotherapy Medically Fragile Ambulatory AD has two other placements in the home, 12 years old and 16 years old, they are both medically fragile as well. The department provided AD with two options for the NMDs to remain at the facility. The first option discussed is for AD to adopt the NMDs. The second option is to license the facility as an adult facility. AD reported needing time to make a decision. The department issued a 6 month waiver to AD which will allow the NMD to remain at the facility until 6/30/2021. During the next 6 months, AD will need to make a decision and inform ASC and LPA Rivera.

LPA conducted a walk-through of the facility inside and out. There was 2 staff, 2 residents and 2 Non-Minor Dependents at the facility during the inspection. One staff was interviewed, due to the clients' developmental and medical fragility, no interviews were conducted. LPA observed 7 bedrooms, 3 bathrooms, and a storage room. LPA inspected and/or reviewed the following: Physical Plant Posting of license and Personal Rights Disinfectants/Cleaning solutions inaccessible Nonperishable Foods at least one week and fresh perishable foods at least two days Working telephone, Carbon monoxide detectors and Smoke Detector, First Aid Kit fully stocked Common Room available and Dining area (enough seating, furniture good condition, not broke or damaged) Medication centrally stored, locked/inaccessible Hot Water between 105-120 degree F Fully charged Fire Extinguisher. Page 1 of 2

Toilets, sink, bath and shower fixtures in good repair Soap and Paper towels and Laundry Facilities in working condition Bedrooms have required linen and furnishings Pool has 5 ft fencing and is locked at all times Disaster Preparedness Disaster and mass casualty plan updated and available Quarterly Drills conducted and documented Disaster preparedness supplies verified- generator and multiple flashlights throughout the home Staffing 3 Staff files reviewed-Criminal record clearances verified First Aid Certificates Client Records 4 of Clients files reviewed, Individual Program Plans Centrally Stored Medication and log reviewed Special Health Care Needs (SHCN) SHCN plan created by licensed professional and implemented as required Staff received training hours-12 hours The following items were reviewed for compliance in the regional office prior to the facility inspection: · Annual fees · Emergency Disaster Plan (per H&S Code 1565) · Personnel Roster, Facility Sketch, LIC 610C and LIC 308 · Waivers and Exceptions An exit interview was conducted with Kathleen Shorts and a copy of this report was emailed to kt_short@msn.com Page 2 of 2

On 10/28/22 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacqueline Carmona conducted an on-site inspection to the above facility. LPA met with the Kathleen Shorts, Licensee. The purpose of this inspection was to confirm that the Small Family Home (SFH) had been vacated of clients. LPA Carmona was given a tour of the interior and exterior of the home. There were no indications of ongoing placement's observed. LPA Carmona was formally notified of this closure via a telephone call on 08/11/22 and a written closure request was received on 08/12/22. The reason for the closure is due to the Licensee retiring and will no longer be able to provide services to this population. The posted license was surrendered, and an updated closure plan was also obtained by this LPA during today’s inspection. The closure plan indicated that the two children’s services were not interrupted during the transition to the new placement. LPA Carmona informed the licensee that there were no current outstanding annual fees, and the facility will be closed on 10/31/22. No citations were issued as a result of this inspection. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report will be emailed to Kathleen Shorts, Licensee.

On June 25, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Deborah Lee and Licensing Program Analyst Kenrick Ellis arrived at the above facility, for the purpose of conducting a Pre- licensing inspection for a Small Family Home License. LPA met with applicant, Eric Kinney who granted access into the home. The applicant and LPAs toured the facility both inside and out. Currently residing in the home is applicant. Applicant is requesting to be licensed for 4 clients ages 3-17 ambulatory only. The home was inspected and the following was observed: This is a one-story house on a duplex property with private home behind facility. The property does not contain a garage, a pool, or backyard. There is a chain link fence around the entire property. Living Room/Family Room: There is adequate furniture which is in good condition. The area is is equipped with a sofa, 4 straight back chairs, 32’ television with gaming system on an entertainment center. Home entrance is protected by a black bar screen, followed by wooden door. Windows operational with vertical blind and screens are operational. There is hardwood flooring with an area rug located in the living room in front of sofa. Dinning area contains a four seated dining set with four straight back chairs. There is a wall heater next to the entertainment center with safety wall heater cover. Smoke alarms were tested during the inspection; there are a total of 4 smoke detectors (2 combo—Carbon/smoke detector located in living room and hallway, 2 smoke in bedrooms 1 and 2) and they all in working condition. Formal Dining Area has a 4 seated dining table. Page 1 of 3

Kitchen: Is equipped with a functioning fire extinguisher mounted on the wall, an operable 4 burner stove, refrigerator/freezer, a chest deep freezer, small kitchen counter appliances, a proposed menu posted, locked cabinet for cleaning supplies and sharps to be inaccessible to clients in care. Bedroom #1: is located off of the hallway and is equipped with bunk bed, computer desk, operable computer, walk in closet with shelving and will be occupied by up to 2 clients. Bedroom #2: is located to right of hall way and is equipped with 2 twin beds, clean bedding, adequate closet, chest of drawers non operation ceiling fan ( has an operable standing portable fan. This room be occupied by up to 2 clients. Bedroom #3: is equipped with 1 king sized bed and it occupied by applicant. Room will be utilized a personal dwelling space and office. Room is equipped with desk computer, printer, office chair, refrigerator for potential medication storage. There is a locked container to be used for centrally stored medication. All rooms are clean, safe, and sanitary. Outdoor activity space (front yard) free of obstructions. The first aid kit checked and is complete with scissors, tweezers, thermometer, and gauzes, antiseptic. Fire Extinguisher available in the home. The home will utilize 2015 Dodge Charger to transport clients in care. Current automobile insurance is with Mercury Insurance Company and is current. Prior to being licensed the following is required: · Small repairs needed in driveway area. There was unlevelled concrete posing a potential safety. Applicant to repair area and send proof of repair to LPA. · Large rock to be removed from front yard which poses a potential safety hazard. Applicant to remove rock and show proof of removal to LPA Page 2 of 3

LPA’s recommendations: · Curtain rod in bedroom #1 needs to replaced · Written emergency/evaluation plan. Exit Interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed to applicant Page 3 of 3

Kitchen: Is equipped with a fire extinguisher that is mounted to the wall, stove with burners, refrigerator/freezer, and deep freezer. Weekly menu is posted. The cleaning supplies and sharp objects are in a locked cabinet and inaccessible to clients in care. Bedroom #1: Is located off the hallway and is equipped with bunk beds, a computer desk, an operable computer, a walk-in closet with shelving, and adequate lighting. Bedroom #3: Is equipped with one king sized bed and is occupied by the Licensee. The room will be utilized as a personal dwelling space and office. The room is equipped with a desk, computer, printer, and an office chair. There is a refrigerator and locked container to be used for centrally stored medication. Camera(s): There are two cameras located in the home. One camera is located in the living room corner. The other camera is located in the hallway. Mr.Kinney was advised to remove the sound to prevent voice recordings. The cameras are monitored through the Ring App. Facility was observed to be clean, safe, and sanitary. Water temperature is within a safe range. There are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the home. Outdoor activity space (front yard) is free of obstructions. The first aid kit is complete with required items. All smoke/carbon monoxide detectors were observed to be in working order. All posting requirements are met. Licensee advised that all assistant caregivers are required to be fingerprint cleared prior to working in the facility. The home will utilize 2015 Dodge Charger to transport clients in care. On June 2, 2025, at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Erika Butler, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), JoAunne Griffin conducted a Small Family Home (SFH) Component III office meeting with Licensee, Eric Kinney. narrative:
On July 28, 2025 at 2:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cheri Wilkerson, License Program Anaylst (LPA) Erika Butler-Williams and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Enrique Hernandez conducted an Informal Meeting with the Licensee Eric Kinney from Kinney Small Family Home. The meeting was conducted at El Segundo Local Unit Children Residential Regional Office located at 300 Continental Blvd El Segundo, CA 90245. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the facility concerns. El Segundo Children Residential has concerns on the following things: Complaint allegations 3 within 12 months License responsibilities and required presence Supervision and Training Mandated Reporting Responsibilities Document incident with Staff Protection of Child Personal Rights Facility Manager Concerns Staff Policy and Procedure Current food inventory practices and meal routines Capacity Change Request Discussion of intent and anticipated changes Open Discussion Summary of Next Steps (LIC Continued on 809C)

Recommendations: The department recommends that the Licensee document instances when staff do not adhere to policies and procedures. It is important to update staff policies and procedures regularly. Continuing to ensure the safety and well-being of all minors in the facility is essential. On January 6, 2024, at 11:45AM, Carrie Palmer, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), conducted an announced Pre-Licensing Inspection for relocation at the above address for the purpose of approval of its License and met with Jedidah Kiema, the Administrator. LPA Palmer toured the facility inside and outside with the Applicant. This is a 2-story house which will serve ambulatory children and non ambulatory children. The first story of the house consists of: a dinning area, kitchen, entrance to the backyard, living room, 1st bedroom, 2nd bedroom and 2 bathrooms (one full bath inside bedroom and 1/2 bathroom in the dining area. The first bedroom and full bath is currently occupied with an adult family member temporarily. The 2nd bedroom currently unoccupied and has a bed and closet. The kitchen had a leak under the sink, but was repaired on 1/6/25, per Administrator. There was a large black stain in the cabinet under the sink that appeared to be caused by the leak under the sink. The administrator states it will be addressed. The facility is also waiting for fire clearance. The request for fire clearance was submited on 12/10/25. The living room is very spacious with a small storage area under the stairs. LPA also observed the garage, where there is storage and the washer/dryer hookup. .Page 1 of 2

The 2nd story of the home consisted of bedroom 3, 4 and 5. The upstairs area opens into the loft/den area. To the right of the stairs, there is bedroom # 3. Bedroom 3 consist of one bed and a full bathroom, with lighting and is occupied by a family member. Bedroom 4 has two beds and two closet spaces with lighting. Bedroom 5 was the master bedroom and a full bathroom with 2 showers and one bathtub, a walk in closet and is occupied by the Administrator and CFO.. No citation was issued at this time. However, the proper finger printing and repair under the sink needs to be corrected before the facility can be licensed. No further inspection is needed at this time. A copy of this report was provided to the Small Family Home representative. An exit interview was conducted.

On February 25, 2022, at 10:30AM, Humberto Flores, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), conducted an announced Pre-Licensing Inspection at the above address for the purpose of approval of its License and met with Jedidah and Samuel Kiema, the Applicants. LPA Flores toured the facility inside and outside with the Applicants. This is a 2-story house located in a community and will serve ambulatory children only. The first story of the house consists of: dinning room, kitchen, living room and a half bathroom. LPA Flores observed that sharp items and knifes are locked with child proof safety locks (CPSL) and inaccessible. The chemicals are located inside a closet with CPSL in the bathroom, the bathroom has no shower. Medications will be stored in a locked cabinet compartment located in the kitchen. The second story of the house has 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms: Room #1: has a queen bed with a mattress, sheets and pillow and a crib its mattress, it has drawers and a closet. The Applicants disclosed that this room will be use by an employee when overnight stay is needed.

#2 Room #2: it has two beds with mattresses, sheets, pillows, drawers and a closet. There is a door that provides access to a small balcony. The Applicants will install alarm in the door as a safety feature and supervise when a child opens the door. Room #3: it has two beds with mattresses, sheets, pillows, drawers and a closet. There is a glass computer desk with a computer, keyboard and a chair. The Applicants were informed that bedrooms cannot be commonly used for other purposes, and the office equipment need to be removed. There is a door that provides access to a small balcony. The Applicants will install alarm in the door as a safety feature and supervise when a child opens the door. Room #4: Master Bedroom. It has a queen bed with mattres, sheets, pillows and a crib with its mattress and a bathroom. The bathroom has a shower and a tub. There is a third bathroom on the second story of the house with 2 sinks and a shower. This bathroom will be used by the placed children. The Applicants stated that there are no firearms in the house. The house temperature is maintained with a centralized air conditioning unit, during the inspection the temperature was at 68F. The water temperature was checked at 110F. The home phone was tested, and it is operational. The smoke detectors were checked and are operating properly. There are 2 fire extinguishers, 1 is located on the first story and the second one is located on the second story and are fully charged and not expired.

cont.#3 According to the Applicants, the local Fire Department conducted a Fire Inspection on 02/24/2022. Pending with the result that will be mail to the Licensing agency. The Applicants requested another extension to submit the corrections to the Program Statement (PS) that are due by 02/28/2022. LPA Flores informed that the new dateline is 03/14/2022. The Applicants were informed that this inspection is pending the installation of the alarms on the doors in the children’s bedroom #2 and #3, the Fire Clearance Inspection and the submission of the corrections needed of the PS. A video showing how the alarms works is needed and the Applicants agreed to send it to LPA Flores via text message. A copy of this report was provided to the Applicants. Exit interview conducted.

met_with: Jedidah W Kiema and Samuel Kiema
narrative:
On February 14, 2022, at 1:00PM, Humberto Flores, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), conducted a Component II Face to Face meeting with Jedidah Wanjiku Kiema and Samuel Kioko Kiema. The purpose of the face-to-face interview, was to held to discuss the application packet and process, and to ensure that the attendees understand the services outlined in the facility program. LPA Flores reviewed Title 22 of the California Code of Regulations, and the provisions that are specific to the applicant facility type. The applicants were provided with assistance in understanding the process in its entirety. During the interview it was discussed and analyzed the licensing forms that need correction or are missing information: - LIC200 – Application. Capacity it is 6 (#10), but then in #11 you input 2 infants’ clients, and 6 clients ages 3-17, that equals 8. Please correct it. - LIC308 – Designation of Facility Responsibility. The facility # 367800008 is missing. - LIC402 – The original form is needed and the amount of the bond must be for $3,000.00. - LIC500 – It needs to reflect a 24hrs schedule.

cont.#2 LPA Flores highlighted the areas of the Program Statement (PS) that need to be developed and corrected. The applicants were explained that there are Sections in the PS that do not require to be addressed in different sections if they belong to the same topic. LPA Flores emphasized that every time that a section of regulation is referenced, that regulation needs to be named. Acronyms are highly recommended, but they need to be spelled at least one time. The applicants were reminded that the dateline for submitting the corrections indicated in the e-mail sent on 01/28/2022, is 02/28/2022. A copy of this report was provided to the Applicants. Exit interview conducted.

On August 9, 2022, at 11:15AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Humberto Flores, conducted an unannounced Post-Licensing Inspection at Kiowanexus Small Family Home (SMH) and met with Samuel Jedidah. The purpose of the inspection was informed to the Licensee. During the inspection a copy of the Personnel Report was provided upon request. There is no client currently. The following topics were inspected: PHYSICAL PLANT: A tour of the facility was conducted, along with the Licensee. The License was placed in a prominent place. Children’s foster rights were available upon request. LPA Flores observed that the facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. The passageways are unobstructed. The disinfectants and cleaning solutions were stored away from the kitchen areas, food preparation areas to the children. The food is safe and of the quality and the quantity necessary to meet the needs of the clients.

cont.#2 Each meal meets at least 1/3 of the recommended in the USDA Basic Food Group Plan-Daily Food Guide. Supplies of staples non-perishable foods for one week and perishable foods for two days are maintained in the facility. The temperature in the rooms that clients will occupy is maintained between 68 and 85 degrees (F) and the hot water temperature was at 109 degrees (F). Emergency Intervention Plan: LPA Flores reviewed the Emergency Intervention Plan. CLIENT RECORDS: There is no client currently. Staff Records: A total of 2 employees’ file was reviewed. The files contain the following documentation: Child Abuse Index Checks/Department of Justice (DOJ)/Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) criminal record clearances, criminal record statement, a health screening with tuberculosis test and First Aid Certificate and Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation for the licensees. No citation was issued. No further inspection is needed. A copy of this report was provided to the SMH representative. Exit interview conducted.

An unannounced annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Carrie Palmer on 2/16/2024. During this visit, LPA Palmer met with Jedidah Kiema and Samuel Kiema. Physical Plant LPA Palmer toured the facility. This is a 2-story house located in an enclosed community serving ambulatory children and non ambulatory children. The first story of the house consists of: a dinning room, kitchen, living room, 1st bedroom and a bathroom. The chemicals are located inside the cabinet under the kitchen sink and inaccessible. Medications are stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. The second story of the house has 3 bedrooms and 2 bathroom. Operational Requirements The operational requirements were reviewed. LPA Palmer conducted an emergency drill with the provider and walked the property to locate the utility shut off valve located in the garage. Temporary Relocation Sites were listed and emergency phone numbers were posted. Disaster drills must be conducted every 6 months by the provider. . No citation was issued. A copy of this report was provided to the Small Family Home representative. Exit interview conducted.

An unannounced annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Carrie Palmer on 3/28/2024. During this visit, LPA Palmer met with Jedidah Kiema and informed her of the nature of the visit. The following domains were reviewed: Client Records and Children with Special Health Care Needs. Client Records During the review of the client records, LPA observed that the facility has a separate record for the client to include admission date and a signed placement agreement. The child’s file also includes the name, address, and phone number of doctors, dentist and mental health providers. Assessments were provided for the child including ambulatory status. A copy of the Needs and Services Plan and the Individual Program Plan were present in the file. The Designated Facility Responsibility Form includes the emergency contacts in the event facility representatives are not available. There was no Form 9158 (Telecommunications Form) observed in the file. LPA Palmer, emailed the form to the facility and the facility printed the form and placed it in the file during the visit. There is evidence that the Needs and Services Plan has been updated at least quarterly. Page 1 of 2

Medical Assessments were conducted within 30 days of acceptance and the medical assessments were in compliance (were not older than 1 year). The assessments were performed by licensed physicians. Diet restrictions were noted in the file. There was no evidence in the file regarding TB results and the facility administrator was unable to provide the document. Children with Special Health Care Needs During the review of client records it was observed that medical problems are listed in the Needs and Services Plan. It was also determined in an interview with the administrator and observation of storage in the facility that the small family home ensures the care for clients with incontinence and that products are stored to support the client such as diapers and wipes. The client is kept clean and dry and the facility remains free from odors. Technical Assistance Violation Telecommunications form LIC 9159 was not in the file. LPA sent the form to the Administrator during the review. Facility Administrator printed, signed form and placed in the file during Type B The facility staff was unable to provide evidence of TB results in the file for the child. One type B was issued and 1 technical assistance was issued during the visit. A copy of this report was provided to the Small Family Home representative. Exit interview was conducted. Page 2 of 2

On July 31, 2024, at 10:00 AM, Component II of the application process for K.E. Jones Living 625, located at 1415 W. Imperial Hwy, Los Angeles, CA 90047, took place at the California Department of Social Services, Community Care Licensing Division - Children’s Residential Program - Regional Office in El Segundo. In attendance were Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dennis Jarmin, (LPA) Kim Dear and Applicant Keoishe Jones. The purpose of this Component II meeting was to review the submitted application and Program Statement, addressing and resolving any outstanding items or concerns. The following incomplete application forms were discussed: o A3. Designation of Administrative Responsibility (LIC 308) • Need a designation of responsibility for the one individual designated as the authorized person of the facility to act in the licensee’s absence. o A12. Health Screening Report - Facility Personnel (LIC 503) • TB Test portion of the form must be filled out, including the result, or separate test verification is needed. o A15. Facility Sketch (LIC 999) • Sketch must give the dimensions of all rooms and designate their use. Door and window exits must be shown. Indicate exit routes by number as shown on the LIC 610/LIC 610A Emergency Disaster Plan. Rooms to be used by non-ambulatory clients/residents and staff should be identified. o Program Statement: o Update information in the area of medication destruction discussed, dietary options at school sample meal, and 30 days client post-admission assessment form required.

Update on the fire clearance. The applicant was advised that the revisions and/or corrections needed to the application and/or Program Statement are due by August 14, 2024. A Pre-Licensing Inspection will be conducted on August 23, 2024, at 9:00 AM. A copy of this report will be provided to Mr. Jones, the applicant..

On 08/14/2024, at 12:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dennis Jarmin and LPA Justine Armstrong conducted a pre-licensing visit with applicant Keoshe Jones at the above address. The home is a one story residence with 3 bedrooms and 1 full bathroom, currently with no children residing. The furniture throughout the home is in good condition. The living room features a sofa, wall mounted television, well maintained lighting, and an informational board with a computer desk near the hallway entry. The family room includes a sofa and a large mounted TV, with ample space for family activities, though there is an accessible open heater in the living room. The windows throughout the home are equipped with blinds and screens in good repair, providing natural light. The kitchen is well stocked with food representing all four food groups, and a fire extinguisher is wall mounted near the laundry area. LPAs confirmed that the smoke detectors located in the living room, bedrooms, and hallways are operable, along with an operable carbon monoxide sensor. A First Aid kit is available in a locked cabinet near the kitchen area. The home also features surplus cabinet space in the kitchen, secured with a locking mechanism, as well as a four burner stove, a microwave in good repair, and a dining table with appropriate seating located on the right side of the kitchen. A medication lock box is stored in the staff bedroom, and the hot water temperature was found to be between 105 and 120 degrees. The home is ventilated by natural air with fans throughout, supported by two large portable AC units in the family room and staff bedroom, and there are no bodies of water on the premises. All bleach and cleaning material are locked under the sink and knives were locked in the kitchen cabinet. LPAs observed no cameras at the time of the visit, and the applicant confirmed there are no firearms in the home. Bedroom #1, which is not occupied by the applicant, contains a twin-size bed and a night stand with drawers that need to be replaced with two separate night stands with drawers for each client, along with appropriate recessed lighting and a fan.

The following items were identified and recommended: 1. The applicant was advised to replace the bathroom trash can with one that has a lid. 2. Bedrooms #1 and #2 each need separate night stands with 4 drawers for each client. 3. The screen frame in Bedroom #2 needs to be repaired or replaced. 4. The applicant was advised to send a copy of the CA ID for the designated employee and the Criminal Record Statement (LIC 508D). 5. The open-faced heater located in the living room and hallway must be locked and made inaccessible. The home was clean; however, repairs were being conducted during the visit, and a follow-up visit is recommended. An exit interview was conducted with the applicant.

On June 19, 2023 at 10:03 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie began a Pre-Licensing inspection for a Small Family Home license. LPA met with applicants Latrine Smith and Jerrel Glasper led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicants. Applicants are applying for a capacity of 2 ambulatory clients. The home consists of: Downstairs: Bedroom #1, It was furnished with a queen bed. It sleeps applicant’s mother and father. There were also a living room, dining area and one bathroom. Upstairs: Bedroom #2, The room consisted of two full beds. It sleeps two biological sons, ages 12 and 14 years. Bedroom #3, The room was furnished with two full beds. It sleeps two biological daughters ages 14 and 18 years. Bedroom #4, The room was furnished with a bunk bed. It will sleep two clients. met_with: Licensees Latrina Smith and Jerrel Glasper
narrative:
On July 7th, 2025, at 09:40 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Claudia Aguilera arrived at L &J Small Family Home (SFH) to conduct and unannounced annual inspection. Currently, there is one ambulatory client, the home is licensed for a capacity of five clients. The Facility was toured both inside and out with Licensee Latrina Smith. The home is a two-story building with five bedrooms and three bathrooms. Upon entry, the downstairs floor consisted of the living room with television and couch. The dining area consisted of a large dining room table with eight chairs. The kitchen contained an island with two additional stools for seating, an operable fire extinguisher and a trashcan with a closed lid were observed. Bedroom #1 was also located downstairs and consisted of a bunk bed, large chair, closet and dressers and is currently vacant for two future clients. Bathroom #1 was fully inspected and functioning. The hallway closet remains locked, and it stores medications, sharps, first aid kit with all required items, and client files. An additional hallway storage space was observed to contain linens and hygiene products. The garage was inspected and used for storage. The water temperature was tested and measured at 112.6 degrees F. LPA observed a minimum of seven-day non-perishable and a three-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for the client as well. The upstairs consisted of the master bedroom that sleeps licensees and remains locked and also included bathroom #2. Bedroom #3 consists of one twin bed, a portable closet, television, a dresser and is currently vacant for one client. The laundry room was also located upstairs; cleansers/chemicals/detergents were locked and stored in the laundry room cabinet.

Bedroom #4 consisted of two twin beds, television, dresser, and closet. One twin bed is currently occupied by 17-year-old client, the other twin bed is currently vacant for a future client. Bathroom #3 was also located in the upstairs hallway, it was inspected and fully functioning. Bedroom #5 sleeps licensee’s biological son. No room was commonly used for other purposes other than a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room.There was adequate drawer and closet space for each child’s belongings. An additional upstairs closet was observed to store additional linens and games. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and working. Two operable fire extinguishers were observed: one upstairs and one downstairs . All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients have access. All windows and screens were in good repair. There were no guns or weapons in the home as stated by licensees. The Licensees were interviewed and one client and no issues were found. The facility outside grounds were also inspected and observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. Clients’ files and staff files were reviewed and found to be in compliance. During the visit, there were no deficiencies observed. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to Licensees.

On February 9, 2022 at 9:50 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie, met with licensee Ivonne Ugalde, who led a tour of the home. Currently, there are four clients in the home. Three are young adult (YA1, YA2) and two are under legal guardianship (YA3 and C1). The home is set up as follows: · Bedroom #1- YA1’s bedroom with full sized bed. Located downstairs. · Bedroom #2- Master suite with Cal-King. Licensee's bedroom. Located upstairs. · Bedroom #3- YA3’s bedroom has full sized bed. Located upstairs. · Bedroom #4- YA2’s bedroom has a full bed. Located upstairs. · Bedroom #5- C1’s bedroom has a full bed. Located upstairs. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The fireplace was properly screened. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the locked laundry room. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in locked kitchen cabinet. The first aid kit is located in the locked closet between the kitchen and the living room. There were no guns or weapons as stated by licensee at this time.

The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be within regulatory requirements. Proper storage of all food was noted. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. On March 08, 2022 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducing a required/annual inspection of the facility. LPA met with Jeffery Lear, Licensee and introduced self and explained the purpose of the visit. LPA began the required/annual inspection of the facility. The facility is a Small Family Home, consisting of six bedrooms and three bathrooms. There are a total of three clients in care, all are ambulatory. Three clients share a bedroom and they are compatible to share a room. There are a total of two live-in staff, the two licensees. LPA Verna completed a physical inspection of the facility and observed that: The facility was observed to be clean, organized, sanitary, safe and free of debris and clutter. The home contained a living room, a kitchen, dining room, and family room. The dining room and family room had a table for the clients to sit and eat, and complete activities and homework. The client bedrooms were observed to contain an individual bed or crib, clean linens, ample room for medical equipment and storage space for client property. There was a hall closet with extra blankets and linens. LPA observed client games and learning materials stationed in the kitchen dining area and family room. The facility license, facility sketch, emergency plan, emergency telephone numbers, were observed to be posted in a prominent place. The facility smoke and carbon monoxide detectors are present and were tested and are in working condition. The fire extinguisher was observed to be in a prominent location and was charged, up-to-date and was last serviced in the last year. The facility had documentation of drills being completed monthly, however the drills lacked details and what topics were covered during the drill. LPA recommended to licensee to create a disaster drill template, and to include more details about what topic/drill was covered, and any safety tests that were done, including testing of CO2 and smoke alarms in the SFH.

The refrigerator and freezer and pantry held enough perishable and nonperishable food in the home in a quantity to meet the needs of the next three meals and the between meal snacks. There was also a refrigerator and freezer located in the garage which held extra frozen foods and the refrigerated medication of the clients. The garage also stored storage items, tools, bikes and activities. The front and backyards were observed to be well maintained and free of debris and hazards. The backyard contained trees, fruit trees, and patio tables and chairs for sitting. During the course of the inspection, LPA reviewed three client files and seven staff files, and observed that: One out of seven staff files reviewed did not contain documentation of a health screening, One out of seven staff files reviewed did not contain documentation of a health screening, One out of seven staff files reviewed did not contain a signed criminal record statement, and One out of seven staff files reviewed did not contain documentation of a current valid CPR and first aid certificate. - See TVs, and There was no documentation of cultural competency training being completed for seven out of seven staff files reviewed. - See TA Only one out of three client files contained a Needs and Services Plan. Three out of three client files did not contain NSPs that were completed/documented annually based on the client's date of placement; One out of three NSP filed in the client files were not signed by the Authorized Representative; and there was no documentation of the licensee's attempts to obtain the NSP signature from the Authorized Representative. - See TVs Interviews were conducted with two staff. Interviews were unable to be conducted with the clients due to their age, being non-verbal and lack of willingness to answer LPA Verna's questions. No citations were issued during today's inspection. An exit interview was conducted with Valerie Lear, Licensee. A copy of this report, were reviewed and provided to Valerie Lear, Licensee.

On March 10, 2022 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducing a required/annual inspection of the facility. LPA met with Valerie Lear, Licensee. LPA continued the required/annual inspection of the facility. LPA Verna completed a physical inspection of the facility and during the course of the inspection, LPA reviewed three client medication (MAR) logs, and medications, and observed that: Client medication was observed to be locked, kept separate per each client, and medication administration documentation (MAR) was in compliance with CCL regulations. The medication in the refrigerator in the garage did not have a lock on it. The inside door of the home to access the garage, however did have a lock. The licensee stated they will install a lock on the garage refrigerator as well. - See TV A complete first aid kit was observed and inventoried. The water temperature of the facility was tested at multiple sources, including two client bathroom sinks, and the kitchen sink, and was observed to measure at 105-120 degrees. One interview was conducted with the licensee. Based on staff interviews, it was determined that the staff and licensee require additional training on Mandated Reporting requirements. - See staff Job Duty TV. LPA Verna completed the annual inspection on today's date. No citations were issued during today's inspection. An exit interview was conducted with Valerie Lear, Licensee. A copy of this report were reviewed and provided to Valerie Lear, Licensee.

The facility is stocked with food and surplus supplies needed to care for clients. Smoke/Carbon detectors and fire extinguishers are in working order however there is no functioning smoke detector/carbon monoxide detector on the second floor. LPA reviewed five client files and five staff files. LPA interviewed the two staff that were on shift and one non-verbal client with the assistance of staff. One Title 22 deficiency is being cited at today's inspection for CCR 83078(e) Buildings and Grounds: Every small family home shall have one or more functioning carbon monoxide detectors on every occupiable level of the home, including basements, and near all sleeping areas as required by the California Fire Code, that meets the standards established in Health and Safety Code Chapter 8 (commencing with Section 13260) of Part 2 of Division 12. The detector shall be audible in each bedroom. An exit interview was conducted and appeal rights were discussed with Matt Lear, C0-Administrator. A copy of this report was emailed due to LPA's printer not working.

On April 25, 2023 at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes began a pre-licensing inspection for Legacy Small Family Home license. LPA met with applicant Monique Leonard who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Currently there is no client in the home. The applicant is applying to serve 2 clients ages 3 to 17. The home is a two story building with three bedrooms and one and one half bathrooms which are set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 (Master) has one bed sleeps the licensee · Bedroom #2 (Client’s) was vacant has two twin beds, it will sleep two clients. · Bedroom #3 (sons) has one full bed, it sleeps the son. · A great room/living room, kitchen, dining area, one and one half bathrooms, an attached one car garage, storage closet, and the backyard. The Client’s bedroom was arranged so that no more than two clients will be in the room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the client’s belongings. There was a smoke detector/Carbon Monoxide detector in every bedroom. The four smoke detectors/carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. There is a dedicated phone line however there is no home phone. The home’s central air conditioning module was located on the back porch. The home’s tankless hot water heater was located inside the garage and the temperature is set to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. The appliances were in working order. Continued on next page.

The client’s files will be locked inside a cabinet in the master bedroom. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable foods. A proper storage of all food was discussed. A trash can for storage of solid waste had a tight-fitting lid and was present. The sharp knives are in a locked kitchen drawer. The medications are located in a locked cabinet in the master bedroom. The hot water in the bathroom 1 measured to be 110.1 degrees Fahrenheit. The water temperature of bathroom 2 measured to be 112.1 degrees Fahrenheit. The home’s First Aid kit was accessible and is located in a cabinet by the refrigerator and had all required supplies. One fire extinguishers was present in the home and is located in the pantry. They were observed to be properly charged and inspected by the fire department. There is one firearm in the home it is stored in a locked box above the stove and the ammunition is in a locked box in a locked cabinet by the pantry. There is no pool or other body of water at the home. The backyard where clients will have access to play is not fenced as fencing is not allowed however there is an alarm on the back door. The following items need to be completed: A home phone The request for a license will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. An exit interview was conducted. On May 25, 2023, at 8:59am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison arrived at Lenmoore Love Small Family Home for the purpose of conducting a Pre-Licensing Inspection Visit. LPA met with Melinda Moore, Licensee who granted access into the home and together a tour was conducted. The home will provide care and supervision to four (4) developmentally disabled children, male and female, ages 0-17 years, ambulatory only. The census on this day is zero (0). The home is single-story located in a residential neighborhood and is set up as follows: Three (3) bedrooms, one (1) bathroom, a living room, a dining room, kitchen, laundry room, detached two (2) car garage, and a backyard. Living Room: Equipped with a sofa, table, playpen, and television. All furniture is in good repair. Kitchen: Equipped with a four (4) -burner gas stove and a refrigerator/freezer. Laundry Room: Located off the kitchen. Equipped with an operable washing machine and dryer, first aid kit and fire extinguisher. Dining/Staff Office Area: Equipped with a table and six (6) chairs, desk, computer, locked cabinet for staff/client files, toys and games. There is also a baby changing table and highchair located in the dining area. All furniture is in good repair. Hallway: Equipped with a locked cabinet and four (4) drawers for extra linens, towels, and extra personal hygiene products for clients. There is a second closet and cabinet for licensee personal clothing items. Bedroom #1: Occupied by Licensee. Equipped with a king-sized bed, television, and a bassinet. Bedroom #2: Vacant. Equipped with two (2) twin sized beds, television, and a desk. There is adequate storage and closet space.

Bedroom #3: Vacant. Equipped with two (2) twin sized beds and a desk. There is adequate storage and closet space. Bathroom #1: Equipped with a bathtub, separate shower, a toilet, and a sink. Clean and in operable condition. Backyard: Has no debris or hazardous materials. Detached two-car garage used for storage. The living room and dining room furniture are in good repair. The home was observed to have a two-week supply of perishable and non-perishable food items. All bedrooms were observed to have adequate lighting, mattresses in good repair and clean linens and bedding. All sharp knives and medication are kept locked in Bedroom #1 and made inaccessible to children in care. All disinfectants/cleaning solutions will be kept in a locked cabinet in the kitchen and made inaccessible to the children. The hot water was tested, and the temperature was found to be within a safe range. All prescribed medications will be stored in a locked cabinet in the licensee bedroom and made inaccessible to children. The first aid kit was checked and found to be missing a thermometer. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors tested audible and were in appropriate working order. The home has one (1) regulation fire extinguishers fully charged. LPA observed the home to have adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. The front and backyards were inspected and found to be clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Foster youth bill of rights and grievance procedures were posted. Caregiver(s)/adults working/residing in the home must have DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Checks. Emergency Mass Disaster Plan was posted. LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. The home will operate within the capacity and limitations of the license. The following must be corrected: · Trash can with lid · Missing thermometer (First Aid Kit) · Missing Crib

Lock for kitchen cabinet for disinfectants/cleaning solutions. · Activity Schedule · Weekly Menu · Garage must be made accessible for licensing inspection · Removal of candles from dining room table Licensee provided LPA with LIC 9182 and a photocopy of driver license for licensee and staff for processing by the Regional Office. LPA advised Licensee that binders must be set up for staff/client files. LPA will conduct a follow-up visit to the home to be scheduled with licensee. Exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Licensee.

During investigation, confidential interview denied that foster children in care engaged in inappropriate interactions due to lack of supervision. A confidential interview stated that all children were adequately supervised in the home while in care. Another confidential interview maintained that FC2 touched FC1 on one occasion, but the interview did not specify where on the body FC1 was touched. Additionally, confidential interview disclosed that the room door was opened when the incident occurred, and LS was in her room. Based on the confidential interviews, the allegation that foster children in care engaged in inappropriate interactions due to lack of supervision, may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report and LIC 811 was provided to licensee.
investigation_findings: 13On March 18, 2024, at 3:13 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie met Liddo Cow Small Family Home Licensee Shavonna Duffin to deliver the investigative finding for the above stated allegation involving the Small Family Home and foster children. On October 31, 2024 on 1:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Abdoulaye Traore arrived at Lifting Hearts Small Family Home to conduct pre-licensing inspection for an initial license. LPA and LPM met with applicant Ekua Baiden who led a tour of the entire home. The applicant is applying for a capacity of two children ages 0 to 17. The home is a two- story building with three bedrooms and two and a half bathrooms. The downstairs consists of two furnished living rooms, a dining room with a table, kitchen , garage and laundry room that shared space with a half bathroom. The bathroom had a missing cabinet door. The second floor consists of a master bedroom for the applicant, a full functioning bathroom, a bedroom furnished with two twin size bed to be utilized for applicants two children and another bedroom furnished with one twin size bed and one full size bed to be utilized for two foster children that are currently vacant. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. LPM and LPA observed that dressers were missing in the client bedroom. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and are working properly. Inside the facility the fireplace is properly screened. There was no landline telephone service. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medication will be locked in cabinets in the upstairs by the bedrooms, however, these cabinets are not locked at this time. Cleansers/chemicals will also be locked and stored in the master bedroom. The master bedroom door will be locked at all times when there are children present. Sharp knives/objects were observed unlocked and accessible on the kitchen counter. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 122 degrees. Applicant understands that the water temperature must be maintained within the regulation range of 105-120 degrees. There are no guns or weapons as stated by Mrs. Baiden at this time.

Proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste did not have tight fitting lids. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan and visitation policy were posted at time. Personal Rights is posted. The backyard was observed to be clean and free of hazards. There is no pool or other body of water. Based on this inspection of the home, the facility will need the following corrections: · The water temperature needs to measure between 105-120 degrees. · Telephone services to be installed. · Sharp knives and objects to be inaccessible. · Trash cans needs tight- fitting lids/covers. · Downstairs bathroom’s cabinet was missing a door. · Medication cabinets to be locked. · Latch on the outside gate to be placed on the inside of the house, currently, the latch is on the outside the gate. · A bed frame missing on the second bed in the clients’ bedroom. · Dressers were missing in the clients’ bedroom. · Facility needs a non-slip rug to replace their current rug. After corrections are completed, the applicant will notify LPA so that another inspection can be completed. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to applicant Euka Baiden.

On June 7, 2021 at 12:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kourtney Williams began a pre-licensing inspection for a Small Family Home license. LPA met with applicant Kellie Davidson who led a tour of the home. The home was toured both inside and out with the applicant. The applicant is applying for a capacity of three ambulatory children. The two-story home consists of: Downstairs first floor: Bedroom #1- The room was furnished with a queen-sized bed. The room will be used a as guest room. Has an attached bathroom, living room and laundry room with a washer and dryer. Bedroom #2 – The room was furnished with a full- sized bed with attached bathroom. The room sleeps applicants 19- year- old son. Open playroom, mud room, kitchen, pantry room, living room, dining area, a common restroom. Backyard with a sliding door and a small play structure with a swing. Applicants plans on building a pool with a spa in the backyard. Upstairs second floor: Bedroom# 3 - The room was furnished with a full- sized bed with an attached bathroom. It sleeps applicants 17- year- old son. Bedroom #4- Master bedroom. It sleeps applicant. The room consists of a California king – sized bed with attached bathroom. Bedroom #5 – The room was furnished with a crib and a twin -sized bed. It will sleep two children. Bedroom #6 – The room was furnished with a crib and a twin- sized bed. It sleeps applicants 2- year -old daughter. It will sleep one more child. Another laundry room with washer and dryer located upstairs. Bedroom#7 - The room was furnished with twin - sized bed is vacant.

Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors were checked and working properly. The garage stores baby strollers and wheelchairs. There is no fireplace. The home has a house telephone. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medications are upstairs in an small locked room near loft. The first aid kit is located in the pantry door. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored under the kitchen sink. Sharp knives were inaccessible locked and stored underneath the kitchen sink. There were no guns or weapons as stated by Applicant at this time. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 107.1 degrees Fahrenheit. Proper storage of all food was discussed. The kitchen trash- can has a tight-fitting lid. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, visitation policy and Personal Rights were posted. Based on this inspection, the home is appropriate for a capacity of three ambulatory clients, however, the licensee needs to add five bathroom trash -can with a lids. Applicant will obtain a lock box for refrigerated medications. After the corrections are completed, the applicant will notify LPA Williams. The applicant has been scheduled for a Component III on Wednesday June 9, 2021. The request of License will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval once the component orientation is completed and the correction has been made.
