On February 11, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Janeth Chavez, conducted an unannounced inspection at the small family home (SFH) above for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection. LPA met with the licensee of the home, Ms. Darlene Livingston. During the inspection there were no other staff or foster children present at the home. There is only 1 foster placement in the home. The licensee does not have any other staff employed. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: small family home grounds are free of observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space, including an outdoor yard. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors are in working order. Knives and sharps are locked in a kitchen drawer. LPA observed the Children’s Personal Rights, Emergency Contacts, Emergency Plan (evacuation) and foster Ombudsman poster posted on the wall in the facility. The medications and client’s files are locked inside a file cabinet located in the living room area. Emergency Intervention Plan: LPA Chavez reviewed the Emergency Intervention Plan. Upon a physical inspection of the facility, the hot water in the kitchen was measured to be 110 degrees. Chemicals and cleaning products are locked in the garage area. Ms. Livingston confirmed there are no weapons and/or ammunition in the home.

There are three bedrooms: Room 1 is used by the client and has two twin beds, Room 2 has two twin beds and is vacant, Room 3 is licensee’s bedroom with own bathroom. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good condition. Each bedroom has enough drawer and closet space for each person. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two persons share a room and there is one person per bed. There are two full bathrooms in the home, and each appeared to be in working order. Client Records: LPA Chavez reviewed one (1) client file. The files contain: Admission Agreement, Medical Assessment, Consent Forms, Emergency Information, Appraisal & Needs Service Plan, Immunization Record and Personal Rights. The Safeguards For Cash Resources was not available during inspection. Staff Records: There is no staff other than the licensee. LPA reviewed licensee’s file and it contained the following documentation: Child Abuse Index Checks/Department of Justice (DOJ)/Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) criminal record clearances, criminal record statement. LPA Chavez observed a health screening and tuberculosis. The Licensee’s First Aid Certificate and Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation is valid until 10/2023. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, along with appeal rights, was provided to licensee, Ms. Darlene Livingston.

Allegation: Caregiver over medicates Ref. #2 - The LPA observed a letter from Ref. #2's doctor that indicated that the Caregiver took Ref. #2 to the Emergency Room on May 19, 2023 and Ref. #2 was medically cleared. The letter indicated that Ref. #2 had been on the prescribed medication for years. An interview with the CSW Supervisor indicated that one particular medication was the cause of Ref. #2's issues observed at school and that Ref. #2 was taken off it after a Child and Family Team Meeting with all the parties. There was no evidence provided that the Caregiver over medicated Ref. #2. The LPA observed no issues with the Psychotropic Medication Administrator Record (MAR). Allegation - Caregiver does not ensure that client is properly fed - A review of the Psychological Evaluation conducted February 17, 2022 indicated Ref. #2 suffered with an eating disorder. The interview with the CSW Supervisor indicated that the medication that Ref. #2 takes made Ref. #2 sleepy and Ref. #2 was not eating. The Supervisor stated that this was the medication that was stopped. The LPA toured the SFH and observed a sufficient supply of perishable and non-perishable food. The LPA observed nutritious meals on the menu. Ref. #2 indicated that they get enough food to eat and is able to get any food from the kitchen that they want. Allegation - Caregiver does not ensure client's hygiene is being met. The Caregiver indicated that there was a complaint, because Ref. #2 wears hair long and dresses in a gothic style. There were statements that Ref. #2's clothes were dirty, hair long, obstructive and unwashed. The LPA observed the client to be clean, dressed in a t-shirt and shorts. Ref. #2 indicated that they shower and wash their hair daily. The LPA observed the SFH to be cluttered with furniture, but observed it to be sanitary without hazards. Allegation - Caregiver does not ensure client is meeting academic needs. The LPA observed a Graduation Status Notification indicating that Ref. #2 had not completed all of the credits to graduate, but Ref. #2 has an IEP which outlines Ref. #2's learning disability. The CSW Supervisor indicated that since Ref. #2 no longer takes that one medication that was causing problems, Ref. #2 has improved at school. The LPA is unable to corroborate the allegations. There was no preponderance of the evidence to substantiate the allegations. So, although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited regarding these allegations. A copy of this complaint was provided to the facility representative.

On July 11, 2024, at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Gutierrez made a case management inspection to the facility and met Administrator, Darlene Livingston. The case management was a follow-up regarding the Special Incident Report (SIR) received on 07/01/24. The SIR indicated that on 06/29/24 at around 4:00 PM, 911 was called and police came to the home. Client (C1) broke into administrator's locked bedroom and took the medication that was in the administrator's purse. Per Administrator Livingston, C1 has a history of suicidal ideations. She keeps C1's medication locked inside a security safe box in her bedroom which she showed this LPA. When the incident happened last 06/29/24,they just came home from the recreational park swimming pool. C1 suddenly broke into her bedroom that was locked at the time while she was unpacking their things. C1 took the medication container that was still in her purse on top of her bed and ran straight into the bathroom and jumped into the tub. She followed C1 and tried to get the medication container back but C1 started hitting her arm. She called 911, and the police came to the home and able to retrieve the medication and took C1 to the hospital. As a safety plan, administrator bought another security safe box where she will keep C1's medication when they travel and will put the medication back into the security safety box that was kept in her bedroom. She also put a new lock in her bedroom door. LPA asked the administrator to make an SIR addendum to add more information to the initial SIR dated 06/29/24. An exit interview was conducted and copy of the LIC 809 and LIC 811 was provided to the administrator. No deficiency citation issued at the time of the inspection.

On July 26, 2024, at 11:45 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) John Bonilla conducted an unannounced Case Management inspection at Livingston Small Family Home (SFH) for the purpose of following up on a Special Incident Report (SIR) received by the Department on July 18, 2024. LPA met with licensee Darlene Livingston. The SIR indicated that on 07/17/24 at 5:53 p.m., 911 was called and police came to the home after client (C1) (See LIC811 Confidential names list dated 07/26/24) had broken into a locked cabinet and smashed a ceramic plate on the floor and started cutting on both arms during a wrap around session. During this inspection, LPA reviewed C1's Needs and Services Plan (NSP), which was still being completed by licensee as C1 was recently placed at the home. Licensee stated she plans to complete the NSP over the weekend, but that is dependent on C1's behaviors. As a result of incident, C1 was taken on a psychiatric hold. Upon discharge, a safety plan was created by the psych team recommending outpatient services. Licensee stated that wraparound services have increased to daily. LPA has spoken with County Social Worker (CSW) and CSW is aware of the situation at the SFH. No deficiencies were cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted and copy of the LIC 809 and LIC 811 was provided to the licensee. No further action required.

investigation_findings: 13On March 28th, 2025, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Maryjane Perez and Claudia Aguilara made an unannounced visit to Lucia Small Family Home (SFH) to deliver the finding for the above stated allegation. On November 1st, 2024 Community Care Licensing received complaint allegation that licensee does not ensure a minor is meeting their hygiene needs. On November 6,2024 LPA conducted a health and safety inspection of the facility, and no hazards were observed. LPA M. Perez also obtained pertinent documents and interviewed licensee (LS), client 1 (C1), client 2 (C2), and client 3 (C3). During the investigation, confidential interviews stated that licensee will provide clients with the proper materials to use for hygiene purposes. Other confidential interviews stated that the clients in the home are not bathing when they are supposed to. Another confidential interview stated they don’t know if they take showers or not. LPA was unable to gather additional information due to clients refusing to continue with interview.

narrative:
On March 3, 2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez conducted a pre-licensing visit for a change of location at Lucia Small Family Home. LPA met with Licensee Lucia Wamutitu who led a tour of the entire home. The licensee is applying for a capacity of 4 children ages 0 to 17. The home is a one story building with 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. The entry way consisted of emergency escape plan. There was bedroom #1 that had two twin size beds with appropriate bedding dresser and closet space that will be utilized for clients. Bathroom #1 was fully functioning with water temperature reaching 110.8 degrees Fahrenheit. Bedroom #2 had two twin size beds fully furnished with dresser and closet space and will be utilized for clients. There was a storage closet storing toilet paper, towels and linen. Bedroom #3 also had two twin size beds with closet and dresser space. There was a laundry room that will be locked at all times as it stored laundry detergents and essentials. The hallway holds fire extinguisher #1 that is up to date and another storage closet with household items. There was a kitchen that was clean and sanitary, the refrigerator and pantry was fully stocked. There were locked cabinets for medications and knives. The kitchen also had fire extinguisher #2 that was up to date. There was a dining table, a living room fully furnished with couch and TV. The master bedroom for licensee held a crib for an infant with all required bedding essentials and bathroom #2 that was fully functioning. The hallway leading to master bedroom had a bulletin board with all required postings such as: personal rights, menu, and emergency evacuation plan. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawers and closets for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. Appliances were in working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients/children will have access. There was a stationed land line service to be used by both licensee and clients

There was adequate food storage space and a supply of three days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable food. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. First Aid kit was accessible with all required items located in a kitchen cabinet. All the appropriate forms were posted in view of facility clients. As stated by licensee, there were no weapons/firearms and there were no pools or other bodies of water. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. There are no deficiencies observed at this time. The request for licensure will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final review and approval. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to licensee Lucia Wamutitu.

On December 21, 2023, at 1:30 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie began a Pre-Licensing inspection for a Small Family Home license. LPA met with applicant Tanja Lugo, led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. The applicant was applying to be licensed for 6 ambulatory clients. The home consisted of: Downstairs: Bedroom #1, It was furnished with a queen bed. It sleeps one foster daughter, aged 24 years. There was also a family room, a living room, dining area and one bathroom. Upstairs: Bedroom #2, The room consisted of two twin beds. It sleeps one adopted daughter, aged 20 years. Bedroom #3, The room was furnished with a queen bed. It was vacant. Bedroom #4, The room was furnished with two twin beds. It sleeps two foster children. Bedroom #5. The room was furnished with two twin beds. It sleeps two foster children. Bedroom #6, The room was furnished with a twin bed. It sleeps one foster child. Bedroom #7, Master bedroom. The room consisted of one king-sized bed. It sleeps the applicant and spouse.

Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes was used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors were checked and were working properly. Inside the facility the fireplace was properly screened. Telephone service and appliances were in a working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medication will be locked in the kitchen cabinet area. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the laundry room cabinet. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in a locked box in the kitchen cabinet. There were no guns or weapons as stated by the applicant at this time. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 112 degrees. Proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. First Aid kit was accessible with all required items and it was in the kitchen pantry. A Fire extinguisher was observed and properly charged. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, visitation policy and Personal Rights were posted. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. The request to be licensed for a small family home will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. A component III orientation was conducted with applicant Tanja Lugo. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to Applicant/Licensee

Continued from 9099 A confidential interview disclosed that the Licensee traveled out of the country from October 21, 2024, to November 4, 2024. LPA reviewed the CCL facility file, and no report was found indicating that the LIC was going on vacation, or no documentation was found that the LIC informed foster children Social Workers or CCL. Based on confidential interviews and a review of pertinent documents, the allegation that the Licensee did not notify authorized representatives of her absence is substantiated. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met. The SFH is cited for a violation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 4, Article 06, California Code Regulations, Section 83061(a)(b) In addition to 80061, the following shall apply: The licensee shall notify the licensing agency and the child’s authorized representative in advance when they intend to be absent from the home for 48 hours or longer… The facility did not follow reporting requirements when LIC went on vacation, which posed potential health, safety, and personal rights risk to the children in care. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were explained and given to La Queta Mormon.
investigation_findings: 13On December 18, 2024, at 1:43 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karen Beal met with Licensee LaQueta Mormon to deliver the investigation findings for the above-stated allegation. On October 24, 2024, at 9:47 AM, LPA initiated the investigation at Lugo’s Small Family Home (SFH) and obtained pertinent documents from the facility files. LPA interviewed the Licensee (LIC). On October 23, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that the Licensee (LIC) did not notify authorized representatives of their (LIC)absence.Specifically, it was alleged that the LIC went on vacation for more than 48 hours without giving CCL notice.A confidential interview stated the foster children’s Social Workers were notified of the Licensee’s absence. A confidential interview stated that they (LIC) could not recall being told that CCL was informed about the Licensee being absent for more than 48 hours. Continued to LIC 9099-C

deficiencies.description: 83061(a)(b) Reporting Requirements. (a)In addition to 80061, the following shall apply: (b)The licensee shall notify the licensing agency and the child’s authorized representative in advance when they intend to be absent from the home for 48 hours or longer… This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews, the Licensee went on vacation from October 21, 2024, to November 4, 2024, without notifying Community Care Licensing that they (LIC) were going on vacation. The facility did not follow reporting requirements when LIC went on vacation, which posed a potential health, safety, and personal rights risk to the children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: S1 stated  the facility will ensure that licensing is notified of any absence more than 48 hours. The notification willl include date of the intended vacation, status of the children, contact number, and the person who will take care of the children if they are not going on vacation.

narrative: It was further reported that the church members performed an exorcism on FC1, where FC1 was levitating and the members had to hold FC1 down. It was further reported the exorcism took four hours and FC1 blacked out and couldn’t remember what happened. It was reported that it was unknown if S1 or S2 was present during the exorcism. Confidential interviews reported church members performed an exorcism on FC1. Other confidential interviews reported that FC1, FC2, S1 and S2 regularly attend their usual church and that this church does not perform exorcisms on any church members. Other confidential interviews reported that the foster children in the small family home voluntarily attend their church and reported feeling safe there. Confidential interviews reported that the foster children in the small family home have not reported any exorcisms were performed on them and they didn’t witness exorcisms performed on other members. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that foster parent allowed church staff to restrain foster child to perform a church ritual without consent may have occurred or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report (LIC 9099) and appeal rights were explained and given to Licensee Tanja Lugo.
investigation_findings: 13On 04/17/2025, at 11:15 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Joon Choi and Claudia Aguilera conducted an unannounced visit to Lugos’ Family Care Small Family Home (SFH) and met with Licensee Tanja Lugo to deliver the investigative finding for the allegation listed above. On 03/18/2025, Community Care Licensing received an allegation that foster parent allowed church staff to restrain foster child to perform a church ritual without consent. On 03/21/2025, LPA Joon Choi conducted a health and safety inspection at the SFH, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. During the investigation, LPA Choi obtained documents pertinent to the investigation and interviewed foster children 1 and 2 (FC1, FC2) and staff 1 and 2 (S1, S2). In regard to the allegation that foster parent (S1) allowed church staff to restrain foster child (FC1) to perform a church ritual without consent; it was reported that FC1 went to a church service where members told FC1 that they “had a demon that took over their body.” CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE...

narrative: Confidential interviews reported that LIC admitted to giving C1, three pills a day instead of the prescribed two pills a day. Other confidential interviews reported that LIC reported that C1’s doctor verbally instructed LIC to give C1 3 pills a day. A review of records and C1’s medication bottles showed that the written instructions for C1’s prescription noted that two pills should be given each day. Based on confidential interviews and a review of pertinent documentation, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and the allegation that licensee is not administering medications to the foster child as prescribed is substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of the Title 22 Regulations, Division 6 Chapter 4, Article 06, section 83075 of Health Related Services, (g) psychotropic medication shall only be used in accordance with the written directions of the physician prescribing the medication and in accordance with authorization requirements specified in Sections 369.5(a)(1) and 739.5(a)(1) of the Welfare and Institutions Code and Section 83070(b)(11). An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report (LIC 9099), deficiencies page (LIC 9099D) and appeal rights were explained and given to Licensee's Caregiver Staff Laquita Momon.
investigation_findings: 13On 07/17/2025, at 09:59 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi conducted an unannounced visit to Lugos’ Family Care Small Family Home (SFH) and met with Licensee's Caregiver Staff Laquita Momon to deliver the investigative findings for the allegation listed above. On 04/09/2025, Community Care Licensing received an allegation that foster parent is not administering medications to the foster child as prescribed. On 04/17/2025, LPA Joon Choi conducted a health and safety inspection at the SFH, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. During the investigation, LPA Choi obtained documents pertinent to the investigation and interviewed FC1 (FC1) and the Licensee (LIC). In regard to the allegation that foster parent (LIC) is not administering medications to the foster child (FC1) as prescribed; it was reported that LIC called C1’s pharmacy to get a refill for C1’s psychotropic medication. It was further reported that there were concerns because C1’s prescription was supposed to last 30 days. However, LIC ran out of the prescribed medication and called before the 30 days. CONTINUED ON THE NEXT PAGE

deficiencies.description:
83075 of Health Related Services, (g) psychotropic medication shall only be used in accordance with the written directions of the physician prescribing the medication and in accordance with authorization requirements specified in Sections 369.5(a)(1) and 739.5(a)(1) of the Welfare and Institutions Code and Section 83070(b)(11). 

This requirement is not met as evidence by: Based on confidential interviews and record review, the licensee gave the wrong dosage to C1 which poses an immediate health and safety or personal right risks to clients in care.

narrative:
On August 28th, 2025 at 12:22PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Ramos met with Licensee Tanja Lugo who led a tour of the home. The purpose of the visit was to conduct an annual inspection of the home. The facility was toured inside and out with the Licensee. Currently there are no clients in placement. The home is a two-story home, with 7 bedrooms and 3 bathrooms. The home is set up as follows: On the first floor there was a large dining table, small living room and kitchen. In the kitchen, LPA observed knives, and medication was kept locked in a top cabinet. Additionally, there is a large family room with a television and games for clients. Bedroom #1 is located downstairs and is currently occupied by Licensee’s adult daughter (25 years old) and always remains locked. Bathroom #1 was inspected and was in good repair. An additional closet was observed to have extra household items. A stairway led to the second floor of the home where Bedroom #2 (Master Bedroom) was located, this room is currently occupied by Licensee and Spouse and remains locked at all times. Master bedroom also contained Bathroom #2. Bedroom #3 was currently vacant for a future client and contained a twin bed, drawers and closet space. Bedroom #4 was currently vacant for future clients and contained two twin beds with adequate drawers and closet space. Bathroom #3 was inspected and in good repair. Bedroom #5 was occupied by Licensee’s biological daughter (22-year-old) and remains locked at all times. Bedroom #6 was vacant with two twin beds and adequate drawers and closet space for future clients. Per Licensee, Bedroom #7 always remains locked as it is used for storage. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE

The fireplace was properly screened. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to clients. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the laundry room and are not accessible to clients. The first aid kit was located in the kitchen and was complete. Per Licensee, there are no guns or weapons in the home at this time. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 111.3 degrees F. Proper storage of all food was noted. Carbon monoxide/smoke detectors alarms were tested and were in good repair. During inspection, LPA observed trash cans for storage of solid waste without tight fitting lids, due to this a Technical Violation (TV) 80088 (f)(1) was given and explained to the Licensee. LPA observed the landline (phone) was broken during the visit. A Technical Violation 80073(a) was given and explained to the Licensee. The garage was inspected and contained additional storage, per Licensee clients do not have access to the garage and remains locked at all times. The backyard where clients will have access to play is completely fenced and free of hazards. There is no pool or other body of water. Staff records were reviewed and were in compliance. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Licensee.

On February 8, 2024 at 09:16 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes began a pre-licensing inspection for Luminous Souls Care Small Family Home. LPA met with applicant Ashley Gauthier who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the Applicant. Currently there are no children in placement The home is a one story building with three bedrooms and two bathrooms which are set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 (Master) has one bed, it sleeps the applicant. · Bedroom #2 (Client’s) has two twin beds, it will sleep two clients. · Bedroom #3 (daughter) has one twin bed, it sleeps the daughter. · A great room/living room, kitchen, dining area, two bathrooms, an office, an attached two car garage, storage closet, and the backyard. The Client’s bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two client’s will be in a room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the client’s belongings. There was a smoke detector/Carbon Monoxide detector in every bedroom. The four smoke detectors/carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. There is a fire sprinkler system in the home. The home’s central air conditioning module was located on the side of the home. The home’s tankless hot water heater was located inside the garage and the temperature is set to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. The appliances were in working order. The client’s files will be locked inside a cabinet in the office. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable foods. A trash can for storage of solid waste had a tight-fitting lid and was present.

The sharp knives are in a locked cabinet across from the applicants bedroom. The medications will be located in a locked box in the office. The hot water in the Master Bathroom measured to be 105.4 degrees Fahrenheit. The water temperature of bathroom 2 measured to be 107.7 degrees Fahrenheit. The First Aid kit was not present at time of inspection. one fire extinguisher was present in the home it is located in the kitchen. It was observed to be properly charged and inspected by the fire department. Applicant stated there were no weapons/firearms in the home. There is no pool or other body of water at the home. The backyard where clients will have access to play was completely fenced. The following corrections need to be made: 1. First aid kit to contain the following Supplies a. Current edition of the first aid manual b. Sterile first aid dressings c. Bandages d. Adhesive Tape e. Scissors f. Tweezers g. Thermometer h. Antiseptic Solution A component III was completed at this time. This application will be forwarded to the Licensing Program Manager for licensing. A copy of this report and Appeal Rights was given to Applicant.

facility_name: L.B. LIMITLESS FOUNDATION SMALL FAMILY HOME
narrative:
On November 26, 2024, License Program Analyst (LPA) Justine Armstrong and LPA Charmetha White conducted an announced visit to conduct a Pre-Licensing Inspection at L.B. Limitless Small Family Home located at 3822 Sutro Ave, Los Angeles CA 90008. During the visit, LPA met with the facility's Administrator Lela Bohannon. Currently, there are no children in the home. This small family home will be licensed for ambulatory minors between the ages of 6-16. Upon entering the facility, LPA Armstrong provided the Administrator with an Entrance Checklist. The facility's exterior was clean and free of debris, with no safety hazards observed. It consists of two bedrooms, two bathrooms, one kitchen, a laundry room, one dining room, one living room, and a garage. There are no bodies of water on the premises.Upon entering the home, there is a locked closet for staff and client files, as well as an emergency backpack for disaster preparedness. **Living Room**: The living room features a wall-mounted TV, two single sofas, and one large sofa, all arranged in an open floor plan. A fire extinguisher is on the wall and there is a fireplace with a metal cage surrounding it to make it inaccessible to clients; however, this fireplace is non-operable. The living room is equipped with a floor heater and an AC vent in the ceiling. **Kitchen**: The kitchen is large, clean, safe, and sanitary. It includes a working faucet, two refrigerators, four operational stove burners, a microwave, and a counter toaster. Inside one of the refrigerators, there is a locked box for medication storage. A weekly menu is posted for staff and clients, and there is a lidded trash can available. Sufficient perishable and non-perishable food supplies for one week are present. Additionally, the kitchen displays the Disaster Plan, Foster Rights poster, and Facility Sketch. A first-aid kit is located in the kitchen, containing tweezers, scissors, a thermometer, sterile first-aid dressings, and band-aids. The kitchen has a side door that leads to the laundry room, and it includes a lock on a cabinet for chemical storage and a lock on a top cabinet for the medication lock box. **Laundry Room**: The laundry room has an exit door leading to the backyard, a washer, a dryer, and a locked cabinet for extra laundry supplies. **Dining Room**: The dining room contains a sturdy table with four chairs, which accommodates the facility's capacity. The dining room also has a side door that leads to the backyard (2nd exit ) see continuation on 809C

**Hallway**: The hallway features two closets. The first closet stores extra linens, towels, blankets, pillows, sheets, and hygiene supplies. The second closet is locked and used for storing cleaning chemicals. **Bedrooms**: There are two bedrooms. The first bedroom, which is currently unoccupied, is designated for clients and is equipped with two twin-sized beds, a closet with clean linens, a warm blanket, and pillows on each bed. It includes two dressers with five drawers each and a nightstand. The spacious shared closet has a laundry basket for each client. Bedroom #2 is the admin bedroom, which also has two twin beds, a spacious bathroom equipped with a shower, a toilet, and a bathtub with a spacious closet. This bedroom door has a lock. The licensee was advised to replace the two twin beds with a single bed and to send a picture once completed. **Bathrooms**: The clients' bathrooms are equipped with a shower, a separate bathtub, a working toilet, a sink with a mirror, and a faucet. The hot water was tested and found to be between 105-120 degrees Fahrenheit. **Garage**: The garage is used for storage and supplies and is located in the backyard. **Backyard**: The spacious backyard is free of debris and features a large play area for clients, along with beautiful lemon and orange trees. A working dual carbon monoxide alarm/smoke detector is installed in the living room, dining room, hallway, kitchen, and bedrooms. At the time of observation, no cameras were present, and the applicant confirmed that no firearms were in the home. The facility has central air and heating, and the area is free of debris and other hazardous items. There is also a gas, water, and power shut-off located at the side of the home. The LPA inspected the facility's vehicle, a 2007 gold Toyota, which is registered until October 2025 and covered by State Farm Insurance which will be renewed January 2025. An Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was provided to the Administrator.

facility_name: L.B. LIMITLESS FOUNDATION SMALL FAMILY HOME
narrative:
On April 1, 2025, at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Justine Armstrong and Dennis Jarmin conducted an announced post-licensing inspection at L.B. Limitless Small Family Home, located at 3822 Sutro Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90008. LPAs met with Administrator Lela Bohannon. At the time of the visit, there were no children in placement. The facility is licensed to provide care for ambulatory minors between the ages of 6 and 16. Upon entry,As there were no children in placement, no client interviews were conducted and no client files were available for review. The only interview conducted was with the licensee. Facility Overview: The home was clean, organized, and free from safety hazards. It includes two bedrooms, two bathrooms, a living room, a dining room, a kitchen, a laundry room, and a detached garage. There are no bodies of water on the property. A locked closet near the entrance stores staff and client files. Living Room: The living room has a wall-mounted TV, two single sofas, and one large sofa. A fire extinguisher is mounted on the wall. The non-operable fireplace is enclosed with a metal safety cover. LPA Advised the Licensee to attach the metal safety cover to the wall, so that it can not be moved and be more inaccessible to children and to send LPA a picture once completed. The room includes a floor heater and ceiling air conditioning vent.

Kitchen: The kitchen is clean and well-maintained. It includes two refrigerators, a stove with four working burners, a microwave, and a toaster. One refrigerator has a locked box for medication. A weekly menu is posted, and there are enough perishable and non-perishable foods for at least one week. Cleaning supplies are stored in a locked cabinet, and a medication box is secured in a top cabinet. A first aid kit containing all required items was observed. Required postings, including the Disaster Plan, Foster Youth Rights, and Facility Sketch, Facility License and emergency resource numbers are visibly posted. A side door leads to the laundry room. Laundry Room: The laundry area has a washer, dryer, and locked cabinet for laundry supplies. An exit door leads to the backyard. Dining Room: The dining room has a sturdy table and four chairs, which meets the needs of the home's capacity. A second exit door provides access to the backyard. There were also 2 emergency disaster backpack placed on door handles in the dining room. Hallway: Two hallway closets were observed. One stores extra linens, towels, blankets, and hygiene items. The second is locked and used for storing cleaning chemicals. Bedrooms: There are two bedrooms. Bedroom #1 is designated for clients and includes two twin beds, clean linens, pillows, warm blankets, and individual laundry baskets. The room also contains dressers and a shared closet. Bedroom #2 is the Licensee room. It includes one king bed and an attached bathroom with a shower, bathtub, toilet, and spacious closet. Bathrooms: Both bathrooms are clean and functional, with a working toilet, sink, shower, and bathtub. Hot water was tested and measured between 105–120°F, which is within the regulatory range.

Garage and Backyard: The detached garage is used for storage and remains locked. The backyard is spacious, clean, and free of hazards. It features a play area and lemon and orange trees. There also two cameras in the backyard. LPA advised to put a lock on the H-back air conditioning unit shut off valve. Health and Safety Compliance: The home is equipped with a dual carbon monoxide/smoke detector in all required areas, and all were tested and operational. There are no surveillance cameras or firearms in the home. The property has central heating and air conditioning. Gas, water, and power shut-off valves are located on the side of the house. Facility Vehicle: LPAs observed a 2007 gold Toyota parked on-site. The vehicle registration is valid through October 2025 and is insured by State Farm. Exit Interview: An exit interview was conducted with Administrator Lela Bohannon. A copy of this report was provided after the inspection.

All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. Cleansers/chemicals and medication lockbox were locked and stored in downstair closet. The request of License will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. On July 24, 2024, at 9 AM, a Component II Office Visit was held to discuss the application received for Maggie Small Family Home located at 1948 Steely Ave. Long beach, CA 90815. Attending Component II were the following individuals: Darlene Simpson, Applicant, Erika Butler. Licensing Program Analyst, and JoAunne Griffin, Licensing Program Manager. The purpose of this Component II meeting was to review and discuss the incomplete application and Program Statement and to resolve any outstanding concerns that may have existed. The following incomplete application forms were discussed at the meeting: 1. Application for a Community Care Facility or Residential Care Facility for the Elderly License (LIC 200). 2. On August 2, 2024, at 1 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Erika Butler, (LPA) Cheri Wilkerson, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) JoAunne’ Griffin arrived at Maggie’s Small Family Home for the purpose of conducting a Pre-Licensing Inspection. LPA's and LPM met with Applicant, Darleene Simpson who granted access to the home and together a tour of the interior and exterior home was conducted. Currently living in the home is the Applicant. The home is set up as follows: This is a 4 bedroom, 2 bathroom home located in a residential area. The home consists of a living room, dining room, kitchen, laundry, patio in backyard, and an attached garage. Living room: is equipped with mounted TV, sofa, ottoman, and covered fireplace. The living room also has sliding glass patio doors leading to the backyard. Dining room: is equipped with glass table with four (4) chairs, with a door that leads to side of home. Kitchen: is equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, a four (4) burner gas stove (all burners were operational at the time of the inspection), microwave, and a dishwasher. Sharp knives are kept locked in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. LPA observed a covered trash can, plenty of cabinet space, ample plates, cups, and eating utensils. LPA observed ample perishable food items in the refrigerator, and non-perishable food items. The applicant will ensure that three (3) nutritious meals and snacks will be provided to the clients. Applicant advised that alcohol beverages located in refrigerator should be stored separately and inaccessible to children in care. Laundry room: is located in the garage. Report continued on LIC 809C Page 1 of 4

Backyard: Observed loose wire. Pathway on side of home was observed to have five paint cans. Gate leading to pathway on side of home is unable to close. Loose boxes were also observed near sliding door. Attached garage: used for the home’s vehicle, and storage. Bedroom #1: Clients bedroom has two (2) bunk beds, one (1) dresser with four(4) drawers each, a TV, a closet, working light, and windows. Dresser drawers need to be repaired. Applicant's personal belongings observed in closet. Bedroom #2: Clients bedroom has a full size bed, one (1) dresser, TV, a closet, working light, and windows. Bedroom #3: Clients bedroom has two bunk beds, two (2) dressers with four (4) drawers each, a TV, a closet, working light, and windows. Applicant's personal belongings were observed in bedroom closet. Applicant was advised that personal belongings need to be removed to accommodate children in care. Bedroom #4: Applicants bedroom has a king size bed, dresser, working light, and windows. The room also has an attached bathroom that contains two (2) sinks, and separate shower, and a walk-in closet. (2) Bathrooms: LPA found all bathrooms to be clean and in working order. The hot water was tested and found to be with 105-120 (F). Vehicle: The applicant will use a 2017 Land Rover Range Rover to transport clients in care. The vehicle is in good condition with current registration through 10/01/2024. The home’s temperature is maintained by central air/heating. LPA observed one (1) fully charged fire extinguisher. Extra linens are stored in the linen closet. The smoke alarm and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. First Aid kit was found to be be complete except for the thermometer. Report continued on LIC 809C. (Page 2 of 4)

Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept in a locked cabinet under the sink in the bathroom, and in the kitchen. The home has a working telephone readily accessible to children in care. Medications will be kept locked in file cabinet located in the dining area. Medications requiring refrigeration will be kept in a locked box stored in the refrigerator. LPA observed the home to be clean, safe, and sanitary. LPA reminded Licensee to ensure the following when children are in placement: Children are accorded personal rights and the corresponding form is in their file. Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Applicant acknowledges abuse reporting requirements. Applicant will ensure grievance process, Disaster Plan, Discipline policies and procedures will be posted in dining room area. During the inspection, LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. Per a check in Guardian conducted on 08//02/2024, the applicant has not started the Criminal Record Clearance process. LPA informed applicant that a Component 3 meeting will be held once applicant obtains eligible clearance. (Page 3 of 4)

Applicant advised to update Program Statement to reflect the use of cameras inside the home and sensors on doors. Applicant advised to complete Personnel Report (LIC 500) to reflect hours worked for Adult and Senior Care program. Applicant advised to add an additional chair to table to accommodate children in care. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of report will be emailed to Applicant, Darleene Simpson. Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with caregiver Darleen Simpson to conduct the post-licensing inspection. The following was observed: This is a four bedroom, two bathroom single family home located in the City of Long Beach, CA. There are currently no clients in placement. Living Room/Dining Room/Kitchen: The stove and refrigerator are in good working condition. There is a locked cabinet for storage of household cleaners and sharp knives. There is a dining table to seat five people. In the living room, the fireplace is securely screened. There is a cabinet for storage of medications. Bathrooms: There are two bathrooms. Fixtures are clean and in good working condition. The hot water temperature is within the safe range. Bedrooms: There are four bedrooms. One bedroom is for the use of the the caregiver. Two of the client bedrooms have bunk beds with rails as required. One of the client bedrooms has one full size bed. Linens are in good condition. There are blinds on the windows. There are no security bars on bedroom windows. There is adequate drawer and closet space. Fire Safety/Yard Safety: There are smoke detectors in each bedroom and in the hallway. There is a carbon monoxide detector in the kitchen. There is also a fire extinguisher in the kitchen. Patio furniture is in good condition. The yard is free of hazards. There are no bodies of water such as pools or jacuzzis.

Misc: There is a complete first aid kit. Notice of personal rights and emergency disaster plan or posted. There are exit plans posted in the bedrooms and the hallway. There is a washer/dryer combo in the attached garage. There were no deficiencies found as a result of this inspection. The capacity will be corrected to a maximum five (5) clients.

On October 6, 2023 at 10:15 AM, a pre-licensing inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie. LPA met with applicant Miesha Hale. The purpose of the visit was to evaluate the home for a possible license for a small family home with capacity of two ambulatory children as requested by applicant. The applicant is requesting to be licensed for a small family home with capacity to serve a total of two ambulatory children ages 0-17. During this inspection, LPA and applicant inspected the facility inside and out. The apartment consists of: Bedroom #1, It was furnished with a King sized bed, it has a bathroom; it sleeps the applicant. Bedroom #2, It was furnished with two twin beds. One bed is currently occupied by one foster-child, age 5 years. There were also a living room, dining area, a closet, a kitchen, cabinets and one bathroom for clients. Bedroom is arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors were checked and were working properly.

Inside the facility, there is no fireplace. Telephone service and appliances were in a working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medication will be locked in a locked box in applicant’s bedroom. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in applicant’s bedroom closet. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in applicant’s bedroom closet. There were no guns or weapons as stated by applicant at this time. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 110 degrees. Proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. First Aid kit was accessible with all required items, and it was in the kitchen cabinet. A Fire extinguisher was observed and properly charged. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, visitation policy and Personal Rights were posted. The patio where children will have access to play was free of hazards. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. The request to be licensed for a small family home will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. A component III orientation was conducted with applicant Miesha Hale. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to Applicant/Licensee

facility_name: MAKING MIRACLES HAPPEN SMALL FAMILY HOME
narrative: Continued from LIC 9099 Regarding licensee threaten to hit FC1 with the shoe, a confidential interview stated denied that FC1 was threatened to be hit with a shoe. The confidential interview indicated that FC1 threw FC’s shoe into the fan and the shoe landed on the licensee who told FC1 that such action was dangerous while holding the shoe. Additionally, the confidential interview stated that FC1 was acting out and throwing things around the house and jumping on the furniture. A confidential interview disclosed that licensee was mean to FC1, and foster mother attempted to hit FC1 with a shoe. In regard to licensee not allowing the foster child to leave the home, a confidential interview stated that FC1 attempted the leave the home by attempting to exit out the garage door. The confidential interview stated the door was blocked to prevent FC1 from exiting the home. However, FC1 was able to run to the front door and exit. Confidential interview stated the FC1 was not able to be located and the police was called and FC1 was later found by the police. A confidential interview stated that licensee/foster mother was mean to FC1 which resulted in FC1 running out of the house. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that licensee threaten to throw an object at FC1 and licensee is not allowing FC1 to leave the home may have occurred or may be valid, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegation. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. Copy of this report, Confidential Names (LIC 811) and appeal rights were discussed and provided to Licensee Miesha Hale.
investigation_findings: 13On November 8, 2024 at 8:50 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karen Beal arrived at Making Miracles Happen (SFH) met with Licensee Miesha Hale to deliver the investigative finding of the complaint involving the small family home and the foster child listed on the Confidential Names (LIC 811). On July 29, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that licensee threaten to throw an object at a foster child and licensee is not allowing foster child to leave the home. It was specified that the Licensee threaten to hit foster child (FC1) with a shoe and the licensee blocked the door to prevent FC1 from leaving the home. On August 7, 2024, at 9:38 AM, LPA K. Beal initiated the investigation at the small family home and gathered pertinent documents from FC1 file. In addition, LPA conducted a health and safety inspection, interviewed licensee and FC1. LPA was unable to contact the County Social Worker (CSW). Continued on LIC 9099-C

narrative:
On September 30, 2021 at 8:28pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Daniel Mena conducted an annual inspection at the facility. The home was toured inside and out with licensees, Angie & Sheny Sanabria. The home is a one story residence with 5 bedrooms and 3 bathroom, home with an attached "casita" which included one bathroom. The home is set up as follows: Bedroom #1- Was furnished with a twin-size bed. Sleeps C1. Bedroom #2- Was furnished with a full-size bed. Sleeps C2 Bedroom #3- Was furnished with a full-seize bed Sleeps C3. Bedroom #4- Resource Parents bedroom. Bedroom #5- Currently used to store clothing. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors were checked and were working properly. There was also a plenty of space for children to play. The fireplace was located in the family room area and it was properly screened. Telephone service and appliances were in a working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the laundry rooms. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen area. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 110 degrees. Proper storage of all food was discussed.

Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. First Aid kit was accessible and contained all required items. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, visitation policy and Personal Rights were posted. Licensee's stated that there are no weapons in the home. There were no pool or other bodies of water. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. Facility is licensed to serve ambulatory developmentally disabled children ages 2- 17 years old. The Licensee's meet the requirements for the 8 hours of annual foster care training. Licensee’s First Aid and CPR cards expire on July 02, 2022. A review of staff records on this date indicates that all adults residing in the home or providing care and supervision to children have received fingerprint and child abuse index check clearances. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided this date.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Abdoulaye Traore conducted a pre-arranged pre-licensing tele-inspection as a result of COVID 19 related restrictions. This tele-inspection was conducted via facetime with applicants Amisi and Julie Morisho. The Facility was toured both inside and out the applicant. The home is a two-story home and consists of: Downstairs: a living room, a family room, a kitchen, a dining area and two bedrooms. Bedroom # 1, the room was furnished with a queen size bed. It was vacant. It will sleep a caregiver Bedroom #2, the room was furnished with two cribs/toddler beds and it will sleep two foster children age 0-2, Upstairs: Bedroom #3, master bedroom. The room was furnished with of a king bed. It sleeps the applicants. Bedroom #4, the room was furnished with a king size bed. It was vacant Bedroom #5, the room was furnished with a bunk bed. It sleeps Amisi’s 8-year-old son Bedroom #6, The room was furnished with a queen bed. It was vacant. There was another room used as exercise which contained sporting equipment’s such as treadmill’s and a stationary bike. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors were checked and were working properly. Outside the upstairs bedrooms were a loft designated office area which contained cabinets to store children records. There was also a plenty of space for children to play.

The fireplace was located in the family room area and it was properly screened. Telephone service and appliances were in a working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the laundry rooms. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen area. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 106 degrees. Proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. First Aid kit was accessible and contained all required items. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, visitation policy and Personal Rights were posted. As stated by applicant, there were no weapons/firearms and there were no pool or other body of water. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. Component III orientation was provided to the applicants/license which include incident reporting procedures, clients and staff records requirements, and client personal rights. Facility will accept only two ambulatory developmentally disabled children and licensed for a capacity of 2 foster children age 0-17. Facility prefers to serve children that are medically fragile and with special health care needs 0-2. Based on this inspection, the home is appropriate for a capacity of two ambulatory clients. All requirements are met at this time. On this date, Facility is recommended for licensure. The request of License will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report to be emailed to the applicant this date.

On September 14, 2021 at 1:19 pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera conducted an annual inspection at the facility. The home was toured inside with licensee's Julie and Morisho Amisi. The home is a two story residence with six bedrooms and 3 bathrooms. The home is a two-story home and consists of: Downstairs: a living room, a family room, a kitchen, a dining area and two bedrooms. Bedroom # 1, the room was furnished with a queen size bed. It was vacant. It will sleep a caregiver Bedroom #2, the room was furnished with two cribs/toddler beds and it will sleep two foster children age 0-2, Upstairs: Bedroom #3, master bedroom. The room was furnished with of a king bed. It sleeps the licensee's. Bedroom #4, the room was furnished with a king size bed. It was vacant Bedroom #5, the room was furnished with a queen bed It sleeps Amisi’s 10-year-old son Bedroom #6, The room was furnished with a king bed. It was vacant. There was another room used as exercise which contained sporting equipment’s such as treadmill’s and a stationary bike. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors were checked and were working properly. Outside the upstairs bedrooms were a loft designated office area which contained cabinets to store children records. There was also a plenty of space for children to play.

The fireplace was located in the family room area and it was properly screened. Telephone service and appliances were in a working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the laundry rooms. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen area. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 110 degrees. Proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. First Aid kit was accessible and contained all required items. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, visitation policy and Personal Rights were posted. Licensee's stated that there is one weapon in the home and that the weapon/gun is locked and stored in the master bedroom closet , and the ammunition is locked and stored separately in the garage. There were no pool or other bodies of water. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. Facility will accept only two ambulatory developmentally disabled children and licensed for a capacity of 2 foster children age 0-17. Facility prefers to serve children that are medically fragile and with special health care needs 0-2. The Licensee's meet the requirements for the 8 hours of annual foster care training. Licensee’s First Aid and CPR cards expire on March 18, 2023. A review of staff records on this date indicates that all adults residing in the home or providing care and supervision to children have received fingerprint and child abuse index check clearances. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided this date.

facility_name: MARGARET AND HENRY SMALL FAMILY HOME
narrative:
On October 07, 2024, at 12:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rafael Enriquez began a pre-licensing inspection for Margaret & Henry Small Family Home for an initial license. LPA met with applicant Margaret Mwangi & Henry Benson who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicants. Currently there are no children placed in the home. The applicants were approved to serve three children ages 0 to 17. The home is a Two-story building with four bedrooms and three bathrooms which is set up as follows: Downstairs: · Bedroom #1 will sleep two foster children; it was furnished with two twin sized beds. It was vacant. · There was also a living room, a dining area, a kitchen, two pantry closets, a laundry room, a bathroom and a storage closet. Upstairs: · Bedroom #2, the master bedroom, it was furnished with a Cal-king sized bed and a crib, it had a bathroom and a walk-in closet. It sleeps the applicants. · Bedroom #3, sleeps applicant’s 22-year-old son, it was furnished with a queen-sized bed. · Bedroom #4, sleeps applicant’s 25-year-old daughter, it was furnished with a queen-sized bed. There was also a linen closet, and a bathroom.

Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. Telephone service and appliances were in working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients/children will have access. Sharp knives and sharp objects were locked in a kitchen drawer. Cleansers/chemicals were inaccessible and stored in a locked kitchen cabinet underneath the sink. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of three days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable food. A proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. The water temperature was observed to be at 105.8 degrees. First Aid kit was accessible with all required items, and it was in a kitchen cabinet. A Fire extinguisher was observed and properly charged. The fireplace was in the living room area, and it was properly screened. All the appropriate forms were posted in view of facility clients. As stated by applicant, there were no weapons/firearms and there were no pools or other bodies of water. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. The request for licensure will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. Applicants were advised to contact the department within 30 days of their first placement. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to applicant Margaret Mwangi & Henry Benson.

facility_name: MARGARET AND HENRY SMALL FAMILY HOME
narrative:
On July 7, 2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez arrived at Margaret and Henry Small Family Home (SFH) for a post licensing visit. LPA met with licensee Henry Benson who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out. Currently there is one client placed in the home. Licensees were approved for a capacity of three children ages 0 to 17 years old. The home is a two- story building with four bedrooms and three bathrooms. The downstairs consisted of an entry way with all required postings such as emergency disaster plan, facility sketch, personal rights, visitation policy, and license. There was fire extinguisher #1 that was operable and a living room with couches, TV, and a telephone land line service. The kitchen was clean and sanitary with locked sharps/ knives, a locked cabinet storing medication, and client files/ personnel records. The pantry and refrigerator were fully stocked with perishable and non perishable foods. There was bathroom #1 that was fully functioning with water temperature measuring 114.6 degrees Fahrenheit and trash cans with tight fitting lids. There was bedroom #1 that had two twin size beds, dresser/ drawer space and was utilized for two clients (one ambulatory and one non-ambulatory) one bed was occupied by an ambulatory client while the other one was vacant. There was a laundry room that was accessible to clients. The garage stored laundry detergents, extra house hold items such as paper towels, and a locked cabinet with gardening tools. The upstairs consisted of bedroom #2 that was the master bedroom for licensees that had a crib for a client currently vacant and bathroom #2 fully functioning. There was bathroom #3 that had a trash can with a tight fitting lid and fully functioning. Bedroom #3 was for licensees biological son and had a queen size bed and fully furnished. Bedroom #4 was for licensees biological daughter and had a queen size bed and was fully furnished.

There was a hallway with fire extinguisher #2 that was operable and a closet storing extra linen and towels. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. Telephone service and appliances were in working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients/children will have access. As stated by licensees, there were no weapons/firearms and there were no pools or other bodies of water. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. The client and facility files were reviewed as well as two staff and one client were interviewed. The home was also inspected for a non-ambulatory status change for one client and meets regulations. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and 10 technical assistances were discussed and provided to licensees MARGARET MWANGI & HENRY BENSON.

On 01/27/2021 at 10:00AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia made an announced to Marshall Small Family Home for the purpose to conduct the Annual/Required licensing inspection. LPA Rosas met with Adult#1 (A1) who granted access to the home and an inspection of the facility was conducted together. Individuals mention in this report are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 01/26/21. This is a single-story family home in a residential neighborhood, and it has three (3) bedrooms, (2) two bathrooms, living room, kitchen, dining area, backyard, working fireplace with a secured screen on. There is an attached garage and pond in the backyard with a fence around it. The facility has alarm system on the doors. The home is licensed to serve four (4) developmentally disabled children, ages 2-17 years, ambulatory only. The annual fee is current. Currently in placement are three (2) clients from Child Welfare Services. A1 confirmed that there are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the home. LPA Rosas inspected the following: Bedroom #1: Is occupied by Adult#1 (A1) and also used as an office. It has one queen size bed, adequate drawer and closet space adequate drawer space, closet space and lighting, comfortable mattress, and clean lines, blankets and pillows. The room has a walk-in closet and bathroom #1. Bedroom #2: Is occupied by Client#3 (C3) It has two twin beds, and adequate drawer space, closet and lighting, comfortable mattresses, and clean lines, blankets, and pillows. Bedroom #3: Is occupied by Client#1 (C1) and Client #2 (C2). It has two twin beds, adequate drawer space, closet space and lighting, comfortable mattress, and clean lines, blankets and pillows. Bathrooms: Bathroom #1 is located inside the master bedroom, equipped with a tub, shower, toilet and sink. Bathroom #2 is located near bedroom #2 and #3 equipped with a tub, shower, toilet and sink. Water temperature measured within safe temperatures, at not less than 105 and did not exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Report continues on LIC 809-C Page 1 of 4

Outdoor Area: There are bodies of water on the premises; a fish pond located in the back yard. The fish pond has two (2) gold fishes and its covered with a fence around the pond. The activity space is free of hazard materials and debris. LPA observed the utility shut-off valves in the side of the home. The facility is surrounded by wooden fence and is observed to be good condition. Garage: The attached two car garage is used as storage and is kept locked. here is a vehicle available to transport foster children; make and model 2014 Toyota Sienna Van. The vehicle has full coverage auto insurance with Farmers Insurance. The washer and dye are located inside of the garage. The laundry is equipped with a washer and dryer unit that was observed to be in good condition. The laundry detergent is made inaccessible to the children and is disputed according to the load of the laundry. Disinfectants and chemicals are locked inside of the garage making inaccessible. Living Room: There is adequate furniture which appears to be in good condition. The living room has dining table with six (6) chairs and television. Additional disinfectants, chemicals, and medication are locked in storage closet in the living room making inaccessible. Dining Area/Kitchen/Family Room (Den): There is adequate furniture which appears to be in good condition. There is a television and working fireplace with a cover. One table with six (6) chairs is next to the Kitchen: There is a gas stove/oven with four (4) burners, all operating. There is a dishwasher, microwave, refrigerator/freezer and a toaster oven. LPA’s observed adequate perishable/nonperishable food supplies. Sharp knives, disinfectants/cleaning solutions made inaccessible to the children locked in cabinet under the sink. Water temperature measured within safe temperatures, at not less than 105 and did not exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Additional LPA observed a key locked closet that stored hygiene supplies, and cleaning solutions. All windows were in good condition with screens and blinds. There were no security bars on the windows. LPA observed ample towels and linen closet. The passageways and porches are unobstructed. All posting requirements were met, (food menu, regulations, licenses, emergency disaster plan, Children’s Personal Rights, and Ombudsman). The home has a working telephone and youths can use the telephone unless restricted by court order. The Emergency Evacuation Plan is posted. All posting requirements were met. Report continues on LIC 809-C Page 2 of 4

Medications, disinfectants, and cleaning solutions are inaccessible to children and kept locked in a storage closet. The home has a functioning carbon monoxide detector that meet the statutory requirements. All smoke detectors were tested and operable at the time of inspection. LPA Rosas observed a fire extinguisher at the time of inspection. Perishable and non-perishable food is adequate in the home. The Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. Facility has a current, written plan of operation. Facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights. Licensee will report changes in the plan of operation affecting service to youths. Licensee will report youth injuries requiring medical treatment. All the children prescribed medications are locked in the closed and children files are kept in a lock cabinet inside Bedroom#1. Staff office is located inside Bedroom#1. The First Aid kit has the required items inside age-appropriate, and scissors, tweezers, thermometer, and gauzes, antiseptic and First Aid Manual Guide and is kept in the kitchen. LPA Rosas reviewed three (3) clients record currently in care. There are three (3) individual client folders. The Facility maintains client’s cash resources, personal property, and valuables. Client's records contain authorization for medical care signed by each client's authorized representative. Client's records contain copies of the original Needs and Services plan signed by each child and their authorized representative (County Social Worker (CSW). LPA was not able to interview youth as they were in school at time of inspection. LPA Rosas reviewed one (1) staff file. A1 has parenting training for 2019 and is enrolled in Casa Pacifica but due to the COVID-19 pandemic has not been able to obtain training hours for 2020. Licensee has current First Aid and CPR training; expiration date of 3/2021 and training was obtained from an accredited agency. LPA Rosas interviewed A1. A review of Facility's Personnel Report Summary on 01/26/2021 indicates that all personnel have criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response. Report continues on LIC 809-C Page 3 of 4

LPA Rosas provided the following PIN 21-20-CRP: Statewide Launch of New Inspection Tools for Children’s Residential Licensees, and PIN 20-17 CPR New Background Check Requirements and copy of MAR, Emergency Disaster Plan for Children Residential Facilities (LIC 610). LPA Rosas issued Advisory Technical Assistance Note for 80087(a) (a) The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors for the living room to be organized and store all extra supplies. Technical Assistance Advisory Note for 83070(b) (12) (b) For each child in the home, the licensee shall maintain a separate, complete, and most up to date record or file that includes the following: (12) A separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed to the child documenting. LPA Rosas provided a copy MAR for logging each psychotropic medication. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with A1 and a copy of this report was left in the facility.

Outdoors activity space free of obstructions. The front and backyard are cleared from hazards. Bedroom #3: Is occupied by licensee and used as an office. Page 2 Kitchen: LPA Wilson observed a posted menu and a fire extinguisher in the kitchen that was operable at the time of inspection. Clients in care are supervised and protected at all times. The home has multiple (2) functioning carbon monoxide detectors that meet the statutory requirements. There are (4) smoke detectors that were tested and operable at the time of inspection. Postings: All posting requirements were met. Facility posts child's rights in dining area adjacent to kitchen.
