On February 19, 2025, at 10:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Erika Butler, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) JoAunne’ Griffin arrived at Brenda's Family Home for the purpose of conducting a Pre-Licensing Inspection. LPA and LPM met with Applicants Brenda Cano, and Britney Martinez who granted access to the home and together a tour of the interior and exterior home was conducted. Currently living in the home is the Applicants and their biological son and daughter. The home is set up as follows: This is a three bedroom, two bathroom home located in a residential area. The home consists of a living room, dining room, kitchen, den, laundry space, backyard area, and garage. Living room: is equipped with mounted TV, two chairs, two children chairs, couch, ottoman, and covered fireplace. Dining room: is equipped with a table with three chairs. Den area: is equipped with a sectional couch, three chairs, coffee table, fish tank, and screen for watching television/movies. Kitchen: is equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, a five burner gas stove (all burners were operational at the time of the inspection), and microwave. Sharp knives are kept inaccessible in a box on top of the refrigerator. LPA observed a covered trash can, dishes, and eating utensils. LPA observed ample and non-perishable food items. The Applicants will ensure that three nutritious meals and snacks will be provided to the clients. 809 continued on page 2

Bedroom #1: Applicants bedroom is equipped with a queen size bed, adequate closet space, television, adequate lighting, and windows. Bedroom #2: client's bedroom equipped with a crib, and toddler bed, adequate closet and dresser space, adequate lighting, and windows. Bedroom #3: Applicants biological children's room equipped with bunk beds, adequate closet and dresser space, adequate lighting, and windows. Applicants were informed that children of the opposite sex over five years of age can not share a bedroom. Bathroom: Bathroom #1 is located in hallway, and bathroom #2 is located near the garage entrance. Applicants states that bathroom #2 is not used. Bathrooms were observed to be clean and in working condition. Vehicle: The Applicants will use a 2022 Range Rover to transport client. Insurance is valid from December 12, 2024 - June, 14 2025. The vehicle was observed to be in good condition. The home’s temperature is maintained by central air/heating. LPA observed one fully charged fire extinguisher which is located in the entrance to the garage. Extra linens are stored in the linen closet located in the clients bedroom. Applicants were advised to only keep the towels/linen for the clients in bedroom #2. All other towels/linen are to be kept in the Applicants bedroom. The smoke alarm and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. First Aid kit was found to be be complete with required items. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept in a locked cabinet in the bathroom. Report continued on LIC 809C. (Page 2 of 3)

LPA reminded Applicants to ensure the following when children are in placement: Children are accorded personal rights and the corresponding form is in their file. Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Applicant acknowledges abuse reporting requirements. Applicant will ensure grievance process, Disaster Plan, discipline policies and procedures will be posted in dining room area. During the inspection, LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. Purchase a mobile phone for client's use, Door need to be replaced on the shed Dog feces need to be removed out of the backyard Wood, toilet, chairs, water heater, cabinet, and exercise equipment needs to be removed. Bedroom #3, The room was furnished with one queen-sized bed. It was vacant. Bedroom #4, The room was furnished with one queen-sized bed. It was vacant. Bedroom #5, Master bedroom. The room consisted of one king sized bed. It sleeps the applicant.

Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medication will be locked in the kitchen cabinet area by the refrigerator. On 04/14/2025 Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Maryjane Perez and Claudia Aguilera conducted an annual/random inspection and met with Licensee Mary Juma. The home is a two-story family home with five-bedrooms, three bathrooms, and three car garage. The downstairs floor consists of a formal living room, formal dining room, kitchen, family room, one-bedroom, and one-bathroom. The kitchen consisted of a dining table with adequate seating, all sharps locked, fire extinguisher, first aid kit with all required elements. There was also adequate amount of perishable and non-perishable foods. The family room consisted of chairs, television, piano, and books. Bedroom number one consisted of one-queen size bed and was fully furnished. In the hallway there was a coat closet for storage. Bathroom number one was also located downstairs and was fully functioning with water temperature of 118 degrees F. The garage consisted of two parked vehicles and stored household items. The upstairs consisted of bedroom number two that had a full size bed which was utilized as a guest bedroom. Bathroom number two was also located upstairs and was fully functioning. Bedroom number three consisted of two twin beds and two dressers with two drawers each, the bedroom is currently vacant and will be utilized for two clients. Bedroom number four consisted of a queen size bed, dressers, desk, and chair currently occupied by minor placed in the home. The fifth bedroom consisted of a queen size bedroom and bathroom number three and is currently occupied by licensee. The upstairs area also includes a loft with a television, books, desk, chair, and computer accessible to the client currently in the home. The laundry room was upstairs storing detergents and was locked at all times.

The outdoor grounds were also inspected, and no hazards or obstructions were observed. During inspection LPAs inspected the client file and licensee file. There was no pool or other body of water. There was no firearm in the home as stated by licensee. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and were working properly. There was a telephone land line service available in the home. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with a TA were reviewed and provided to Licensee Mary Juma.

narrative: During the investigation, a confidential interview disclosed that FC1 was playing with children. It was reported to Ex-H at the SFH that FC1 was bothering the children, so Ex-h called FC1 a wimp. The FM stated that she was not aware of the interaction between FC1 and her Ex-H. FM stated that FC1 didn’t tell her anything. FM pointed out that when FC1 wandered away, her ex-husband was not there that day, therefore, this allegation could have occurred during the prior weeks. Ex-H admitted that he called FC1 a wimp because FC1 was picking on the girls. CSW stated that she was not aware of the comment and explained that FC1 didn’t mention anything to her regarding any inappropriate comment as FC1 called her almost every day. The CSW mentioned that FC1 had a history of making falsehoods. Other confidential interviews did not provide any information. Based on confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been me and the allegation that Ex-H made inappropriate comment towards FC1 is substantiated. This poses a potential health and safety, or personal rights risk to children in care. The facility is being cited for Violation of California Code of Regulations, Tittle 22 Division Six, regulation 83072(d)(6) Personal Rights. This report was emailed to Memory for signature along with the appeal rights.
investigation_findings: 13Due to COVID 19, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Abdoulaye Traore conducted a tele-inspection via Google Duo on November 3, 2020 at 3:00 PM with Memorable Small Family Home (SFH) Licensee Memory Beaumier to issue the finding for the above stated allegation involving the SFH and foster child listed on the Confidential Names List (LIC 811). LPA was unable to conduct interviews with four of the six foster children due to their developmental delays and ages. Additionally, LPA conducted a collateral interview with a foster child (FC1) and contacted the county social worker (CSW).

deficiencies.description:
83072 Personal rights (d) The licensee shall ensure... child… is accorded the personal rights...the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the personal rights (6) To be accorded dignity... with staff and other persons.
This requirement was not met as evidence by: Based on confidential interviews and a witness statement, Ex-H made inappropriate comment toward FC1. This poses a potential health and safety, or personal rights risk to the children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee stated that she adddressed the issue with her ex-husband. FM added that she told her ex-husband that he came to visit his daughter, therefore, he shouldn't interact or say any comments to her foster children.

narrative:
On November 3, 2022 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karen Beal and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Abdoulaye Traore arrived at the Memorable Small Family to conduct an annual Inspection. LPA met with staff Greta Chikakai who granted LPA/LPM access to the home. At 10: 30 am, LPA/LPM began a tour both inside and out with the staff and Licensee Memory. There were 4 children in the home at the time of this inspection. The home has currently 5 children in placed. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes was used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The fireplace was properly screened. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medications were locked and stored in upstairs locked hallway cabinet by master bedroom. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in a locked cabinet under kitchen sink. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored also under the kitchen sink. There was 7 days of non-perishables and 3 days of fresh perishable foods observed in the pantry, refrigerator and freezer. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be at 110 degrees.

Proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. First Aid kit was accessible and contained all required items. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, visitation policy and Personal Rights were posted. As stated by Licensee, there were no weapons/firearms. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. There was no pool or other body of water on the premises. Administrative records included. A review of two staff and two client's records on this date indicates that all facility. Staff have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances and required documents. Based on this annual inspection, the home was operating within a capacity of 5 foster children and guardian child. In accordance with Title 22, Division 6, Chapters 1 & 4, there were no deficiencies being cited at this time. investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Daniel Mena met with Licensee's Sister, Greta Chikakai to discuss the investigative findings for the above stated allegation. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Daniel Mena conducted an inspection to the Small Family Home (SFH) on March 01, 2023, at 3:20pm and on May 26, 2023, at 9:03am. No immediate hazards observed. Special Investigator (SI), Marlon Williams and LPA Daniel Mena interviewed Resource Mother (RM), three children (C1, C2 & C3), Adult Assistant (A1), as well as reviewed client interview, facility and client records. Community Care Licensing received information on February 27, 2023, alleging that Staff sexually abused minor while in care, more specifically that Adult Assistant (A1) had inappropriately touched C1’s private parts while bathing. Information obtained in confidential interviews did not corroborate the allegation with a preponderance of evidence. LPA Mena and SI Williams obtained conflicting information during confidential interviews. Confidential interviews denied that A1 or anyone else in the home had ever inappropriately touched or sexually abused C1 during the time that they had lived in the home. According to confidential information obtained, C1 did not like to bathe on a daily basis and suffered from poor hygiene. According to confidential interviews A1 did assist C1 in bathing, including their private parts on at least two occasions, but denied any sexual abuse or inappropriate touching by A1 during the bathing.

narrative: In regard to the allegation, It was specifically alleged the foster mother (FM) was not preventing physical contact between FC1, FC2, and FC3 which was causing FC1, FC2, and FC3 to obtain bruises. Confidential interviews stated FC1, FC2, and FC3 played with each other in a rough manner and would fight each other. The children would hit themselves, bump against the wall and tables. FC3 would have tantrums and fall onto the floor. A confidential interview stated that most of the bruising on FC1 occurred while attending school. A confidential interview stated FC1, FC2 and FC3 were constantly monitored due to engaging in physical altercations and self-harm. Based on confidential interviews and file review, FM does not provide adequate supervision resulting in FC1, FC2 and FC3 engaging in physical altercations may have happened or may be valid, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegations, therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights were reviewed and provided to the licensee, Memory Tom Beaumier

narrative: . Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Beal conducted an inspection at the SFH, collected the following pertinent documents and interviewed staff (S1) and foster mother (FM). LPA was unable to contact the County Social Worker (CSW). FC2 and FC3 were not interviewed due their development ages. FC1 refused to be interviewed. Regarding foster children sustained unexplained injuries while in care, it was specifically alleged the foster children had bruises and rashes on their bodies. During investigation, confidential interviews stated the children would play rough with each other, have tantrums, and engage in self-harm. A confidential interview stated the children would have rashes around their mouths due to having fevers. FC2 was being cared for by a dentist for decaying teeth. LPA was unable to gather additional information. In regard to the allegation that licensee does not provide foster children appropriate clothing and shoes, it was specifically alleged that the children were wearing clothing too small or too big and the clothing was not gender appropriate or shoes were too small. A confidential interview stated the bio mother did not like the clothing the children were wearing and wanted the children to wear designer clothing. A confidential interview stated the children clothing was appropriate for their ages; the children wore clothing sized for their bodies and shoes were sized for the children’s feet. LPA didn’t observe FC1 wearing inappropriate clothing during the interview. Based on confidential interviews and file review, the allegations that FC1, FC2 and FC3 sustained unexplained injuries while in care and licensee does not provide foster children appropriate clothing and shoes may have happened or may be valid, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegations, therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. investigation_findings: 13On 05/10/2014, at 9:20AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maya Chavez arrived at Memorable Small Family Home (SFH) and met with Licensee Memory Beaumier to deliver the investigative finding regarding the allegations involving foster children (FC1-FC4) and the facility as listed on the Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated 05/9/2024. On July 5,2023, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that license did not adequately supervise minors resulting in inappropriate interactions between minors in care. On July 14, 2023, at 12:32PM, LPA Aborchie arrived unannounced to Memorable SFH to initiate an investigation and conducted a safety inspection with staff. No immediate safety hazards observed at this time of inspection. In addition, LPA M. Chavez arrived at the facility to conduct investigation. LPA interviewed licensee/Foster Mother (FM) and staff (S1). Furthermore, LPA conducted collateral interviews with FC2, FC3 and FC4. LPA was unable to interview FC1 and another child.

narrative: In regard to the allegation that foster children sustained unexplained injuries, it was specifically alleged that the children have bite marks and bruises on them. FC2 has a bruise near FC2’s eye the size of a quarter and a large bruise on FC2’s forehead. FC2 has bruising on FC2’s left arm from the elbow to the hand that almost look like grab marks. During investigation, licensee and staff disclosed that FC1, FC2, and FC3, would self-inflict injuries as well as hurt one another which were all documented when occurred. Confidential interviews didn’t provide any information regarding the allegations. A confidential witness was unable to recall incident involving FC1, FC2 and FC3. CSW stated that many of the injuries the siblings sustained were self-inflicted and that they would often hurt each other as well. Regarding the allegation that licensee did not prevent minor's hair from getting matted, licensee and staff stated that FC2 had curly hair and did not like for it to be brushed and even when brushed FC2 would mess their hair up when they lost their temper. Confidential interviews didn’t provide any information regarding the allegations. A confidential witness was unable to recall incident involving FC1, FC2 and FC3. A confidential interview stated that one time during a visit, FC1 had on an adult sized diaper but other than that, they can’t recall another time foster children were improperly dressed. LPA received a conflicting information. In regard to the allegation that licensee did not ensure minors in care were properly dressed, licensee and staff stated that FC1, FC2, and FC3 had plenty of clothes and were always properly dressed but they would often take their own clothes off during tantrums. A confidential witness was unable to recall incident involving FC1, FC2 and FC3. LPA received a conflicting information. Another interview disclosed that foster children have access to clothes and there has never been a time, foster child have been inappropriately dressed. Based on interview and record review, the allegations FC1, FC2, and FC3 sustained unexplained injuries while in care, licensee did not prevent FC1, FC2, and FC3 hair from getting matted, and licensee did not ensure FC1, FC2, and FC3 in care were properly dressed may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violations, therefore, this allegation are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to licensee Memory Beaumier.

narrative: In regard to the allegation, it was specifically reported that FC1 appears to be losing weight FC’s pants fall off on FC1) and FC1 has not been eating at school because FC1 was refusing to drink the vanilla Ensure that foster mother provided, however, FC1 would only drink the chocolate flavored Ensure and licensee said the insurance will only cover the vanilla flavored. During investigation, licensee stated that FC1 was prescribed Ensure as a meal replacement, the insurance provided only the vanilla flavored Ensure due the chocolate flavored being unavailable and it was noted that FC1 didn’t like the vanilla and preferred chocolate as a result, FC1 did not want to consume the Vanilla Ensure that FM sent to the school. LPA conducted a safety inspection with (S1). There were no immediate safety hazards observed at this time of inspection. In addition, LPA M. Chavez obtained photographic image of FC1’s vaginal area from licensee and interviewed foster children 1-3 (FC1-FC3), staff 1 (S1) and Licensee/Foster Mother (FM) as listed on the Confidential Names List (LIC 811) LPA was unable to interview FC1 due to FC1’s developmental age and FC1’s being non-verbal. narrative:
On November 13, 2023, at 1:53PM, LPA B. Aborchie arrived unannounced to Memorable SFH to initiate the investigation, interviewed licensee (LS) and conducted a health and safety inspection with licensee (LS). There were no immediate safety hazards observed at this time of inspection. In addition, LPA M. Chavez interviewed foster children (FC1, FC2, FC3 and FC4) and obtained copies of Needs and Services Plan, and a summary of Optometrist visit. LPA Chavez conducted additional interviews with licensee (LS), staff #1 (S1). LPA M. Chavez was unable to contact County Social Workers. In regard to the above allegation that licensee made numerous threats to evict minor as a mean of discipline, it was specifically reported that foster mother was always threatening to put in a 14-day notice to kick FC1 out if FC1 did not behave or listen to her in the way she expected or being disrespected by FC1. During investigation, a confidential interview disclosed that the threats to be evicted only occurred when FC1 was first placed at the SFH. Another confidential interview disclosed that evicting FC1 was not a threat or means of discipline but rather a conversation. Confidential interview explained that the conversation was to explain FC1 their rights to be placed elsewhere and that FC1 would have their support regardless of FC1’s decision. The confidential interview continued explaining that it was later mutually decided between LS and FC1 that FC1 would stay at SFH. Regarding licensee did not get prescription glasses for minor, a confidential interview disclosed that FC1 did not receive glasses for two to three months after losing them. In another confidential interview, it was disclosed that FC1 did not inform LS that FC1 lost their glasses until two to three months later, but when LS was informed about the glasses, she immediately made an appointment for FC1 to get new glasses. A confidential interview stated that LS had to pay out of pocket for glasses due to FC1’s insurance only covering new glasses every two years. (See LIC9099-C)

In regard to the allegations that licensee yelled at minor and did not treat minor with dignity nor respect, it was specifically alleged that foster mother has blown up and yelled at FC1 at least four times causing FC1 to cry. A confidential interview disclosed that LS would yell a lot when FC1 was first placed at the SFH, but then later LS got the yelling under control and eventually stopped. In another confidential interview, it was disclosed that LS and S1 both have loud voices, and their tones often are perceived as yelling. A confidential interview disclosed that they have not witnessed LS treating or dis-respecting FC1 or any other foster children. LPA didn’t receive any additional information. In regard to the above allegation that licensee does not pick up FC1 from school in a timely manner and it was reported FC1 has had to wait up to two hours for a ride during hot summers and cold winters repeatedly. During investigation, a confidential interview disclosed that the longest FC1 has ever waited for a ride was at the most, thirty minutes but was informed ahead of time. Another confidential interview disclosed that when LS is running late to pick up FC1 that LS always gives FC1 the option to wait, get an uber, or arrange for someone else to pick FC1 up. LPA received a conflicting information. In regard to the above allegation that LS did not provide FC1 with hygiene products specially soap. A confidential interview disclosed that FC1 does not like to shower nor brush their teeth and FC1 used falsehood during a meeting that soap was not available. Another interview disclosed that the facility has plenty of hygiene products that are unlocked. Another confidential interview indicated that when they run out of hygiene products, they just have to ask LS or S1 to provide hygiene products. LPA received a conflicting information. Based on interview, inspection, and record review, the allegations that licensee made numerous threats to evict FC1 as a means of discipline; licensee did not get prescription glasses for FC1; licensee yelled at FC1 and does not treat FC1 with dignity or respect; licensee did not pick FC1 up in a timely manner from school, and licensee does not provide FC1 with hygiene products (soap) may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violations, therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Staff #1.
investigation_findings: 13On 07/24/2024, at 9:15AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maya Chavez arrived at Memorable Small Family Home (SFH) and met with Staff #1 Gretta Chikakai to deliver the investigative finding regarding the allegations involving foster child #1 (FC1) and the facility. On November 07, 2023, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint consisting of the following allegations: Licensee made numerous threats to evict minor as a means of discipline; licensee did not get prescription glasses for minor; licensee yelled at minor; licensee does not treat minor with dignity or respect; licensee did not pick minor up in a timely manner from school; and licensee does not provide minor with hygiene products (soap). (See LIC9099-C)

narrative:
On July 25, 2024 at 09:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) R. Enriquez arrived at Memorable SFH to initiate the complaint and conducted a safety inspection with (S1). There were no immediate safety hazards observed at this time of inspection. In addition, LPA M. Chavez conducted a visit to Memorable SFH. LPAs conducted interviews with child 1 and 3 (C1 & C3) staff 1 (S1), licensee (LS), and C1’s county social worker (CSW) as listed on the Confidential Names List (LIC 811). LPAs were unable to interview child 2 and 4 (C2 & C4) due to C2 and C4 being non-verbal. In regard to the allegations that licensee does not prevent a minor from walking around nude while in care and licensee does not prevent a minor from engaging in inappropriate interaction with another minor. It was specifically reported that C2 walks around the SFH late at night nude and one-night C2 tried to get in to bed with C3 while nude. Multiple confidential interviews disclosed that after C2 goes to bed for the night that C2 will then take their clothes off and walk to the restroom during the night naked. In addition, confidential interviews disclosed that C2 now has one on one supervision to ensure C2 doesn’t leave their room naked and there are now doorbells on C2’s bedroom door which make a sound when C2 leaves their room during the night. Multiple confidential interviews disclosed that C1 and C3 lock their door at night to avoid C2 from going in their room. In addition, multiple interviews stated that C2 has never harmed any clients and the time C2 went into C1 and C3’s room was an accident. Regarding the allegation that licensee does not provide adequate transportation for a minor, it was specifically reported that LS does not pick up C1 from school and that LS has C1 take Uber home. During confidential interview, it was disclosed that C1 had to take an uber home on a few occasions where LS was running late to pick up but as of November 2024, C1 has not had to take Uber home and that LS is on time to pick up C1 from school. In addition, a confidential interview disclosed that during a child family and team meeting LS disclosed that during situations where LS was not able to get C1 on time from or to school then LS would use Uber and C1’s social worker nor any other participants in the meeting stated Uber was unacceptable. In regard to the allegation that licensee screams at a minor, it was specifically reported that LS screams at C1 for falling asleep on the couch. During multiple confidential interviews, it was disclosed that LS does not scream at C1 or any other clients in care. Other multiple confidential interviews disclosed that LS has a naturally loud voice but does not yell at C1. LPA did not receive any further details.

Based on interview and record review, the allegations that licensee does not prevent C2 from walking around nude while in care; licensee does not prevent C2 from engaging in inappropriate interaction with another minor; licensee does not provide adequate transportation for C1; licensee screams at C1 may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violations, therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to licensee Memory Beaumier.

On July 17, 2023, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that licensee does not prevent a minor from walking around nude while in care; licensee does not prevent a minor from engaging in inappropriate interaction with another minor; licensee does not provide adequate transportation for a minor and licensee screams at a minor.

narrative: In regard to the allegation that a foster child is being neglected while in care it was specifically reported that LC pointed to their private parts saying "hurt" and there was suspicion that LC may be pregnant. During multiple confidential interviews, it was disclosed that LC will point to body parts and communicate that LC is in pain. In addition, confidential interviews added that this a tactic LC used to gain attention because LC is attention seeking. Furthermore, the confidential interviews disclosed that LC is not sexually active and is on birth control because LC does not know how to deal with menstruation. Regarding licensee did not meet foster children’s medical needs allegation, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that LS takes LC to doctor’s appointments and urgent care as needed/ frequently. Another confidential interview disclosed that LS will share LC’s medical documents with county social worker and LS does take LC to their medical appointments. A confidential interview disclosed that when LC is not receiving attention, LC will communicate that LC is sick or in pain to LS, teacher, or school nurse. Another confidential interview disclosed that children in LC’s class often go to the nurse’s office to get their medication daily and it has been brought to LS’s attention that when classmates are leaving the class to the nurse’s office, LC will suddenly report to the teacher that LC is in pain or sick. LPA was unable to gather additional interviews whether the foster children were being neglected. Based on interview and record review, the allegations that a foster child is being neglected while in care and licensee did not meet children’s medical needs may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violation, therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to staff 1, Gretta Chikakai.

narrative:
On March 20, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez arrived at Memorable Small Family Home to conduct annual required inspection. LPA met with licensee Memory Tom Beaumier who granted access into the home. Currently, there were 3 ambulatory clients placed in the home and it is licensed for a capacity of 6. The Facility was toured both inside and out with the licensee. The home is a two story building with 6 bedrooms and 3 bathrooms. The downstairs consisted of dining room with adequate seating, living room #1 with couches and television, bathroom #1 that was fully functioning but the trash can needs a lid. The kitchen was clean and sanitary with a fully stocked pantry and refrigerator with perishable/ non-perishable foods and a lock box storing medication. There was a fire extinguisher that was up to date. The knives were in a kitchen locked cabinet as well as client medication. There was living room #2 that had more couches, television, and games. There was bedroom #1 downstairs that was vacant and used as a guest room with a twin size bed. The hallway had a first aid kit with all required elements. There was a storage closet that was locked and stored extra household items. Bedroom #2 was also downstairs and had a full size bed for licensee's family member. The upstairs had a loft that was used as a family play area as there was couches, television, toys and a desk. There was a locked laundry room that stored washer and dryer as well as soaps and detergents. Bedroom #3 was for foster children and had one full size bed and one twin size bed with dressers and closet space. Bedroom #4 had two full size beds with dresser and closet space- both beds occupied one for foster child and one for licensee's child. There was bathroom #2 was fully functioning with dual sinks and water temperature reaching 110.4 degrees Fahrenheit. There was bedroom #5 that had one full size bed and one twin size bed being occupied by one foster child and fully furnished. The hallway stored client files and personnel files locked in a cabinet. There was bedroom #6 that was for licensee and had a king size bed with bathroom #3 fully functioning.

During inspection of staff files LPA found there to be missing required training's for licensee and staff members. During inspection of client files there was missing documentation of the consent medication authorization form for one client and Tuberculosis Test for all clients. Based on these observations, the facility is cited for violation of California Code of Regulations Title 22, Division 6 Chapter 1 section 80069(c)(1) Client Medical Assessment (c) The medical assessment shall include the following: (1) The results of an examination for communicable tuberculosis and other contagious/infectious diseases. The backyard was free of hazards and had a gate with a latch for emergency exit. There was no pool or other body of water. There was no firearms in the home as stated by licensee. All bedrooms were arranged for one child per bed. There were adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and were working properly. LPA interviewed 2 staff and 1 client. LPA reviewed 4 staff files and 3 client files. During the visit there was 1 deficiency and 8 technical violations , an exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with an LIC809D form and technical assistances were reviewed and provided to Licensee Memory Tom Beaumier.

On December 3, 2020 at 1:45PM, Licensing Program Analyst, LaTonya Wilson, met with Administrator Tafadzwa Chikakayi. The purpose of this visit was to interview a foster child pertaining to concerns reported on another facility. A copy of this report was provided to the Administrator.

On October 26, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarah Smith, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Natasha Dunlap conducted an unannounced Annual inspection to the Memorable Small Family home. LPA Smith met with licensee Tafadzwa Chikakayi who led an inspection of the home. The facility was inspected inside and out at 1:33 p.m. There are currently two clients in the home. The home is four bedrooms and three bathrooms. The home is set up as follows: • Bedroom One Master bedroom has king bed and crib - sleeps licensee • Bedroom Two has two twin beds - sleeps two clients • Bedroom Three has two twin beds - sleeps adoptive child • Bedroom Four has a queen bed and crib – bedroom not in use Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The fireplace is properly screened. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. Currently, none of the clients are taking any medications. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in the laundry room and under the kitchen sink with locks. The first aid kit contains all required items. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in the kitchen cabinet. Licensees had current CPR/ First Aid certificates. Licensee provided proof of 8 hours of continued education training. see continuation page

There are no guns or weapons as stated by licensee at this time. Water temperature was tested and is safe and within regulation requirements. Smoke detectors & carbon monoxide detector in hallways are all rooms were tested and operable. Proper storage of all food was noted. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. The Emergency Disaster Plan with exit map was posted and available for view. Title 22 Personal Rights, and visitation policies are posted at this time. Toys are safe, clean, and age appropriate for the age group of children being cared for. Two children files and one staff file were reviewed. Children records are organized and up to date. A review of staff records on this date indicates that all facility staff have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances. The back yard was inspected. LPA observed and photographed a hole in the fence. Per LPA observation a review of records indicated that there is no fire drill documentation. However, Licensee stated that fire drills are conducted every six months. See LIC9099D page. Based on LPA observation and record review, facility is cited for Title 22 80087(a) Buildings and Grounds, and 80023(d)(2) Disaster and Mass Casualty Plan which poses a potential health and safety risk to clients in care. Exit interview conducted and copies of this report, appeal rights given and explained to the licensee. Due to technical difficulties, original signatures have been placed in the facility file.

LPA Castillo met with licensee Tafadzwa Chikakayi who led an inspection of the home. The facility was inspected inside and out. There is currently one client in the home. The home is four bedrooms and three bathrooms. The home is set up as follows: • Bedroom One Master bedroom has king bed and crib - sleeps licensee • Bedroom Two has two twin beds - sleeps two clients • Bedroom Three has two twin beds - sleeps adoptive child • Bedroom Four has a queen bed and crib – bedroom not in use Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The fireplace is properly screened. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. Currently, none of the clients are taking any medications. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in the laundry room and under the kitchen sink with locks. The first aid kit contains all required items. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in the kitchen cabinet. Licensees had current CPR/ First Aid certificates. Licensee provided proof of 8 hours of continued education training. (continue on next page)

There are no guns or weapons as stated by licensee at this time. Water temperature was tested and is safe and within regulation requirements. Smoke detectors & carbon monoxide detector in hallways are all rooms were tested and operable. Proper storage of all food was noted. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. The Emergency Disaster Plan with exit map was posted and available for view. Title 22 Personal Rights, and visitation policies are posted at this time. Toys are safe, clean, and age appropriate for the age group of children being cared for. One child file and one staff file were reviewed. Child's records are organized and up to date. A review of staff records on this date indicates that all facility staff have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances. The back yard was inspected, LPA did not observe any health and safety issues or concerns. LPA's review of records indicated that the fire drill documentation is up to date. At this time there are no deficiencies observed. Exit interview conducted and copies of this report, appeal rights given and explained to the licensee.

On October 5, 2023 at 12:15pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karen Beal arrived at Memorable Small Family Home 2 to conduct an annual inspection. Licensee informed LPA that the annual was already completed.

** continued from LIC 9099-C** On October 25, 2023, at 2:40 PM, LPA Karen Beal arrived at Memorable Small Family Home (SFH) to continue an investigation regarding the above allegation. LPA met with Licensee and LPA collected copies of needs and services plans, incident reports, and placement agreements. LPA conducted an interview with the licensee. On October 30, 2023, a confidential interview was conducted with the resource grandmother (RG), October 31, 2023, a confidential interview was conducted with CSW. On November 1, 2023, LPA conducted a collateral interview with FC1, November 8, 2023, confidential interview was conducted with FC2. Regarding the allegation foster parent locked foster child out of the home, confidential interviews stated FC1 was never locked out of the home. FC1 did not allow time for the door to be opened. Once opened FC1 chose not to enter the home. It was stated that FC1 was having an emotional outburst due to FC1 didn’t want to leave RG home. The police were called and deemed that FC1 did not meet the requirements to be placed on a 5150 hold. In regard to foster parent hitting foster child and another child in the home, confidential interviews stated there was never any kind of physical abuse occurring in the home. Children in the home are disciplined by taking their electronics away and restricting television time. LPA didn’t receive additional information. Lastly regarding foster parent did not provide adequate supervision for foster child(ren) and foster child sustained multiple injuries while in care due to lack of supervision, confidential interview disclosed that there was supervision provided for the children in care. When the licensee needed to attend to other business, care for the children was provided by the grandmother confidential interviews stated that the children would get into fights and would receive scratches from the fights. LPA received conflicting information. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that foster parent locked foster child out of the home, foster parent hit foster child and another child in the home, foster parent did not provide adequate supervision for foster child(ren), foster child sustained multiple injuries while in care due to lack of supervision may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegations. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights were reviewed and provided to the S1..
investigation_findings: 13On November 17, 2023, at 12:30 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karen Beal met with Memorable Small Family Home #2, Tafadzwa “Ivette” Chikakayi, Licensee to deliver the investigative finding for the above stated allegations. narrative: ****Continued from LIC 9099**** Regarding the allegation that foster parents do not prevent physical altercations between minors, it was specifically alleged that FC2 punched FC1 numerous times in the face while in the car. On September 23, 2024, at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rafael Enriquez began a pre-licensing inspection for Menifee Hills Home Small Family Home for an initial license. LPA met with applicant Babatope Opadotun who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Currently there are no children placed in the home. The applicant was approved to serve two bedridden children ages 0 to 17. The home is a Two-story building with five bedrooms and three bathrooms which is set up as follows: Downstairs: · Bedroom #1 will sleep two foster children, It was furnished with two twin sized beds. It was vacant. · There was also a living room, a dining area, a kitchen, a pantry, a study room, a bathroom, and a coat closet. Upstairs: · Bedroom #2 is a guest room; it was furnished with a queen-sized bed. It was vacant. · Bedroom #3 is a guest room; it was furnished with a queen-sized bed. It was vacant. · Bedroom #4, sleeps applicant’s two daughters, it was furnished with two twin sized bed. · Bedroom #5, the master bedroom, it was furnished with a king-sized bed, it had a bathroom and a walk-in closet. It sleeps the applicant and his spouse. · There was also a study nook, a loft, a laundry room and a bathroom.

Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. Telephone service and appliances were in working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients/children will have access. Sharp knives and sharp objects were locked in a cabinet in the kitchen. Cleansers/chemicals were inaccessible and stored in a locked storage outside. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of three days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable food. A proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. The water temperature was observed to be at 114.0 degrees. First Aid kit was accessible with all required items, and it was in the client’s room. A Fire extinguisher was observed and properly charged. All the appropriate forms were posted in view of facility clients. As stated by applicant, there were no weapons/firearms and there were no pools or other bodies of water. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. The request for licensure will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. Applicant was advised to contact the department within 30 days of their first placement. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to applicant Babatope Opadotun.

On May 19, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez made an unannounced visit to Menifee Hills Home to conduct a post licensing inspection. LPA met with licensee Babatope Opadotun who led a tour of the entire home inside and out. Currently there is one child in placement. The licensee was approved for a capacity of two bedridden children ages 0 to 17. The home is a two-story building with five bedroom and three bathrooms. The downstairs consisted of a kitchen, living room, study, bathroom, and a bedroom. The kitchen was clean and sanitized with locked sharps/ knives, an operable fire extinguisher, refrigerator and pantry with three days of perishable and seven days of non-perishable foods as well as a locked cabinet storing medication. The water temperature was measuring 115.8 degrees Fahrenheit. The living room consisted of a couch, television, and toys. There was a study that had books, a desk, printer, and all required postings such as emergency disaster plan, visitation policy, facility sketch and facility license. There was bathroom #1 that was fully functioning, with adequate space and a trash can with a lid. There was also bedroom #1 that had a hospital bed for one bedridden client that was currently occupied, a twin size bed- currently vacant, and dresser/closet space for personal belongings and a locked cabinet storing clients medications and client files. The bedroom also stored the first aid kit with all required elements. The home was missing a telephone land line service. The upstairs consisted of bedroom #2, bedroom #3, bedroom #4, bathroom #2, a loft, a laundry room, and bedroom #5 that was considered master bedroom with bathroom #3.

Bedroom #2 was utilized for storage, storing extra house hold items. Bedroom #3 was utilized as a guest bedroom with a queen size bed and closet space. Bedroom #4 was utilized for licensee's biological children and had two twin size beds, toys, and closet space. Bathroom #2 was fully functioning and had two side by side sinks, a trash can with a lid, and locked cabinets storing cleaning products. The loft had a couch, television, and toys. The laundry room was accessible and had laundry detergents stored away from children's reach. Bedroom #5 was considered master bedroom that was utilized for licensee and had a cal- king size bed, fully furnished, and had fully functioning bathroom #3. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. The garage stored an extra freezer with extra food, extra items for client such as diapers/bedding, and a wheel chair. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. There was no pool or other body of water. There were no firearms as stated by licensee. One client and two staff files were reviewed as well as two staff and one client were interviewed. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. Appliances were in working order. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report, 3 technical assistances, and 1 technical violation were discussed and provided to licensee Babatope Opadotun.

On 08/10/2021, at approximately 4 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon attempted to conduct an unannounced on-site inspection of this facility to follow up on a report that the Regional Office received via phone of a COVID-19 outbreak in the facility. LPA was met at the door by staffer Kim Miller. Three individuals from this facility have been hospitalized due to COVID-19 symptoms (all three tested positive for COVID-19). The one client the facility had cannot come back to the facility for the time being--the County Case Worker and North Bay Regional Center have been informed of recent developments. There is a hold on facility operations at the moment. No citations were issued as a result of this inspection.

On 02/14/2022, at approximately 4 PM, LPA Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this facility. LPA collected the Home's physical Community Care licenses as part of the process of formally closing the facility--the closure is brought on by the licensee passing away. LPA met with Rhonda Levias, facility caregiver and daughter of the licensee, who confirmed that there were no clients under the facility's care; LPA observed no indication of placements being on the premises. Ms. Levias does have an adopted child living in the home. No citations were issued, and this inspection effectively closes Miller's Care Home #1 without contingency; a copy of this report is being provided to the facility.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill met with Edward Miller, Licensee applicant at the Community Care Licensing office to conduct a Component II, face to face meeting with Edward Miller, Licensee, to discuss the facility application. LPA Hill and licensee discussed the application and went over the document provided to the applicant regarding the application review. LPA Hill did receive a copy of the facility sketch of the property indicating a fence around the pool located at the facility. LPA Hill discussed the need for water safety certificate(s) for all staff using the pool with the youth in care. LPA Hill also received a copy of the facility deed as proof of ownership of the home. Some topics discussed during the inspection included positive discipline, emergency interventions, being clear about the clientele to be admitted to the facility, ages of clients to be served (differing ages and the LIC200 indicates they would accept children ages 0 to 5). LPA Hill discussed with Mr. Miller that the updated documents need to be provided to this LPA by 5/31/25. Exit interview was conducted with Mr. Miller and the document was provided.

On this date Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Daniel Mena conducted an annual inspection at the facility. The home was toured inside and out with licensee, Heidi Mitchell. The home is a one story residence with 6 bedrooms and 3 bathroom. The home is set up as follows: Bedroom #1 - is the master bedroom, contains a king size bed and sleeps the licensees. Bedroom #2 - is designated as a sewing/storage room. Bedroom #3 - is designated for the licensee’s biological child. The room contained one twin size bed and had adequate drawer and closet space for child’s belongings. Bedroom #4- is designated for two foster children. The room contained two cribs and had adequate drawer and closet space for child’s belongings. Bedroom #5 - is designated for the licensee’s biological children. The room contains two-twin sized beds at this time and had adequate drawer and closet space for child's belongings. Bedroom #6 - is utilized as a school room. The room contained desks, cubbies, and additional storage space. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors were checked and were working properly. There was also a plenty of space for children to play.

The fireplace was located in the family room area and it was properly screened. Telephone service and appliances were in a working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the laundry rooms. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, visitation policy and Personal Rights were posted. Licensee's stated that there are no weapons in the home. There were no pool or other bodies of water. Facility is licensed to care for medically fragile/developmentally disabled children 0-17 years of age, ambulatory only. Licensee prefers to serve medically fragile children ages 0-2 years old. The Licensee's meet the requirements for the 8 hours of annual foster care training. Licensee’s First Aid and CPR cards expire on February 02, 2023. The client has been sick for months and in hospice care. Administrator has notified all parties. Administrator sent in an Incident to regional center and gave a copy to LPA. LPA also requested a copy of the clients needs and services plan.

met_with: Applicants- Monica Mugo and Patrick Muchiri
narrative:
On February 14, 2025, at 9:50 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez arrived at Monica Mugo and Patrick Muchiri Small Family Home (SFH) for a pre-licensing inspection for an initial license. LPA met with applicants Monica Mugo and Patrick Muchiri who led a tour of the entire home inside and out. Currently there is one resource family approval (RFA) child placed in the home but no other clients. The applicants are applying to serve four children ages 0 to 17, 2 ambulatory and 2 non-ambulatory. The home is a two-story building with 5 bedrooms and 4 and a half bathrooms. The downstairs consisted of living room #1 fully furnished with couches, toys, and adequate play space. There was a half bathroom as it has only a sink and toilet with water temperature reaching 111 degrees Fahrenheit. There was a closet that stores extra house hold items such as toilet paper and paper towels. There was living room #2 fully furnished with couches, television, and telephone land line. The fireplace was in the living room area as well and it was properly screened. The kitchen had working appliances and a fully stocked refrigerator and pantry with perishable and non-perishable foods. There was a locked bag to store refrigerated medication if needed. The knives and sharps were locked in a kitchen drawer as well as medication. Under the kitchen sink there was a locked cabinet storing kitchen cleaning supplies. There was a bulletin board in the kitchen with posted personal rights, facility sketch, emergency disaster plan and visitation policy. Fire extinguisher #1 is located in the kitchen as well. There was also a locked cabinet that stores client files and cash resources. The first aid kit sits on kitchen counter with all the required elements. There was a dining room with dining table with adequate seating. Downstairs also had bedroom #1 that will be utilized for two non-ambulatory clients that was fully furnished and had one full size bed and one twin size bed with the appropriate bedding. The full size bed is currently vacant meanwhile the twin bed is occupied by an RFA child who might be removed from the home once licensed. There was full bathroom #1 that was fully functioning with a sink, toilet and shower/ tub.

The upstairs consisted of a laundry room that was accessible to clients but had several locked cabinets storing laundry detergents and essentials. There was also cabinets storing extra blankets and linen. There was bedroom #2 that was fully furnished and had a queen size bed that was utilized for applicants biological son. There was also bedroom #3 that had one full size bed and one twin bed currently vacant and fully furnished with closet and drawer space that will be utilized for 2 ambulatory clients. Across from the bedrooms was bathroom #2 that had two sinks, a toilet, and shower/ tub. Bedroom #4 had a queen size bed and was fully furnished with dressers and closet space that will be utilized for one ambulatory client. There was bathroom #3 with two sinks, toilet, and shower/tub. The upstairs hallway had cabinets storing blankets, towels and a locked cabinet for personnel records. Fire extinguisher #2 was placed in upstairs hallway as well. There was a game room that was fully furnished with couch and television with adequate play space. The master bedroom was fully furnished and had a king size bed with a infant crib with required bedding and bathroom #4 fully functioning. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and are working properly. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The garage was spacious and free of hazards with a an extra freezer storing frozen goods. The backyard was fully enclosed with a gate that has a latch and free of hazards and obstruction. There is no pool or other body of water and there are no guns or weapons as stated by both applicants at this time. There are no deficiencies observed at this time. Component III orientation was completed this day with LPA. The request for licensure will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final review and approval. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to applicants Monica Mugo and Patrick Muchiri.

On March 28, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez began a post-licensing inspection for Monica Mugo & Patrick Muchiri Small Family Home (SFH). LPA met with licensee Monica Mugo who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out. Currently there is one child in placement. The licensee was approved for a capacity of four children ages 0 to 17. The home is a two- story building with five bedrooms and four and a half bathrooms. The downstairs consisted of a play area with toys and couches, a living room with couch, TV, and a land line service, a half bathroom , a dining room with adequate seating arrangement, a clean/ sanitary kitchen with an abundance of perishable and non-perishable foods, first aid kit, fire extinguisher #1 and all required postings such as disaster plan, visitation policy, facility sketch, menu, and license posted. The kitchen also had locked medications and knives/sharp objects stored in a cabinet. The downstairs also consisted of bathroom #1 that was fully functioning with water temperature measuring 123.8 degrees Fahrenheit- licensee understands the water temperature range must be from 105-120 degrees Fahrenheit. Bedroom #1 had closet/ dresser space with one hospital bed for a client and was currently occupied and one full size bed for another client that was currently vacant. The upstairs had a laundry room with locked cleaning supplies and detergents, bathroom #2 that was fully functioning with dual sinks, bedroom #2 that was fully furnished and was utilized for licensees biological child. There was also bedroom #3 that had one full size bed and one twin size bed, closet and dresser space that would be utilized for two clients and is currently vacant. There was bedroom #4 that was fully furnished and had bathroom #3, a hallway storing extra towels and linens as well as fire extinguisher #2. The upstairs also had bedroom #5 that was licensee's bedroom with bathroom #4, and a loft area with TV and couches.

Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate lighting and drawer/ closet space for children’s belongings. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The outdoor grounds were also inspected, and no hazards or obstructions were observed. During inspection LPA inspected one client file and two staff files. There was no pool or other body of water. There was no firearm in the home as stated by licensee. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and were working properly. LPA interviewed two staff and one client. During the visit. there were no deficiencies observed, however, LPA issued three technical advisories (TA) which were explained and given to licensee. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with three TA's were reviewed and provided to licensee's Monica Mugo and Patrick Muchiri.

On August 19, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez met with applicant Monica Mwaniki this date for a Component II. LPA went over revisions needed for the application prior to licensure. LPA gave a copy of the LIC 184, Letter of Application Revision, and additional correspondence to assist with the revisions needed to the application. A copy of this report was provided to applicant Monica Mwaniki.

met_with: Applicant- Monica Mwaniki and Steve Kibiku
narrative:
On August 29, 2025, licensing program analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez arrived at Monica Small Family Home (SFH) for a pre-licensing inspection for an initial license. LPA met with applicants Monica Mwaniki and Steve Kibiku who led a tour of the entire home inside and outside. The applicants are applying to serve four clients (2 ambulatory, 1 non-ambulatory, and 1 bed ridden) ages 0 to 17 years old. Currently there are no clients placed in the home. The home is a two-story building with five bedrooms and five bathrooms. The downstairs consisted of an entry way with a table with a visitation log, a storage closet storing extra household items such as water, paper towels, and games. There was bedroom #1 that had one queen size bed for one non-ambulatory/bed ridden client with bathroom #1 that had a walk in shower and had a trash can with a lid. The applicants understand that there needs to be two beds to show there is room for one non-ambulatory and 1 bed ridden client. There was a hallway with all required postings such as facility sketch, personal rights, and emergency disaster plan. There was a living room with couches, a TV, a sliding door leading to the outside, and a formal dining room with adequate seating arrangement and fire extinguisher #1. The kitchen was clean and sanitary with a locked cabinet for storing sharp objects/knives, a locked medication cabinet, the refrigerator and pantry were fully stocked with perishable and non-perishable foods. There was a dining table with adequate seating and a cabinet storing a first aid kit with all required elements. There was another sliding door leading to the backyard. There was a small family room that had couches and a locked refrigerator for storing only medication. Bathroom #2 was fully functioning with water temperature measuring 115.1 degrees Fahrenheit. The upstairs had a hallway that had fire extinguisher #2 that was fully operable. There was a loft that stored

client files and staff records in a locked file cabinet. The loft also had couches, a TV with video games, and a desk with a computer. Bedroom #2 was fully furnished with one twin size bed and one full size bed, dresser/ closet space, and all required bedding that will be utilized by two clients currently vacant. Bathroom #3 had dual sinks, shower/bathtub, and a trash can with a fitted lid. Bedroom #3 had two twin size beds, dresser/closet space, and all required bedding that will be utilized for two clients and is currently vacant. Bedroom #4 was for applicants biological son and had a bunk bed with one full size bed at the bottom and one twin size bed at the top. The room was fully furnished and had bathroom #4 with dual sinks, a shower/bathtub, and a trash can with a lid. The laundry room was locked at all times and stored a locked cabinet for laundry detergents, laundry essentials, and cleaning supplies. There was a linen closet that stored extra blankets, linen, and towels. Bedroom #5 was the master bedroom for applicants that will be locked at all times and had a Cal-king size bed, a crib for an infant, and bathroom #5 that was fully functioning with two sinks, a walk-in shower, and a separate bath tub. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and are working properly. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced, had a gate with a latch and was free of hazards. There were no pools or other bodies of water and no weapons/firearms as stated by applicants. There was a land- line telephone service and all appliances were in working order. The garage stored extra house hold items such as toys for children and a refrigerator for storing extra goods. Based on this inspection of the home, the facility will need the following corrections: bedroom to be arranged for 1 non amb client and 1 bedridden client After corrections are completed, the applicants will notify LPA so that another inspection can be completed. Component III orientation was also completed this day of August 29th, 2025. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to applicant Monica Mwaniki and Steve Kibiku

On September 29, 2021 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Belinda Gilmer conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility at 8:03 AM. LPA met with Marta Montiel, Licensee. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct an Annual/Required inspection of this Small Family Home. Currently there are there are three (3) foster children and two (2) legal guardian. This is a six bedroom, three bathrooms one story single family home. During the inspection, LPA conducted a physical plant inspection, operational requirements interviewed (1) client the staff working with Licensee doesn't speak English and was not interviewed today. Physical Plant: The license is posted in a prominent, disinfectants, cleaning solutions are kept in the garage and sharps are kept on a high shelf in the kitchen over the refrigerator. The home has non-perishable foods for at least one week. Medications are centrally stored and locked box in the bathroom. All kitchen, food preparation, and storage areas are kept clean and free of rodents and other vermin. There are two carbon monoxide detectors in the home. The hot water temperature was tested and measured at 120 degrees. No more than 2 children share a bedroom. All beds are equipped with good springs and a clean mattress; and supplied with pillows which are clean and in good repair. Facility provides age-appropriate clothing items and hygiene products. Operations Licensee did not have a register of clients and the register at the time of this inspection. Licensee does not handle cash resources for clients.

LPA issued provided Advisory Notes- Technical Violations (LIC 9102-TVs). 80076(a)(5) food service: Licensee had a menu but it wasn't dated, and she didn't have the items that were listed to be served today available during this inspection. 80071(a) (1) Register of Clients: Licensee did not have a registerer of clients during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted and a signed copy of this report was provided to the facility along with LIC 811 (Confidential Name/s) list). Appeal rights explained.

On 10/19/21 at 8:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Belinda Gilmer conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility. LPA met with Licensee Marta Montiel the purpose of the inspection was to conduct a Annual Continuation. During this inspection, LPA reviewed one (1) staff file as there is only one staff working at this facility. Currently there are three (3) foster children and two (2) legal guardian in placement. This is a six (6) bedroom, three bathrooms one story single family home. During the inspection, LPA competed the operational requirements, interviewed (1) one staff that doesn't speak English using Interaction Voice Response Translator. Operations Licensee did not have a the clients register, clients ambulatory status not notes on the medical form, required forms wasn't complete, no record of cash resource weren't in the file at time of inspection, Licensee hasn't practice disaster drills and the emergency numbers including wasn't posted or located at the facility. Staffing: LPA Gilmer reviewed the one (1) staff personnel records. All individuals subject to criminal record review have been fingerprinted. There was no documentation in file of any training for staff. Children with Special Health Care Needs LPA reviewed the section of Children with Special Health Care Needs, no deficiencies were observed.

Client Records: LPA reviewed the clients records the following forms were either not in the files or weren't completed: the client's medical assessment, there was no psychotropic medication log, no verification of doctor's order and or medication as prescribed in according to doctor's orders. LPA issued deficiency citations and provided Advisory Notes- Technical Violations (LIC 9102-TVs). An exit interview was conducted and a signed copy of this report was provided along with LIC 811 (Confidential Name/s list). Appeal rights explained.

On December 12, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Claudia Portillo conducted an unannounced visit at the small family home (SFH) above for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection. LPA met with the licensee of the home, Marta Montiel. There are four foster children in care and one child under limited conservatorship. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: small family home grounds are free of observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space, including an outdoor patio. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors are in working order. Knives and sharps are locked in the garage. LPA observed the Children’s Personal Rights, license, and Emergency Plan LIC 610C posted in the facility. The medications are locked in the client's restroom and client’s files are locked inside a file cabinet located in the living room area. LPA obtained and reviewed the following updated documentation: · LIC 500 Personnel and client roster · Disaster Drills log · Plan of operation/Program Design The Small Family Home (SFH) program was in compliance with 2 applicable areas of the Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) Tools, for Children’s Residential licensees: physical plant and operations. LPA made recommendations to certain sections and will issue technical advisory's. LPA will conduct a case management at a later time to correct the capacity from three to six. Community care licensing (CCL) focuses its efforts on three priority areas: prevention, compliance, and enforcement. LPA will continue with the annual at a later date. A copy of this report was provided to the Administrator, Marta Montiel.

On 12/19/22, LPA Portillo met with the Administrator to obtain documentation on the capacity increase (from 3 to 6). Administrator provided copies of the following: Check for $25, letter to support change and LIC 200. LPA reviewed documentation for processing and will provide a copy of the license before 12/31/22.

On October 25, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Claudia Portillo conducted an unannounced visit at the small family home (SFH) above for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection. Only authorized representatives have access to the files and medications. LPA obtained and reviewed the following updated documentation: · LIC 500 Personnel and client roster · Disaster Drills log · Plan of operation/Program Design The Small Family Home (SFH) program was in compliance with 4 applicable areas of the Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) Tools, for Children’s Residential licensees: physical plant, operations, staff and client files. Community care licensing (CCL) focuses its efforts on three priority areas: prevention, compliance, and enforcement. LPA Portillo conducted one staff interview.

An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report was provided to the facility representative along with LIC 809, LIC 809D, LIC 811(Confidential Names) and 2 Technical Violations. Appeal rights explained . A copy of this report was provided to the Administrator, Marta Montiel.

On September 26, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Claudia Portillo conducted an unannounced visit at the small family home (SFH) above for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection. LPA met with the licensee of the home, Marta Montiel. There are two clients in care (1 minor and 1 non-minor dependents (NMD) in care. Community care licensing (CCL) focuses its efforts on three priority areas: prevention, compliance, and enforcement. LPA Portillo reviewed 2 staff and 2 client files. Clients are non-verbal.
