Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward visited the foster home to conduct the annual required inspection. The following was observed. This is a six bedroom, two bathroom home located in a residential area of the City of Compton. There is one foster care clients and four legal wards. All clients are non-verbal. Licensees also have current first aid/CPR training. They each have 3 hours of current caregiver training and are scheduled to enroll in more classes is September 2021 There are no bodies of water, no fireplaces and no fire arms in the home. All medications, knives and household cleaners are safely stored. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are working and properly placed. The yard area is free of visible safety hazards. Bedrooms #1, 2, and 3 have exit doors Bedrooms #4, 5, and 6 have working security bars. The security bar release in bedrooms #4 and #6 are blocked by furniture All bedrooms have adequate beds and storage space. Bathroom and kitchen equipment is in good working condition. There is ample food in the home. All adults in the home have the required Criminal Background Clearances. The licensees were cited under 80087(c) Buildings and Grounds, Furniture was blocking the security bar releases. However the deficiency was corrected prior to close of inspection, The licensees were also cited under 80068.3(a) Modifications to Needs and Services Plan; The Needs and Services Plan for one client was not current

Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward visited the Morales Small Family Home to conduct the Required 2 Year Inspection. The following was observed. This is a six bedroom, two bathroom home located in a residential area of the City of Compton. There is one foster care client and four legal wards. All clients are non-verbal. Licensees also have current first aid/CPR training. Both licensees have several hours of current foster parent training, There are no bodies of water, no fireplaces and no fire arms in the home. All medications, knives and household cleaners are safely stored. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are working and properly placed. There is a fully charged fire extinguisher. The yard area is free of visible safety hazards. The following were posted as required: License, Menu, Floor Plan and Notice of Personal Rights. Bedrooms #1, 2, and 3 have exit doors Bedrooms #4, 5, and 6 have working security bars on windows. The security bar releases are not blocked by furniture. All bedrooms have adequate beds with linens in good condition and the required storage space. Bedrooms were found to be at a comfortable temperature. The home has air conditioning and working wall heaters. Bathroom and kitchen equipment is in good working condition. Food supply exceeds the Title 22 requirements for fresh and non-perishable food. All adults in the home have the required Criminal Background Clearances. There were no deficiencies cited as a result of this inspection.

Licensing Program Analyst Reagan Cohen and Licensing Program Manager Lakescia Smith made an unannounced visit to the Morales Small Family Home for the purpose of a case management other visit. LPA and LPM attempted to conduct an annual required inspection, but the visit type is not available. Therefore LPA will return at a later date to conduct the annual required inspection. Currently there are no foster children in care and LPA and LPM verified legal guardianship of Child 1. LPA and LPM advise the caregiver to contact licensing if the wish to surrender their license. LPA and LPM discussed the facility personnel report summary dated 08/23/24, which shows two adult individuals without a complete clearance. LPA and LPM will verify in /guardian whether a clearance was completed and follow up with the caregivers. LPA and LPM advised caregiver of their outstanding fees. LPA and LPM provided PIN # to check and pay fees online. Per Mr. Morales they "never received a fee" or notice of payment due. Exit Interview completed.

facility_name: MORE THAN A HOUSE SMALL FAMILY HOME
narrative:

The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the pending Small Family Home application and Program Statement review. • Personal Hygiene Items • Personal Allowance/Paid Jobs • Medical/Dental • Record and Reporting FOLLOW – UP: A Pre-Licensing Inspection will be conducted on 06/04/2024 at 10:00 AM. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to the Applicant.

facility_name: MORE THAN A HOUSE SMALL FAMILY HOME
narrative:
On June 4, 2024, at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White arrived at More Than A House Small Family Home for the purpose of conducting a Pre-Licensing Inspection. LPA was met by Applicant, Carmyn Wyrick, who granted access to the home and together a tour of the interior and exterior home was conducted. Currently living in the home is the Applicant. The residence is set up as follows: This is a single-story 3-bedroom, 2 bathroom home located in a residential area. The home consists of a living room, dining area, Office area, kitchen, laundry room, backyard, and a detached garage. Living room: is equipped with a sectional sofa, mounted TV, mounted storage cabinet. Dining area: is equipped with a wooden table and eight (8) chairs. Office area: Desk, chair, computer, and locked storage cabinet for client and staff files. Kitchen: is equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, a five (5) burner gas stove/oven (all burners were operational at the time of this inspection), a microwave, and a pantry. Sharps and knives are kept in locked kitchen drawers. Cleaning supplies and laundry detergent are kept in a locked kitchen closet next to the refrigerator. Laundry room: is located off the kitchen and is equipped with a washer, dryer, and storage shelves. Backyard: is equipped with two (2) tuff shed used to store tools. Detached garage: LPA observed the garage to be used for extra storage. Bedroom #1: will be used as the client’s room. The room is equipped with a queen size bed, dresser, a mounted TV, a night stand, lamp, and has two (2) windows. The room contains a working ceiling light/fan and a closet. Report continued on LIC 809C. (Page 1 of 3)

Bedroom #2: will be used as the client’s room. The room is equipped with a queen size bed, two (2) dressers, a mounted TV, a nightstand, lamp, and has two (2) windows. The room contains a working ceiling light/fan and a closet. Bedroom #3: is occupied by the Applicant. The room is equipped a king size bed, a crib, two (2) dressers, two (2) nightstands, working lights, two (2) walk-in closets, and an en suite. Bathroom #1: is located along the hallway near bedroom #1. The bathroom is equipped with a toilet, a sink, and a combination shower/tub. Bathroom #2: is located inside bedroom #2. The bathroom is equipped with a toilet, double sinks, a stand-alone shower, a tub, and a two (2) windows. The hot water was tested and found to be with 105-120 degrees (F). LPA observed the home to have a fully charged fire extinguisher, a complete First Aid Kit, and a combination lock box to store refrigerated medications. The homes hallway cabinets store extra linen and hygiene products. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. Extra disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept locked… The home has a working telephone readily accessible to children in care. LPA observed the applicant to have a dog. LPA observed the applicant to have current up to date veterinarian record. LPA observed the home to be clean, safe, and sanitary. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps and open porches are unobstructed. The front and backyard were clean and free of debris. There are no bodies of water located on the premises. There are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the home. Vehicle: Applicant will transport children in 2022, BMW 750i. LPA observed the vehicle to have working seat belts, horn, and lights. Applicant has current registration through September 2024 and insurance with Progressive Express Insurance which expires on 09/17/2024. Report continued on LIC 809C. (Page 2 of 3)

LPA reminded Applicant to ensure the following when children are in placement: Children are accorded personal rights. Children are to be supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. LPA observed the Disaster Plan and Discipline policies posted… During the visit, LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports, Law Enforcement contacts, and to report all changes within the home to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. Applicant acknowledges abuse reporting requirements. Criminal Record Clearance Status: Per Guardian the Applicant is associated to the facility and listed as eligible. Prior to licensure the following is still required: Component III will be scheduled for June 12, 2024. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was left with the Applicant. (Page 3 of 3).

facility_name: MORE THAN A HOUSE SMALL FAMILY HOME
narrative: On June 12, 2024, 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White will submit the application for review and final approval of licensure. A Copy of this report was provided to the applicant.

narrative:

(Page 1 of 2)

Bedroom #3: is occupied by the licensee. The room is equipped a king size bed, a crib, two (2) dresser drawers, two (2) nightstands, working lights, and two (2) walk-in closets. Living room: is equipped with a sectional sofa, mounted TV, mounted storage cabinet. Dining area: is equipped with a wooden table and eight chairs. Office area: is equipped with a desk, chair, computer, and locked storage cabinet for client and staff files. Kitchen: is equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, a five-burner gas stove/oven (all burners were operational at the time of this inspection), a microwave, and a pantry. Sharps and knives are kept in locked kitchen drawers. Cleaning supplies and laundry detergent are kept in a locked kitchen closet next to the refrigerator. Laundry room: is located off the kitchen and is equipped with a washer, dryer, and storage shelves. Backyard: is equipped with two tuff sheds used to store tools. Detached garage: LPA observed the garage to be used for extra storage. Pg1

Bedroom 1: Vacant. The room is equipped with a queen size bed, dresser, a mounted TV, a nightstand, lamp, and has two windows. The room contains a working ceiling light/fan and a closet. Bedroom 2: Vacant. The room is equipped with a queen size bed, two dressers, a mounted TV, a nightstand, lamp, and has two windows. The room contains a working ceiling light/fan and a closet. Bedroom 3: is occupied by the Licensee. The room is equipped a king size bed, a crib, two dressers, two nightstands, working lights, two walk-in closets, and on-suite. Bathroom 1: is in the hallway. The bathroom is equipped with a toilet, a sink, and a combination shower/tub. Bathroom 2: is located inside bedroom 2. The bathroom is equipped with a toilet, double sinks, a stand-alone shower, a tub, and two windows. The hot water was tested and found to be with 105-120 degrees (F). LPA observed the home to have a fully charged fire extinguisher, a complete First Aid Kit, and a combination lock box to store refrigerated medications. The homes hallway cabinets store extra linen and hygiene products. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. The home has a working telephone readily accessible to children in care. The hot water was tested and found to be within a safe temperature. LPA observed the Licensee to have a dog with current veterinarian record. LPA observed the home to be clean, safe, and sanitary. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps, and open porches are unobstructed. The front and backyard were clean and free of debris. There are no bodies of water located on the premises. There are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the home. LPA reminded Licensee to ensure the following when children are in placement: Children are accorded personal rights. Children are to be supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. LPA observed the Disaster Plan and Discipline policies posted. Pg. 2

During the visit, LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports, Law Enforcement contacts, and to report all changes within the home to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. Criminal Record Clearance Status: Per Guardian the Licensee is associated to the facility and listed as eligible. There were no deficiencies at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to Carmyn Wyrick. Pg 3.

facility_name: MORE THAN A HOUSE SMALL FAMILY HOME
narrative:
On June 13, 2025 at 9:15am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Lanice White and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Kevin Sauk arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required Inspection. LPA and LPM met with Facility Administrator (FA), Carmyn Wyrick, who granted access into the home. A health and safety assessment was conducted. Currently residing in this home are the Facility Administrator (FA), client (C1), and two dogs. The home is located in a residential area and is set up as follows: This is a single-story three bedroom and two-bathroom home. The home also consists of a living room, dining area, office, kitchen, laundry room, backyard, and a detached garage. Living room: is equipped with a sectional sofa, mounted TV, mounted storage cabinet. Dining area: is equipped with a wooden table and five chairs. Office area: located in the living room, is equipped with a desk, chair, computer, and locked storage cabinet for client and staff files. Kitchen: is equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, a five-burner gas stove/oven (all burners were operational at the time of this inspection), a microwave, and a pantry. Sharps and knives are kept in locked kitchen drawers. Cleaning supplies and laundry detergent are kept in a locked kitchen closet next to the refrigerator. Laundry room: is located off the kitchen and is equipped with a washer, dryer, and storage shelves. Backyard: is equipped with two tuff sheds used to store tools. Detached garage: LPA observed the garage to be used for extra storage and home gym. (Continued on 809-C page 2)

Bedroom 1: Sleeps client (C1). The room is equipped with a queen size bed, dresser, a mounted TV, a nightstand, lamp, and has two windows. The room contains a working ceiling light/fan and a closet. Bedroom 2: Vacant. The room is equipped with two twin size beds, two dressers, a mounted TV, a nightstand, lamp, and has two windows. The room contains a working ceiling light/fan and a closet. Bedroom 3: is occupied by the Licensee. The room is equipped a king size bed, a crib, two dressers, two nightstands, working lights, two walk-in closets, and on-suite. The two dogs have received all required vaccinations and sleep in the living room or in Bedroom#3. Bathroom 1: is in the hallway. The bathroom is equipped with a toilet, a sink, and a combination shower/tub. Bathroom 2: is located inside bedroom 2. The bathroom is equipped with a toilet, double sinks, a stand-alone shower, a tub, and two windows. Cameras: Camera #1 is located near the front porch, #2 is in the driveway /East side of home, #3 back door, #4 back yard, #5 westside of home, #6 exterior front yard, #7 front door bell, #8 Living room, #9 Hallway, #10 dining room, #11 Work desk area, #12, Laundry area, and #13 kitchen area. LPA advised licensee that all cameras to mounted and fixed. LPA observed the home to have a fully charged fire extinguisher, a complete First Aid Kit, and a combination lock box to store refrigerated medications. The homes hallway cabinets store extra linen and hygiene products. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. The home has a working telephone readily accessible to children in care. The hot water was tested and found to be within a safe temperature. The hot water was tested and found to be with 100 degrees (F). LPA observed the home to be clean, safe, and sanitary. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps, and open porches are unobstructed. The front and backyard were clean and free of debris. There are no bodies of water located on the premises. There are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the home. (Continued on LIC809-C, page 3)

Client Records: LPA reviewed one client (C1) records for children Staff Records: LPA reviewed three staff (FA, S1, S2) records . LPA reviewed training LPA obtained the Facility Profile and Personnel Report and confirmed that the Licensee have required criminal record clearances. DOJ, FBI and Child Abuse Response, which meet qualification. Staff Interview: LPA conducted a confidential interview with staff (FA and S1). Client Interviews: One client (C1) interview was conducted. Two deficiencies were cited at the time of inspection. (See LIC809-D) LPA Lanice White and LPM Kevin Sauk concluded the Annual/Required Inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to the Facility Administrator (FA).

On March 8, 2023 at 9:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection of the home. LPA met and toured the home with Licensee, Kandra Moss. This Small Family Home (SFH) is a two story home located in a residential area. The home consists of 2 client bedrooms and 2 client bathrooms, living and dining areas, and kitchen. The home is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. All passageways are unobstructed and all doors open freely. There is no pool on the premises. Fire arms are not allowed on the home premises. At the time of visit, the following was observed: Fire extinguishers are throughout the house. Smoke detectors/carbon monoxide detectors are throughout the house and operational. Each bedroom has a bed, clean linens, and adequate drawer/cabinet space. First aid kit was observed. Hot water temperature measured at 105 degrees Fahrenheit. Staff and client records will be stored and locked on site. Medications will be centrally stored and locked on site. Disinfectants and other toxic materials will be locked in the garage. Extra bedding and towels are kept in the hallway cabinet. Knives and sharps will be kept locked in the kitchen. LPA will submit application to Licensing Program Manager (LPM) for approval. Component II: LPA Pavia discussed with the following, with Licensee: - home core services and support - home emergency intervention plan
Visit was attempted on 01/05/24 at 1:00 PM. LPA will return at a later date to conduct post licensing. See LIC 812 pertaining to attempted visit.

On 06/25/2024 at 10:31am, Licensing Program Analysts Kristin Pierotti and Jasmine Cardeno conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection at listed facility. LPA met with Kandra Moss, Licensee, and toured the facility inside and out. The Small Family Home is licensed to serve three clients. Present during the inspection were 1 staff and 0 clients. At 10:45am LPA Pierotti and Cardeno reviewed 1 client file and 4 staff files. At 11:02am, LPA Pierotti and Cardeno toured the facility. LPA Pierotti and Cardeno observed 4 bedrooms and 3 bathrooms. LPA's observed facility license, personal rights, facility sketch, meal menu, and other forms posted on the walls throughout the facility. LPA Pierotti tested the water temperature and found it to be 107.8 degrees which is in range. The thermostat read 73 which is within range. Chemicals were locked and safely stored. There were two days of perishable foods and seven days non-perishable foods present. The medication was also stored and locked in medical box in fridge. The facility is in good repair and clean. LPA Pierotti and Cardeno interviewed 1 staff and 0 clients because client was at school. At 11:30am LPA Pierotti and Cardeno toured the backyard. There were no open bodies of water. The backyard was in good repair and clean. At this time LPAs observed locks on the fridge and some food cabinets. LPAs instructed licensee to remove locks and contact client's physician to obtain records as to why the locks are necessary for the client's over-eating behaviors. Licensee will follow up with an email to request an exception for locks.

At this time LPAs observed an unlocked used injections container and had a conversation with licensee regarding proper storage. Licensee immediately placed the container in a locked cabinet. During a staff file review, prudent parenting training was missing. LPA will send training information to Licensee. At this time LPAs delivered two Technical Violations and one Technical Assistance. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Kandra Moss, Licensee.

On 04/17/25 at 10:25am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kristin Pierotti conducted a required annual inspection. LPA met with Kandra Moss, Licensee and informed of the purpose of the visit. The Small Family Home is licensed to provide care for 3 developmentally disabled clients, ambulatory only. LPA used the CARE Inspection Tool and conducted a tour of the facility site, review of 2 personnel records and 1 resident records, and confidential interviews with 1 staff member and 0 residents. LPA observed the facility to be in good condition, clean and well organized. Kitchen and bathrooms are sanitary. The facility currently has 1 resident and each resident has their own bedroom with individual beds and plenty of storage for personal items. The rooms and common spaces are nicely decorated and furnished. Medications, sharps, and chemicals are stored where inaccessible to the residents. LPA observed personnel and resident records to be complete and had all necessary documents. Staff have full background clearances and valid first aid training certifications. Residents' records contain current emergency contact information and complete care plans. Upon reviewing the residents' medication records, LPA observed that for the month of April there are not separate logs for each psychotropic medication. LPA observed there to be separate logs for months prior. LPA is providing technical assistance for Psychotropic Medication Administration Records.

Based on interviews, LPA observed staff to be knowledgeable of facility policies, mandated reporting, and client needs. No citations were issued at today's visit. One technical violation advisory was issued. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, and a copy of this report was left with Licensee, whose signature confirms receipt.

investigation_findings: 13On 04/23/25 at 11:35am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kristin Pierotti made an unannounced visit to the facility to deliver complaint investigation findings for the investigation of the above allegation(s). LPA met with Kandra Moss, Licensee and informed of the purpose of the visit. During the investigation, it was found that minors had been engaging in inappropriate interactions. Based on interviews, observations, and record review, it was found that staff did not prevent minors from engaging in inappropriate interactions. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation is found to be substantiated. This is a violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Section 80078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. LPA is issuing a citation. See attached LIC9099D page. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed and a copy of this report was left with Kandra Moss, Licensee whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

deficiencies.description: 80078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews, observations, and record review, it was found that staff did not prevent minors from engaging in inappropriate interactions which poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to persons in care
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee shall submit a written plan to ensure that each client is supervised appropriately based on the client’s needs. The plan will be emailed to LPA Pierotti by end of day 4/24/25 to kristin.pierotti@dss.ca.gov.

...CONTINUED Confidential interviews indicated that C1 was provided a facility phone upon request to make calls, which occurred regularly and was one of C1’s coping strategies during escalations. A confidential interview indicated that S1 would often refuse C2 the facility phone; however, there was no additional information to corroborate this assertion. CCL also received the allegation that the licensee (S1) and adults (S2) made inappropriate comments towards a minor (C1), and that the licensee (S1) mistreated a minor (C1) while in care. It was reported that C1’s caregivers called C1 a “devil,” and told C1 to “shut up,” that C1’s parent is mentally ill and does not want C1, that C1 does not act normal, and for C1 to “suck it up” while upset. It was also reported that C1’s caregivers interrupt C1 while C1 is trying to express themself, punish C1 for crying, and blames C1 for things they don’t do. A confidential interview indicated that S3 made fun of C1 for their weight and called C2 several hurtful names; however, no third-party witnesses to these incidents were named and C2 was unable to be interviewed on this allegation. Conflicting confidential interviews indicated that C1 had a close relationship with adults in the home and did not report any mistreatment to CSW or CASA while living in the home. Confidential interviews indicated that S1 raises their voice at clients for misbehaving; however, one of the interviews provided contradictory information and disclosed that S1 uses appropriate forms of punishment. CCL also received the allegation that the licensee (S1) did not prevent a minor (unnamed) from damaging another minor's (C1) personal belonging. It was reported that another client in the home stepped on and ruined C1’s family photos. A review of C1’s emails indicated that C1’s family photos were damaged by another client and that C1 was told to “suck it up” when complaining about it to their caregivers. A conflicting confidential interview indicated that it was S1 and S2 who stepped on and ripped C1’s photos, not another client; however, no third-party witnesses to this incident were named. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that the licensee denied communications for a minor, the licensee and adults make inappropriate comments towards a minor, the licensee is mistreating a minor while in care, and the licensee did not prevent a minor from damaging another minor's personal belonging are unsubstantiated. The allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted with Kandice Nelson, Licensee and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided.
investigation_findings: 13On April 23, 2025, at 6:20 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem met with Kandice Nelson, Licensee of Nelson Place to deliver the findings for the above-stated allegations. LPA Carol Anderson initiated a complaint inspection at the facility on 8/07/2024 at 2:46 PM and no immediate deficiencies were observed. During the investigation, LPA Salem interviewed Staff (S1 and S3), Clients (C1-C4), and a court appointed child advocate (CASA). Additionally, LPA Anderson interviewed a county social worker (CSW). Pertinent records were obtained and reviewed. On August 1, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that the licensee (S1) denied communications for a minor (C1). It was reported that C1’s electronic devices which allowed C1 to have regular communication with their parent were taken; howeve, the report received by CCL does not specify if the devices were taken before or after C1 entered S1’s care. A confidential interview indicated that C1 did not have a phone when entering S1’s home. CONTINUED...

narrative: ...CONTINUED A confidential interview indicated that cameras with audio recording were used upstairs, where C1’s bedroom was located, during the duration of C1’s stay in the facility. A conflicting confidential interview indicated that S1 disabled the audio in all facility cameras after receiving technical assistance from LPA Anderson prior to the above allegation being made, but that the upstairs cameras never recorded audio. Confidential interviews indicated that C1 never had cameras in their bedroom where C1’s private calls took place, and that S1 was unaware of what was said during the approved unsupervised calls C1 was having with their parent. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that staff do not accord children privacy while making phone calls is unsubstantiated. The allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted with Kandice Nelson, Licensee and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided.
investigation_findings: 13On April 23, 2025, 6:15, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem met with Kandice Nelson, Licensee of Nelson Place to deliver the finding for the above-stated allegation. LPA Carol Anderson initiated a complaint inspection at the facility on 8/28/2024 at 1:15 PM and no immediate deficiencies were observed. During the investigation, LPA Salem interviewed Staff (S1 and S2), Clients (C1-C4), and a court appointed child advocate (CASA). Pertinent records were obtained and reviewed. On August 23, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that staff (unnamed) did not accord children (C1) privacy while making phone calls. It was reported that there may have been cameras in the home that could hear C1 on the phone with their parents. A confidential interview indicated that C1 was not allowed to have private phone calls and had to be near facility staff while using the phone. Conflicting confidential interviews indicated that clients in care are allowed to make phone calls in private areas of the home, such as their bedrooms. CONTINUED...

narrative:
...CONTINUED A confidential interview indicated that S2 and S3 began attacking C1 for an unknown reason, including jumping on and punching C1, which lead to C1’s nose being broken. Conflicting confidential interviews and records reviewed indicated that C1 became escalated and attacked S2 after having their tablet taken away, leading to C1 being placed on a psychiatric hold at the hospital, and that C1 did not have injuries indicative of abuse. Records reviewed indicated that C1 has a history of unexpected violent behavior towards caregivers and staff. A confidential interview indicated that S1 threw a shoe at the head of another client in care, C4; however, conflicting information was gathered during this interview and the shoe throwing was disputed by a named witness. Confidential interviews indicated that other clients in care have not experienced physical abuse or been made to feel uncomfortable by S2 or S3. CCL also received the allegation that the licensee (S1) verbally abused a minor (C1) in care, the licensee (S1) threatened a minor (C1) in care, and the licensee (S1) discriminated against a minor (C1) in care. It was reported that S1 and other adults in the home verbally abused C1 with demeaning language related to weight, mental disabilities, ethnicity, and sexual orientation, as well as threatened harm. A confidential interview indicated that S3 made fun of C1 for their weight, ethnicity, and sexual orientation, and that S1 called C2 several hurtful names; however, no third-party witnesses to these incidents were named and C2 was unable to be interviewed on this allegation. Conflicting confidential interviews indicated that C1 had a close relationship with the adults in the home and did not report any mistreatment to their county social worker or CASA while living in the home. Confidential interviews indicated that although S1 utilized individualized interventions and care, S1 treated clients equally and upheld consistent rules. CCL also received the allegation that the licensee prevented minor from reporting incidents while in care and that the licensee (S1) retaliated against minor (C1) in care. It was reported that C1 alleged neglect and abuse by S1 and other adults in the home and, as a result, S1 took C1’s tablet away and was verbally abusive and threatening to C1. A confidential interview indicated that there were no disciplinary consequences, such as C1’s iPad being taken away, or other forms of retaliation due to C1 alleging neglect or abuse; however, the same interview indicated that C1 was not allowed to have private phone calls and had to be near facility staff while using the phone. Conflicting confidential interviews indicated that clients in care were allowed to make phone calls in private areas of the home, such as their bedrooms. CONTINUED...

...CONTINUED A confidential interview indicated that S1 would often refuse C2 the facility phone; however, there was no additional information gathered to corroborate this assertion. CCL also received the allegation that the licensee (S1) did not seek medical attention for a minor (C1) in care as necessary, and that the licensee (S1) did not ensure that a minor (C1) received necessary services while in care. It was reported that C1 was not being properly treated for an ongoing medical condition while living with S1, as well as not receiving needed mental health services or school accommodations. A confidential interview and records reviewed indicated that C1 required daily medication and at one point while living with S1 needed an appointment with a specialist. Confidential interviews indicated that S1 took C1 to their required medical appointments and provided C1 with their medication daily. A confidential interview indicated that S1 would sometimes forget to provide C1 with their medication, and that C1 would have to remind S1; however, no corroborating information for this assertion was gathered. Confidential interviews and records reviewed indicated that C1 was also diagnosed with mental health conditions requiring treatment and therapy. Confidential interviews and records reviewed indicated that while living with S1, C1 received wraparound mental health services that carried over from their previous placement, and that once the services ended S1 submitted referrals at various locations for C1 to remain in therapy and receive services. Confidential interviews indicated that there was a gap in services during this time, but that C1 was still receiving mental health services through their individualized education plan. CCL also received the allegation that the licensee (S1) leaves minor(s) in care unsupervised and that an uncleared adult had access to minor(s) in care. It was reported that C1 did not receive adequate supervision and was left unattended with adults who were unauthorized to be supervising C1, including S1’s spouse. A confidential interview indicated that C1 was regularly left alone at S1’s home without adults, as well as left alone with S1’s family members. Confidential interviews and records reviewed indicated that some of S1’s family members assisted in supervising and caring for C1, and that everyone who lived in the facility had criminal records clearance, including S1’s spouse. A confidential interview indicated that C1 was left alone twice with another relative of S1 without criminal background clearance. Conflicting confidential interviews indicated that C1 was not supervised by any of S1’s relatives without criminal background clearance. CONTINUED...

...CONTINUED CCL also received the allegation that the licensee’s (S1) conduct posed a risk to minor(s) (C1) in care. It was reported that S1 took C1 on an unnecessary trip out of state despite C1 being medically fragile. Confidential interviews and records reviewed indicated that C1 was not considered medically fragile while living with S1. A confidential interview indicated that while travelling C1 felt healthy and was provided with their normal medication. It was also reported that another client in the home was allowed to provide illicit drugs to C1; however, C2 was unable to be interviewed on this allegation and no corroborating information was gathered during the investigation. A confidential interview indicated that S1 and other adults in the home did not strive to keep C1 safe; however, no further details were provided. Conflicting confidential interviews indicated that S1 and other adults in the home work to keep clients in care safe and protect their personal rights. Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, the allegations that the licensee physically abused a minor in care, causing injury, the licensee did not prevent other adults in the home from physically abusing a minor in care, causing injury, the licensee verbally abused a minor in care, the licensee threatened a minor in care, the licensee retaliated against a minor in care, the licensee did not seek medical attention for a minor in care as necessary, the licensee discriminated against a minor in care, the licensee prevented a minor from reporting incidents while in care, the licensee did not ensure that a minor received necessary services while in care, the licensee left minor(s) in care unsupervised, the licensee’s conduct posed a risk to minor(s) in care, and that an uncleared adult had access to minor(s) in care may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted with Kandice Nelson, Licensee and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided.
investigation_findings: 13On May 8, 2025, at 1:55 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem met with Kandice Nelson, Licensee of Nelson Place to deliver the finding for the above-stated allegations. The investigation was conducted by Special Investigator (SI) Ernestina Bellucco, who interviewed Clients (C1-C3), Staff (S1-S3), and staff from another group home (S4 and S5). Additionally, LPA Salem interviewed Clients (C1, C3, and C4), Staff (S1 and S3), and a Court Appointed Child Advocate (CASA). LPA Salem attempted to interview C5 but was unable due to C5 declining. Pertinent records were obtained and reviewed. On August 30, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that the licensee (S1) physically abused a minor (C1) in care, causing injury, and that the licensee (S1) did not prevent other adults (S2 and S3) in the home from physically abusing a minor (C1) in care, causing injury. It was reported that S1-S3 attacked C1 while C1 was doing homework, which led to C1 being injured and having to go to the hospital. CONTINUED...

narrative: ...CONTINUED A confidential interview indicated that C2 non-consensually touched C1 in a private area while adults in the home were not supervising; however, in a separate interview with county investigators, the same interviewee stated that no inappropriate touching had occurred. Confidential interviews and records reviewed indicated that S1 enforced house rules and took other supervision measures to prevent inappropriate interactions involving C1 and to ensure safety of clients in care due to C1’s history of sexualized behaviors and fixating on foster siblings of the opposite sex. Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, the allegation that the licensee did not prevent inappropriate sexual interactions between minors is unsubstantiated. The allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted with Kandice Nelson, Licensee and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided.
investigation_findings: 13On June 5, 2025, at 5:45 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem met with Kandice Nelson, Licensee of Nelson Place to deliver the finding for the above-stated allegation. LPA Carol Anderson initiated a complaint inspection at the facility on 10/22/2024 at 1:30 PM and no immediate deficiencies were observed. During the investigation, LPA Anderson interviewed Client (C1) and Staff (S1), and LPA Salem interviewed Staff (S1 and S2) and Clients (C3-C5). LPA attempted to interview Client (C2) but was unable due to C2 declining. Pertinent records were obtained and reviewed. On October 15, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that the licensee (S1) did not prevent inappropriate sexual interactions between minors (C1, C2, C3, and/or C4). It was reported that C1’s foster sibling (C3 or C4) non-consensually touched C1’s private parts. CONTINUED...

narrative:
On January 9, 2025, at 12:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem met with Danielle Nelson, Designee, for the purpose of conducting a pre-licensing inspection for a Small Family Home. Applicant Kandice Nelson is applying for a license for six ambulatory clients. The home is a two story residence located on a residential street. LPA and Applicant Nelson toured the home inside and out. The home is currently empty and unfurnished due to the the applicant's current facility still utilizing the furniture and other supplies. LPA observed the applicant's current facility to be in compliance and contain all the necessary provisions, such as bedding and storage closet for files and medications, and Applicant Nelson stated that all furniture and equipment currently in use will be brought to the new home upon relocating with the clients in care. The current home contains a kitchen, two living rooms, garage, backyard, and will have a storage closet where client files will be stored. The license, LIC 610C, and Personal rights will be posted in the front hallway upon the applicant and clients relocating to the home. The upstairs bedrooms will be set up as follows: - Bedroom 1: sleeping two clients - Bedroom 2: sleeping one client - Bedroom 3: sleeping one client - Bedroom 4: sleeping one client - Bedroom 5: sleeping one client - Bedroom 6: applicant's master bedroom The client bedrooms have ample lighting and are in good repair with adequate storage space for clothing and personal belongings. The applicant has a working and recently inspected fire extinguisher, and complete first-aid kit and manual. The kitchen contains working and clean appliances for food preparation, storage, and cleaning. CONTINUED...

...CONTINUED There were no safety or health hazards observed during the walk though of the home and property. There is a central heating/air conditioning unit in the home located upstairs and additional A/C units downstairs to keep the home at a comfortable temperature. Client bathrooms are clean and appliances are in working order. Windows and screens were inspected and are in good repair. The following deficiencies were observed: 1. Hot water temperature controls in client bathrooms does not automatically regulate water temperature between 105 degrees and 120 degrees, and there are no warning signs for hot water. The request for a license will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager Dawn Segura for final approval once the deficiency is cleared. Due to printer malfunction, an exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to Danielle Nelson, Designee.

On March 28, 2025, at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem conducted an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of conducting an post-licensing inspection and met with Kandice Nelson, Licensee. LPA reviewed three client files (C1-C3), which are kept locked in the licensee's office. The client files reviewed contain required information, such as placement agreements, health and immunization records, and authorized representative information. LPA reviewed staff files (S1-S3), which contain the required background clearance documentation, demographic information, and health screenings. LPA conducted two staff interviews. LPA inspected the facility’s physical plant, including personal rights postings, health related services, buildings and grounds, food services, telephones, indoor and outdoor activity space, and furniture, fixtures, equipment and supplies. The home is clean, in good repair, and free from observable risks to clients' health, safety, and personal rights. The home is a two story building with three client bedrooms in use and two client bathrooms which are set up as follows: Bedroom #1 has one twin bed and sleep one client, bedroom #2 has one twin bed and sleeps one client, bedroom #3 has one twin bed and sleeps one client, and master bedroom used by the licensee and spouse. There is a kitchen and living room, multiple family room areas, upstairs office and storage closets, and backyard/patio. Due to time constraints, the annual is being extended to conduct client interviews. An exit interview was conducted and a signed copy of this report was provided to Kandice Nelson, Licensee.

On June 3, 2025 at 9:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adaleyci Caballero met with Applicant Shemeen Lewis for a Component II of the application process. LPA A. Caballero went over revisions needed for the application prior to license and are due no later than July, 3, 2025. LPA A. Caballero provided applicant with a copy of the LIC 184, Notice of Incomplete Application and additional correspondence to assist with the revisions needed to the application. A copy of this report was provided to applicant via email. The original signed copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

On June 16, 2025, at 9:40AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adaleyci Caballero completed a pre-licensing inspection of New Journey Small Family Home (SFH). LPA met with Applicant Shemeen Lewis who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. There are no clients in placement. The home is a two-story building with five bedrooms and three full bathrooms which are set up as follows: Bedroom #1- It consisted of one queen bed. The bed had linen, comforters, and pillows. It will sleep applicant. Bedroom #2- It consisted of one single bed. The bed had linen, comforters, and pillows. It will sleep one client. Bedroom #3- It consisted of two single beds. The beds had linen, comforters, and pillows. It will sleep two clients. Bedroom #4- Not furnished. It will be utilized for guests. Bedroom #5(first floor)- It will be utilized as an office. A living room, kitchen, dining area, loft, laundry room, two car garage, and a backyard. The garage will be utilized for storage.

The clients' bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two clients will be in a room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the clients' belongings. There was a smoke detector in every bedroom. The eight smoke detectors were checked and working properly. The Carbon Monoxide detector was located in the loft area. The home’s central air conditioning module was in the backyard. The water heater was in the garage. The appliances were in working order. The clients' and staff files were locked inside a filing cabinet in the office. Medications will be locked in a lock box in a kitchen cabinet. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of perishable food and non-perishable food. The home had a trash can for storage of solid waste inside a sliding cabinet. The hot water was at a temperature of 115.3 degrees Fahrenheit. There was one fire extinguisher present in the home located in the foyer. It was observed to be properly charged and inspected by the fire department. The First Aid Kit was located in the office accessible to clients in care. There are no firearms in the home. There is no pool in the home. The backyard is fully fenced and free of debris. The home has two cameras on the outside premise of the home. Emergency Disaster Plan (LIC 610), Personal Rights, Grievance procedures, and Visitation Policies were posted in the garage accessible to the public. Corrections: Camera Usage added to Program Statement per (PIN 24-09-CRP) All chemicals, sharps, and cleaning solutions must be locked and inaccessible to clients in care. Component III was conducted. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to applicant Sheemen Lewis via email. The application will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager Abdoulaye Traore once corrections are submitted to LPA.

On 8/21/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kristin Pierotti and LPA Mariah Hawkins conducted a post-licensing inspection. LPAs met with Licensee Betheny Jordan and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPAs used the CARE Inspection Tool to complete this inspection. LPAs toured the facility site and inspected facility records. One resident interview was conducted. LPAs observed the facility to be maintained in safe condition, kitchen and bathrooms were in sanitary condition, resident bedrooms were furnished and offered clean linens and plenty of storage space, and potentially dangerous items, including chemicals, knives, and medications, were stored where inaccessible to the resident in care. LPAs observed some food cabinets in the kitchen are locked for client's safety as recommended by the client's physician. LPAs advised that an exception request must be made for having locks. LPA came to know through talking with Licensee that they assist the client with their injection medication. LPA advised that Licensee speak with pharmacist to ensure proper administration of the medication and requested the training details of the Medication Education training that both Licensee and licensee's husband have obtained. LPAs observed staff and client files to be complete. LPAs observed that there is no record of psychotropic medication administration. LPA is issuing a Type B citation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 4, Article 6, Section 83070(b), which specifies the requirement to log administration of psychotropic medication. See LIC 809-D attached. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, and a copy of this report was left with Licensee.

On May 15, 2024 at 10:40 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield and LPA Celeste Aparicio conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection of the home. LPA 's met and toured the home with Licensee, Betheny Jordan. This Small Family Home (SFH) is a two story home located in a residential area. The home consists of 3 client bedrooms and 1.5 client bathrooms, living and dining areas, and kitchen. The home is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. All passageways are unobstructed and all doors open freely. There is no pool on the premises. Fire arms, are not allowed on the home premises. At the time of visit, the following was observed and the care tool was used: Fire extinguishers is located in the kitchen. Smoke detectors/carbon monoxide detectors are throughout the house and operational. Each bedroom has a bed, clean linens, and adequate drawer/cabinet space. First aid kit was not observed during this inspection. Hot water temperature was within the required range per regulations. Staff and client records will be stored and locked on site. Medications will be centrally stored and locked on site. Disinfectants and other toxic materials will be locked in cabinet in the kitchen, Extra bedding and towels are kept in the hallway cabinet. Knives and sharps will be kept locked in a cabinet in the kitchen. By the end of business today 5/15/2024 at 5PM, licensee agrees to submit proof of purchased first aid kit. There were no citations issued during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with licensee Betheny Jordan.

On 05/05/2025 at 11:15am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kristin Pierotti made an unannounced visit to the facility to conduct the Annual Inspection. LPA met with Betheny Jordan, Licensee and explained the purpose of the visit. LPA was unable to conduct the inspection at this time due technical issues. LPA will return to complete the inspection at a later date. There are no deficiencies at this time. A copy of this report was left with Betheny Jordan, Licensee, whose signature confirms.

On 05/19/2025 at 10:45am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kristin Pierotti conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility. The purpose of the visit was to print the facility's updated license. LPA met with Betheny Jordan and explained the purpose of the visit. During the inspection, there were 2 staff present and 1 client. Client was participating in online school while LPA was present. LPA observed the facility to be in good condition, clean and well organized. Kitchen and bathrooms are sanitary. The facility currently has 1 residents and each resident has their own bedroom with individual beds and plenty of storage for personal items. The rooms and common spaces are nicely decorated and furnished. Medications, sharps, and chemicals are stored where inaccessible to the residents. No deficiencies were found at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and the updated Facility License was left with Betheny Jordan, Licensee whose signature confirms receipt.

On 07/01/25 at 9:45am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kristin Pierotti conducted a random annual inspection. LPA met with Betheny Jordan, Licensee and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA used the CARE Inspection Tool and conducted a tour of the facility site, review of 5 personnel records and 1 resident record, and confidential interviews with 1 staff member and no residents. The resident was not present at the time of inspection. LPA observed the facility to be in good condition, clean and well organized. Kitchen and bathrooms are sanitary. The facility currently has 1 resident and who has their own bedroom with an individual bed and plenty of storage for personal items. The rooms and common spaces are nicely decorated and furnished. Medications, sharps, and chemicals are stored where inaccessible to the residents. LPA observed personnel and resident records to be complete and had all necessary documents. Staff have full background clearances and first aid training certifications. Residents' records contain current emergency contact information. The resident in care is an emergency placement and has not been in the facility long enough to have a completed medical assessment or Needs and Services Plan. Based on interviews, LPA observed staff to be knowledgeable of facility policies, mandated reporting, and client needs. No deficiencies were observed at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with Licensee whose signature confirms receipt.

On May 1, 2024, at 1:40 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karen Beal began an inspection for a Small Family Home license. LPA met with applicant Nichole Wilson who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicants. Applicants are applying for a capacity of 2 ambulatory children and the house is a 5-bedroom two-story house: Downstairs: It consists of a kitchen; a closet, bathroom #1; a pantry; a large dining table; a living room; family room and the garage. Upstairs: Bedroom #2- Applicant's Bedroom Bedroom #3- foster children's room- two twin beds Bedroom #4 foster children's room- two twin beds Bedroom #5 Bio daughter room Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. Outside the bedrooms, there is a laundry room, The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and are working properly. All hazardous items will be stored upstairs in the laundry room and have been properly made inaccessible, children will not have access. Medication lockbox were locked and stored in downstair closet. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored downstairs in a locked box in the pantry. First Aid kit was accessible with all required items. A Fire extinguisher was observed and properly charged. There were no guns or weapons as stated by Nichole Wilson. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 111 degrees. Applicants understand that the water temperature must be maintained within the regulation range of 105-120 degrees. Proper storage of all food was noted. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids.

****Continued from LIC 809**** The Emergency Disaster Plan with exit map, Title 22 Personal Rights, and visitation policies were posted at this time. The home have a telephone service at this time. The backyard where children will have access to play is completely fenced and free of hazards. There is no pool or other body of water. Component III orientation was conducted by LPA Beal. Based on this inspection, the home is appropriate for a capacity of 4 ambulatory children. The request of License will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to Nichole Wilson, applicant.

On October 31, 2024, at 1:40 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karen Beal began a post licensing inspection for Nikki's Angels Small Family Home . LPA met with applicant Nichole Wilson who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicants. Applicants are applying for a capacity of 4 ambulatory children and the house is a 5 bedroom two-story house: Downstairs: It consists of a kitchen; a closet, a bathroom, a pantry, dining room, living room; family room and the garage. Bedroom #1- it is vacant and it is located downstairs Upstairs: Bedroom #2- licensee's Bedroom Bedroom #3- foster children's room FC1 and FC2- two twin beds Bedroom #4 foster children's room FC3 and FC4- two twin beds Bedroom #5 Bio daughter room Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. Outside the bedrooms, there is a laundry room. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and are working properly. All hazardous items will be stored upstairs in the laundry room and have been properly made inaccessible, children will not have access. Medication lockbox were locked and stored in downstair closet. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored downstairs in a locked box in the pantry. First Aid kit expires on 02/2026 on was accessible with all required items and is located in the washroom. A Fire extinguisher was observed and properly charged. They are located in the kitchen and in the upstairs hallway. There were no guns or weapons as stated by licensee. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 118 degrees. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. ***Continued to LIC 809-C***

***Continued from LIC 809*** The Emergency Disaster Plan with exit map, Personal Rights, client list, License, and visitation policies were posted at this time. The home have a telephone service at this time. The backyard where children will have access to play is completely fenced and free of hazards. There is no pool or other body of water. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to Nichole Wilson, licensee.

****Continued from LIC 9099**** . During investigation, a confidential interview denied the FP threatened to spank the children in care. Another confidential interview stated that the LIC would threaten to spank FC3 and FC4 when they did not do their chores. A confidential interview stated the LIC would call FC1 and FC2 “stupid and a whore”. However, another confidential interview stated the words “stupid or whore” were never used at the SFH. LPA received a conflicting information. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations the FP threatened to spank FC3 and FC4 and FPinappropriately to FC1 and FC2 may have happened or be valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to the Licensee, Nicole Wilson.
investigation_findings: 13On January 7, 2025 at 1:08 PM, Licensing Program Analyst(LPA) Karen Beal met with Licensee Nichole Wilson to deliver the investigative finding for the above-stated allegations. On October 31, 2024, at 12:31 PM, LPA initiated the investigation at Nikki’s Angels Small Family Home (SFH) and obtained pertinent documents from the facility files. LPA interviewed the foster parent (FP) and foster child 1 (FC1), foster child 2 (FC2), foster child 3 (FC3), attempted to interview foster child 4 (FC4) but was unable to due to FC4 limited ability to communicate. In addition, LPA interviewed the County Social Workers (CSW). On October 28, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint that foster parent threaten minor with physical harm and foster parent spoke inappropriately to minor in care. Specifically, it was alleged the Licensee (LIC) threatened to spank foster children and the LIC used inappropriate language towards FC1 and FC2. ****Continued on LIC 9099-C****

narrative: On Monday February 26, 2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes met with Applicant Kezia Houzell via Microsoft Teams to complete a component II interview. LPA discussed applicants fingerprints. A signed copy of this form will be placed in applicants file.

On April 12, 2024 at 12:50 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes completed a pre-licensing inspection of Nirvana Small Family Home. LPA met with Applicant Kezia Houzell who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Currently there are no clients in placement. The home is a two story building with four bedrooms and three bathrooms which are set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 (Applicants) has one bed will sleep the applicant. · Bedroom #2 (Client’s) has two bed, it will sleep two client’s. · Bedroom #3 (Client’s) has two bed, it will sleep two client’s. · Bedroom #4 (Client’s) has two bed’s, it will sleep two client’s. · A great room/living room, kitchen, dining area, three bathrooms, laundry room, a loft/office, three car garage and the backyard. The Client’s bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two client’s will be in a room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the client’s belongings. There was a smoke detector/carbon monoxide detector in every bedroom. The seven smoke detectors/carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. The home is equipped with a fire sprinkler system. The home’s central air conditioning module was located in the back yard. The home’s tank less hot water heater was located the garage. The appliances were in working order. The client’s files will be locked inside a filing cabinet in the office. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable foods. A trash can for storage of solid waste had a tight-fitting lid and was present. The sharp knives will be in a locked drawer in the kitchen. The medications will be located in a locked cabinet the applicants bathroom.

The hot water in bathroom one measured to be 109.7 degrees Fahrenheit, bathroom two was 117.5 degrees Fahrenheit, and in bathroom three 115.4 degrees Fahrenheit. The home’s First Aid kit was accessible and is located in the kitchen and contained all required supplies. There are two fire extinguisher present in the home one is located in the kitchen by the kitchen cabinets and the second is located in the upstairs laundry room. They were observed to be properly charged and inspected by the fire department. Licensee stated there were no weapons/firearms in the home. There is no pool or other body of water at the home. The backyard where clients will have access to play is fenced. There are no corrections that need to be made at this time A Component III was completed. An exit interview was conducted. Application will be forwarded to the Licensing Program Manager for Licensing.

On August 10, 2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie, met with applicant Mercedes Noble this date for a Component II. LPA went over revisions needed for the application prior to licensure. LPA gave a copy of the LIC 184, Notice of Incomplete Application, and additional correspondence to assist with the revisions needed for the application. On November 29, 2023 at 10:08 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie began a Pre-Licensing inspection for a Small Family Home license. On May 29, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at Noble Small Family Home (SFH) pre-licensing inspection for a relocation. Currently, there are two clients who are under legal guardianship with the licensee, and the home is licensed for a capacity of four clients (one non-ambulatory and three ambulatory clients). The Facility was toured both inside and out with the licensee. The home is a two-story building with five bedrooms and three bathrooms. During the inspection, LPA observed that the downstairs consisted of the kitchen, a den, a living room, a dining area with a large table and one bedroom. Bedroom #1 was vacant, and it consisted of a full-size bed, it will sleep one non-ambulatory client, it has an exit door to the outside. The medications will be stored and locked in a metal storage safe located in the bedroom #1. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in under the kitchen sink. The First Aid Kit was in the downstairs closet and contained all required items. The garage was inspected and used for cars. The water temperature was tested and measured at 110 degrees F. LPA observed a minimum of seven-day non-perishable and a three-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients. In addition to the downstairs space, there was also one full bathroom fully functioning and hallway closets used for storage. A trash can was observed to have tight fitting cover. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: personal rights, visitation policy, and current menu. The clients’ medication log records were kept updated with no discrepancy. Eight fire extinguishers were observed and operable. The downstairs consisted of a laundry room that always remained locked.

The upstairs was a master bedroom #2 for licensee and spouse and it consisted of a king size bed and a bathroom; The licensee’s bedroom is not accessible for the clients; bedroom #3 was fully furnished with a queen size bed, a closet and plenty of storage space. It will sleep one client, it was vacant. Bedroom #4 sleeps a seventeen-year-old male client and a twelve-year-old both under legal guardianship and was fully furnished with two twin beds, a closet, storage space. All bedrooms were arranged for one child per bed. No room was commonly used for other purposes other than a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawer and closet space for each child’s belongings. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and working. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the laundry room. The upstairs space includes an additional bathroom used for the clients. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients have access. All windows and screens were in good repair. There were no guns or weapons in the home as stated by Licensee. There was a total of five cameras, all located outdoor which meet the title 22 camera policy. The facility outside grounds were also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. Clients’ files and staff files were reviewed and found to comply. Based on today's inspection and observations, there are no deficiencies being cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to Licensee.

Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with Mrs. Becky Norris to commence the annual Inspection. However since the children in the home were recently exposed at Sierre Madre Jr. High and the home is under quarantine, the visit was abbreviated. There are currently no children under foster placement. There are two children under adoptive placement. There are no bodies of water and no fire arms in the home. There are no security bars on windows. Smoke alarms and carbon monoxide detectors are working. There is an alarm system serviced by POST. The home is currently under remodeling, due to be completed in early October. Inspection will be continued at that time

Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward arrived at the facility at 11:00 AM to check on the progress of the home renovations. Ms. Norris was not at home so LPA reached her by telephone. Ms. Norris stated that the completion of her renovations were delayed by 14 days because after her children had been quarantined due to COVID exposure, the workmen would not resume work until the children were cleared. Ms Norris stated that she did approach the City of Pasadena to inquire if she needed any permits and she was told that she did not because the work being done to her home is solely cosmetic not structural. The only things being changed are paint and plaster. Ms. Norris stated that the children are protected from the renovation materials. Their room is not being worked on and they are not allowed into the areas that are receiving work. She also said that when the workmen leave for the day, they take their materials and equipment with them. The inspection will be continued once renovations are complete.

Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with licensee Becky Norris to complete the annual inspection. There are currently no children under foster placement. There are two children under adoptive placement. There are three bedrooms and two bathrooms. Bedroom #1 is occupied by the licensee and her spouse Bedroom #2 is occupied by Child #1 and #2. It has two twin beds with all the required linens. Bedroom #3 is currently unoccupied. The home is currently under renovation which has been prolonged due to licensee not being able to obtain needed materials because of the national supply chain crisis. Per licensee, all building materials are put away when the workmen leave in the evenings. Therefore they are not accessible to clients. There are no bodies of water and no fire arms in the home. There are no security bars on windows. Smoke alarms and carbon monoxide detectors are working. There is an alarm system serviced by POST. LPA tested the water temperature and had the licensee lower it to between 105 and 120 degrees. LPA observed a full first aid kit. Licensee records were reviewed. Licensee has current caregiver training. Licensee is unable to locate her First Aid/CPR cards but will email them to the Department within 24 hours. There were no deficiencies found as a result of this inspection
