The licensee stated that there weren't any firearms or other weapons on the premises. Smoke alarms were operable throughout the facility. There is adequate space for indoor and outdoor activities. The outdoor areas were observed to be free of debris and hazards. LPA reviewed files and found the files to be in order. LPA found no Title 22/ILS violations on this date. Exit interview done LPA discussed the warm weather conditions and precautions with licensee and provided licensee with the department's website address (www.ccld.ca.gov).

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Caitlin Chambers, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Juliet Robles, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Yan Yeung, went to the Olaw Small Family Home on 3/21/25 at 8:45am for the purposes of a annual inspection. LPA met with Leah Wilson, licensee, and conducted a comprehensive inspection at the facility.. The facility is located inside a residential complex setting along with other townhouses. The facility has three bedrooms, four bathrooms, kitchen, living room, and a garage. The licensee resides here with her son, and one client, C1 (See 811). LPAs, LPM, and the licensee toured the facility with the licensee. There are cameras that are unplugged as of 3.21.25. During the inspection, LPA observed three level townhouse in a gated community with three bedrooms in the facility. Bedroom #1 has one full bed, a white dresser with clothes in it and closet space with clothes in it. The bedroom was occupied by client #1 (refer to LIC811 dated 3.21.25). Bedroom #2 has one toddler bed, dresser, and closet space. The bedroom is occupied by the licensee's biological son (see LIC811). Bedroom #3 has one queen bed, dresser, and closet space. The bedroom was occupied by the licensee. There was adequate space in the living room and dining area. LPA observed a fire extinguisher in the kitchen area. The temperature of sinks and showers is above 125 degrees Fahrenheit. There are two dogs in the home that are kept away from client when the client is home. The garage is always locked. In the garage there are chemicals and supplies not locked up. The temperature of the home was 74 degrees Fahrenheit.

The licensee stated that there were no firearms or ammunition on the premises. LPAs observed smoke alarms were operable throughout the facility. There is adequate space for indoor and outdoor activities. The outdoor areas were observed to be free of debris and hazards. The kitchen has a menu on the fridge with food that matches the menu. A medication check was done. LPA observed that the staff was cleared in fingerprints in the system. The car registration and insurance is current. LPA reviewed one staff file and one client file. LPA Robles interview the licensee. There is a pool on premise that is gated with a metal fence at least five feet tall about three minutes away from the townhouse. LPA requested an addendum for the cameras in the home. LPA issued the following citations one technical violation, one Type A violation for and four Type B violations. Exit interview was completed. A copy of the LIC 809, LIC 809 D, and an LIC 811 was given to the licensee, appeal rights were reviewed,

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Caitlin Chambers conducted an inspection visit to the facility to follow up on a Plan of Corrections (POC) for a citation given 03.21.25 under Title 22 Regulations with a POC of 4.01.25, for the following: Hot water temperature controls shall be maintained to automatically regulate temperature of hot water delivered to plumbing fixtures used by clients to attain a hot water temperature of not less than 105 degrees F (40.5 degrees C) and not more than 120 degrees Fahrenheit (48.8 degrees C). In the facility on 03.21.25 the downstairs sink, in the clients (C1) room was 113 degrees Fahrenheit, the shower in the clients room was 126.1 degrees Fahrenheit, the sink in the kitchen upstairs was 120.1 degrees Fahrenheit, and sink in the bathroom on the second floor was 123.7 degrees Fahrenheit. On the annual inspection on 03.21.25, the temperature was too high out of range and did not meet the regulation 80088(e)(1). Today on 04.01.25, the temperature in the sink downstairs in the client’s room read 118.5 degrees Fahrenheit, and the shower downstairs in the client’s (C1) shower read 120.1 degrees Fahrenheit, the sink in the kitchen read 122.9 degrees Fahrenheit, and the sink in the bathroom on the second floor read 121.6 degrees Fahrenheit. Based on LPA's observation using a temperature tool, the licensee did not comply with the section cited above in each of the sinks and showers that are accessible to the client that is above 125 degrees F which poses an immediate health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.

This report was given to the Licensee as a not cleared Plan of Correction. A civil penalty was given of $100 per day for a total of $1100 as a result to the non- compliance of the first Type A citation given on 3.21.25 with a due date of 3.22.25 (the start date of the penalty)- 4.01.25 Appeals rights were reviewed. An exit interview was conducted.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Caitlin Chambers conducted a Plan of Correction inspection on 4.7.25 and met with Administrator, Leah Wilson. A 421FC was given to licensee on 4/1/2025. The assessment dates should be from 3/23/25 to 4/1/25 for a total of $1,000 instead of $1,100. This report supersedes the amount on the form given on 4/1/2025. LPA Chambers toured the facility and checked water temperatures at the facility. LPA observed previous deficiencies and cleared all deficiencies that was cited on 3/21/2025. On today’s visit the temperature in the sink downstairs in the client’s room read 107.7 degrees Fahrenheit, and the shower downstairs in the client’s (C1) shower read 107.7 degrees Fahrenheit, the sink in the kitchen read 107.7 degrees Fahrenheit, and the sink in the bathroom on the second floor read 107.3 degrees Fahrenheit. LPA observed and cleared all deficiencies that was cited on 3/21/2025 which included all four Type B violations and all technical violations were cleared during this POC visit and the letters of the POC were given to the licensee. This 809 report was given to the licensee, a plan of corrections letter, and a new-revised LIC 421FC form with the new amount of $1000 as indicated on this report . Appeals rights were reviewed on page two. An exit interview was conducted.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Caitlin Chambers conducted a case management inspection at the facility to follow up the addendum submitted from the licensee regarding the use of video camera. LPA met with Administrator, Leah Wilson for the purpose gathering information regarding the camera addendum submitted on 05.29.25. LPA reviewed the Camera Provider Information Notice, and then we toured the facility with licensee. Licensee indicated each location of the cameras in the home as followed: · there are four cameras total. · the exterior camera is the doorbell security camera installed by the security company, Vivant Security Systems, · the second camera is mounted by the hallway by the front door and faces the hallway stairs · the third camera is living room underneath the television facing the couch, · the fourth camera is in the kitchen above the fridge, and faces the kitchen, hallway and patio. LPA has reviewed images of the mobile app to ensure the camera angles did not face neighbor’s bedroom or bathroom windows, Only the administrator has access to the mobile app. Recordings are stored for ten days. The administrator showed LPA that the audio function has been disabled. The Administrators Addendum matches what is in the home. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this LIC 809 report is given to licensee.

In regard to youth refusing medication and youth’s truancy, youth explained that it’s the youth’s preference to stop taking medication and youth cannot be forced to take them. Youth explained that it’s also the youth’s choice to stop attending school. Youth acknowledge that youth’s treatment team constantly provides guidance and support to ensure youth’s safety and well-being. FP denied the allegations and explained that youth spends time outside the home with FP, staff/alternate caregiver and with individuals from youth’s treatment team. FP follows the youth’s safety plan due to youth’s known unsafe behaviors. FP contacted law enforcement and the placement agency once it was discovered that youth left the home. FP reached out to youth’s therapist and school personnel when youth started refusing to take medication and attend school. There were multiple meetings held to support the youth and ensure that youth’s goals are met as identified in the youth’s treatment and safety plans. Additional information obtained during the investigation revealed that FP went above and beyond to ensure that youth is always safe. FP maintains effective communication with school personnel, placement agency staff and other members of the youth’s team. Despite this, youth refused to follow through with the youth’s placement preservation plan. Based on information obtained, the allegations are determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is no preponderance of evidence found to support it. The following reports were provided to the facility representative at the conclusion of today’s inspection: LIC9099, LIC9099-C and LIC811 Confidential Names. Appeal rights forms were also given and explained. There was no deficiency citation issued.
investigation_findings: 13On July 22, 2025 at 9:35am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Irene Yamamoto conducted a subsequent complaint inspection at the facility and met with the licensee. The purpose of the inspection is to deliver the finding regarding the above allegations received by the Department on April 4, 2025. This LPA investigated the allegations. Confidential interviews were conducted with the identified youth and the foster parent (FP) on 4/7/25 and county placement agency staff on 6/16/25. Pertinent records were reviewed including, but not limited to the Personnel Report, Initial Needs and Case Plan Summary, Needs and Services Plan, Child and Family Team Meeting (CFTM) notes, Medication Records and Incident Reports. Information obtained from confidential interviews did not support the allegations. The allegations were denied by the youth who explained that the youth left without permission because the youth wouldn’t be allowed to spend time with individuals the youth wanted to. The youth informed FP and a staff/alternate caregiver that the youth planned on returning home when they reached out to the youth during youth’s AWOL.
